questions.text: A 22-year-old female from India presents with symptoms of arm claudication and a significant difference in blood pressure between her left and right arms. On further evaluation, she is found to have renal artery stenosis. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Takayasu arteritis:

  • In this scenario, the most likely diagnosis is Takayasu arteritis.
  • Takayasu arteritis is a large-vessel vasculitis commonly affecting young females, particularly from India. It is associated with ostial narrowing of the major arteries, including the renal artery, which can lead to reduced renal blood flow and hypertension.
  • Histologically, there is granulomatous thickening and narrowing of the aortic arch and proximal great vessels.
  • Clinical features:
    • Weak upper extremity pulses, blood pressure difference between left and right arms
    • Arm claudication
    • Fever, night sweats
    • Arthritis, myalgias
    • Skin nodules
    • Ocular disturbances 
  • Investigations: MR angiography is the investigation of choice, and helps stage the disease distribution. CT angiography can also be done.
  • Initial treatment of symptomatic Takayasu arteritis begins with corticosteroids.
  • Surgical revascularization is required in a few patients. 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Atherosclerosis of the renal artery: While atherosclerosis can cause renal artery stenosis, it typically occurs in older individuals, especially those with a history of smoking. In atherosclerosis, the entire length of the blood vessel narrows, whereas in Takayasu arteritis, only the ostium narrows.

Option B - Fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD): FMD is another cause of renal artery stenosis, typically seen in young females living in the USA. It is characterized by abnormal cell growth within the arterial wall, leading to narrowing. However, in this scenario, the clinical features (arm claudication, significant blood pressure difference) and the patient's origin (India) are more suggestive of Takayasu arteritis.

Option D - Coarctation of the aorta: Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital heart defect characterized by narrowing of the aorta, typically near the insertion of the ductus arteriosus. It causes a difference in blood pressure between the arms and legs, with higher blood pressure in the arms. However, this condition is usually diagnosed in childhood or early adulthood and is not associated with renal artery stenosis.

questions.text: At what age, the child can follow rapidly moving objects?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1 year:

  • 1 year: Follows rapidly moving objects

Incorrect Options:

Option A - 3 months:

  • Fixates instantaneously on an object shown to him (grasps with eyes)
  • Can follow the red dangling ring to 180 degrees

Option B - 4 months:

  • Binocular vision: Begins to develop by 6 weeks and established by 4 months of age

Option C - 1 month:

  • 4 weeks: Can follow the red dangling ring to 90 degrees

questions.text: A newly joined teacher develops rice water stools. The causative agent acts on which of the following receptors?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - GM 1 Ganglioside Receptor:

  • The presence of rice water stools suggests the causative agent is Vibrio cholerae.
  • Vibrio cholerae produces cholera toxin, which is coded by the CTx gene, and it is bipartite.
  • Cholera toxin has 2 fragments, A and B.
  • Fragment B has 5 subunits responsible for the attachment to the jejunal epithelial cells through GM 1 ganglioside.
  • Fragment A has 2 subunits, A1 and A2. A2 fragments link the active subunit A1 with the B fragment. Fragment A1 is biologically active subunit responsible for toxic effect,
    • Activate adenyl ate cyclase.
    • Phosphorylation of cystic fibrosis transmembrane protein.
    • Ions secreted in lumen, responsible for rice water stools.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: The active principle of this toxic seed is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ricin:

  • The given image is castor seed also known as Ricinus communis.
  • It contains an active principle- Ricin, which leads to intense gastroenteritis and bloody diarrhea.
  • Ricinus communis (Plant and seeds)

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Croton:

  • Croton Tiglium (Jamalgota): The processed seeds are used in Indian medicine for treating flatulence, dyspepsia, colic, edema, dyspnea and persistent cough.
  • All parts are poisonous, but seeds contain the maximum concentration of the active principles. Crotin, a toxalbumin and crotonoside, a glycoside are the active principles.

Option C - Abrin:

  • Abrus Precatorius (Rati, Gunchi, Jequirity): Seeds contain active principles, abrin, a thermolabile toxalbumin; abrine, an amino acid; hemagglutinin, a lipolytic enzyme; and abralin, a glycoside.

Option D - Capsicin:

  • Capsicum or Chilli fruits are universally employed as a condiment, the powdered form being known as Red Pepper or Lal Mirch.
  • Active Principles: Capsaicin and capsicin, are exceedingly acrid, volatile, non-alkaloidal, and non-fatal substances.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man complains of itching and a red, scaly rash in the groin area. He reports that he is active in the gym for long periods of time and repeats his clothes. What is the term for this condition, and what is its commonly used colloquial name?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Tinea Cruris; Dhobi Itch:

  • Tinea cruris is a fungal infection that commonly occurs in the groin area, often referred to colloquially as Dhobi Itch or Jock Itch. It is characterised by itching, redness, and a scaly rash, especially in regions with skin folds. The fungus tends to thrive in warm and moist environments, such as those caused by constant sweating. T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, and E. floccosum causes tinea cruris.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tinea Pedis; Athlete's Foot: Tinea Pedis, commonly known as Athlete's Foot, is a fungal infection that affects the feet, typically causing itching, scaling, and redness between the toes.

Option B - Tinea Versicolor; Sunspots: Tinea Versicolor is a fungal infection that presents with hypo- or hyperpigmented macules on the skin. It is not commonly referred to as "Sunspots."

Option D - Tinea Capitis; Ringworm: Tinea Capitis is a fungal infection affecting the scalp, often colloquially referred to as Ringworm. It causes hair loss and characteristic circular or annular lesions on the scalp.

questions.text: In a community medicine study assessing the efficacy of a new vaccination program, researchers aim to determine if the program reduces the incidence of a specific infectious disease in a population. They set the significance level (α) at 0.05. During analysis, they discover a statistically significant decrease in disease incidence among vaccinated individuals compared to the control group. However, upon further investigation, it is found that the decrease in disease incidence is not actually attributable to the vaccination program. Which of the following is not true about Type 1 error?

choices.text: The null hypothesis is false but rejected

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - The null hypothesis is false but rejected:

  • The correct statement would be: “The null hypothesis is true but rejected.”
  • Type 1 error means stating that there is an effect or difference when none exists (H0 incorrectly rejected in favor of H1).

 

Reality

H1

H0

Study rejects H0

Power (1-β)

Type 1 error (α)

Study does not reject H0

Type 2 error (β)

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - α error:

  • α error refers to the probability of rejecting the null hypothesis when it is actually true. In this case, the researchers set the significance level (α) at 0.05, indicating the threshold for accepting or rejecting the null hypothesis. Therefore, α error is related to this scenario.

Option B - False positive trial:

  • A false positive trial occurs when the intervention appears effective, but in reality, it does not have the intended effect. In this scenario, the apparent decrease in disease incidence among vaccinated individuals constitutes a false positive result because the vaccination program is not the cause of the observed reduction.

Option C - Serious error:

  • Type 1 is a serious error in hypothesis testing as it can lead to incorrect conclusions and potentially harmful decisions, such as implementing an ineffective intervention or treatment.

questions.text: All of the following are the fetal complications of Multiple pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Downs syndrome:

  • Down syndrome is not a fetal complication of Multiple pregnancy
  • The fetal complications of Multiple pregnancy are as follows:
  • The fetal complications are as follows:
  • Increased IUGR
  • Discordant twins
  • Single fetal demise
  • Congenital anomalies
  • Increased Malpresentation
  • Twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and C:

  • These are the fetal complications of Multiple pregnancy

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of dimunition of vision in his left eye for the past three months. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) is performed, showing the findings given below.What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cystoid macular edema :

  • The OCT examination in the above patient shows presence of cystoid spaces filled with fluid . These findings along with the presenting clinical features indicate the presence of cystoid macular edema.

CME (Cystoid Macular Edema)

Cystoid macular edema (CME) is swelling of the layers of the neurosensory retina within the macula. When excess fluid builds in the retina, it typically collects in “pockets,” referred to as “cysts.”

Signs and Symptoms:

  • Slow, painless loss of vision
  • Metamorphopsia (distortion of shape)
  • Micropsia (objects appear small and distorted) or macropsia (objects appear large and distorted)

Diagnostic Tools:

  • Amsler's grid
  • +90 D lens (best instrument to examine CME)

Investigations:

Fluorescein Angiography (FA):

  • Dye used: Fluorescein Sodium
  • Arm retina circulation time: 12 seconds
  • Pattern of leak indicates pathology
  • Limitations: invasive and may cause allergy

Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT):

  • Gold standard investigation for all macular disorders
  • Non-invasive
  • Provides a cross-sectional view of the retina

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Central serous retinopathy: It typically presents with serous retinal detachment and fluid accumulation underneath the neurosensory retina, often occurring in younger patients and often associated with stress or corticosteroid use.

Option C - Retinal detachment : It involves the separation of the neurosensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium and is associated with symptoms like flashes of light and a sensation of a "curtain" coming down over the vision.

Option D - Age related macular degeneration : It is characterized by the gradual deterioration of the macula, often leading to central vision loss, but it usually presents with drusen and pigmentary changes, rather than cystic spaces seen in CME.

questions.text: A 15-year-old female was brought to the clinic by her mother with complaints of absence of menstruation till now. On examination and evaluation, secondary sexual characters were present. Which of the following is the diagnosis of the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Primary amenorrhoea:

  • Primary amenorrhea is defined as a girl who never had periods up until 13 years or up to 15 years when secondary sexual characteristics are present without delay.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Secondary amenorrhoea:

  • Secondary amenorrhoea is defined as no periods for 6 months or when she misses 3 regular cycles

Option C - Metropathia haemorrhagica:

  • Metropathia haemorrhagica is defined as prolonged amenorrhea followed by a heavy withdrawal
  • It is characterized by an anovulatory bleed after 40 (~ 45-48 years) years of age

Option D – Menometrorrhagia:

  • Menometrorrhagia is defined as Irregular acyclical bleed (no fixed pattern)

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male presented with yellowish discoloration of his skin and sclera. He is otherwise normal. He gives a history of viral infection 10 days ago, which was resolved 2 days back. He also gives a history of similar episodes in the past following any illness. Lab values are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Serum bilirubin: 2.4 mg/dL Unconjugated bilirubin: 2.1mg/dL Conjugated bilirubin: 0.3mg/dL Serum AST and ALT: Normal
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Gilbert syndrome:

  • Gilbert Syndrome is a genetic disorder affecting bilirubin processing in the liver due to a mutation in the UGT1A1 gene, which encodes the enzyme UGT.
  • Reduced UGT activity leads to bilirubin accumulation, causing jaundice during stress or illness.
  • Diagnosis involves blood tests for bilirubin levels, distinguishing it from other syndromes.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Dubin-Johnson syndrome: Rare disorder impacting bilirubin secretion, resulting in conjugated bilirubin buildup and skin discoloration. Contrastingly, Gilbert's syndrome involves unconjugated bilirubin accumulation.

Option B - Criggler-Najar type 1 syndrome: Rare genetic disorder causing severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, leading to jaundice and complications. Differs from Gilbert's syndrome due to the severity and UDP-glucuronosyltransferase deficiency.

Option D - Rotor syndrome: Rare disorder causing conjugated bilirubin accumulation, akin to Dubin-Johnson syndrome, but distinguished by absence of dark pigments in urine, unlike Dubin-Johnson syndrome.

questions.text: All of the following are indications for kidney biopsy in PSGN except?

choices.text: Raised C3 at the beginning of the illness
Clinical features and/or low C levels persisting even >2 months after onset of illness

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Raised C3 at the beginning of the illness:

  • In Post-Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN), a kidney biopsy is generally not required unless the clinical course or presentation deviates from the expected. 

  • Indications for a kidney biopsy in PSGN:
    • A. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): In cases of PSGN, most patients recover with conservative management. However, if there is significant AKI that is not resolving, a biopsy may be warranted to rule out other causes.
    • B. Nephritic-Nephrotic Presentation: A nephritic-nephrotic syndrome presentation is atypical for PSGN and may indicate an underlying or co-existing glomerular disease, prompting the need for a biopsy.
    • D. Clinical features and/or low complement (C3) levels persisting >2 months: In PSGN, complement levels (specifically C3) are typically low at the onset of the illness and return to normal within 6-8 weeks. Persistently low C3 levels or persistent clinical features beyond 2 months raise the suspicion of other glomerulopathies (e.g., membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis), and a biopsy is indicated.
  • In PSGN, C3 levels are usually low at the onset of the disease due to complement activation by immune complexes. Raised or normal C3 levels at the beginning are atypical but not an indication for a biopsy by themselves.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B and D are indications for renal biopsy in PSGN.

questions.text: Nissl's body is an aggregate of rough endoplasmic reticulum and free ribosomes, which of the following is not true regarding Nissl’s body?

choices.text: The highest density is found in motor neurons
They are rich in RNA material

questions.solution:
Correct Option B – They are eosinophilic in nature:

  • Nissl bodies are basophilic, not eosinophilic. They stain blue or purple when using basic dyes like methylene blue or hematoxylin due to their high RNA content, which binds to these dyes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – The highestdensity is found in motor neurons: This statement is true. Nissl bodies have the highest density in motor neurons, which are metabolically very active and require substantial protein synthesis.

Option C – Never found in axonal cytoplasm: This statement is true. Nissl bodies are primarily found in the cell body or soma of neurons and are absent in the axonal cytoplasm.

Option D – They are rich in RNA material: This statement is true. Nissl bodies consist of aggregated rough endoplasmic reticulum and free ribosomes, which are rich in RNA.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases does not fall in the category of disease under vision 2020 globally?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Diabetic retinopathy:

  • Diabetic retinopathy is included in diseases under India vision 2020
Diseases under India Vision 2020 Disease under vision 2020 globally
  • Cataract
  • Childhood blindness
  • Refractive errors & low vision
  • Corneal blindness
  • Diabetic retinopathy
  • Glaucoma · Trachoma
  • Cataract
  • Childhood blindness
  • Refractive errors & low vision
  • Trachoma
  • Onchocercariasis

Incorrect Options: 

  • Options A, B and C are incorrect

questions.text: In a clinical investigation of nerve function, which type of nerve fiber is most likely to exhibit the highest spike duration during an action potential?

choices.text: Spike duration is equal for all the nerve fibers

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - C fibers:

  • Spike duration is the duration for which a neuron's membrane potential remains elevated during an action potential. Slow nerve fibers typically have longer spike durations compared to fast fibers. C fibers, being unmyelinated and slower, often exhibit longer spike durations than myelinated fibers.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – A fiber: A-alpha fibers are large-diameter, myelinated fibers. They typically have shorter spike durations due to their myelination and larger diameter, allowing for faster conduction.

Option B – B fiber: B fibers are medium-diameter, myelinated fibers primarily associated with the autonomic nervous system. They generally have moderate spike durations.

Option D - Spike duration is equal for all the nerve fibers: This statement is inaccurate. Different nerve fibers exhibit variations in spike duration due to differences in diameter and myelination.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions Oschner-Sherren's regimen is used as management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Appendicular mass:

  • Oschner-Sherren is indicated in appendicular mass.
  • If an appendix mass is present and the patient's condition is satisfactory, the standard treatment is the conservative Oschner-Sherren regime.
    • Temperature, pulse and Fluid record should be recorded 4 hourly.
    •  
    • The extent of mass should be marked and examined regularly.
    • NPO And IV fluid supplement.
    • Antibiotics and Analgesics.
    • Allow oral liquid on subsequent days.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Appendicular abscess:

  • The appendicular abscess is a collection of pus resulting from necrosis of the tissue superimposed with infection in an inflamed appendix.
  • Treatment of appendicular abscesses usually involves drained radiologically.

Option B - Chronic appendicitis:

  • Chronic appendicitis is along-standing inflammation or fibrosis of the appendix that presents clinically as prolonged or intermittent abdominal pain.
  • The preferred treatment for chronic appendicitis is surgical removal of the appendix (appendectomy) rather than conservative management.

Option D - Acute appendicitis:

  • Acute appendicitis is an inflammatory condition of the appendix characterized by acute severe right iliac fossa pain and leukocytosis and requires urgent appendectomy.

questions.text: Which among the following best describes the 'Wartenberg sign'?

choices.text: Inability to adduct a small finger against the ring finger
Inability to flex the middle finger
Inability to maintain intrinsic plus position

questions.solution:
Option A: Inability to adduct a small finger against the ring finger

  • Wartenberg's sign/test is used for assessing the integrity of the motor innervations of hand intrinsics in cases of suspected ulnar neuropathy. It refers to the slightly greater abduction of the fifth digit. It is due to weakness or paralysis of the adducting palmar interosseous muscle and also due to the unopposed action of the radial innervated extensor muscles, e.g., digiti mini, digitorum communis
  • It should not be confused with Waardenburg syndrome; it is an entrapment of the superficial branch of the radial nerve; it only manifests with sensory abnormalities and no motor deficits.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B: Inability to extend the wrist

  • This patient's radial nerve is intact to extend his wrist.

Option C: Inability to flex the middle finger

  • The median nerve mainly Supplies the flexors of a middle finger, so flexion of the middle fingers would be intact in this patient.

Option D: Inability to maintain intrinsic plus position

  • The intrinsic plus position is the position in which MCP joints are Flexed at 60°, the IP joints are fully extended, the thumb is in the first position, and the wrist is held in an extended position.
  • An ulnar nerve palsy doesn't affect the position.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with sudden painless loss of vision in the left eye. On examination, the following retinal findings are observed. Please select the most likely diagnosis based on the retinal findings:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO):

  

  • The findings in the above images are Hollenhorst plaques, Cherry red spot, and Box car appearance in the retinal vessels, respectively. The presence of a cherry red spot in the macula, along with a boxcar or cattle truck appearance of the retinal vessels and the presence of Hollenhorst plaques or emboli in the retinal arteries, strongly suggests CRAO.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Branch retinal artery occlusion (BRAO): BRAO typically presents with a sudden, painless loss of vision  in a specific portion of the visual field corresponding to the affected branch of retinal artery. The cherry red spot, as described in the case, is more characteristic of CRAO involving the entire macula.

Option C - Retinal detachment: Retinal detachment is characterized by the separation of the neurosensory retina from the underlying retinal pigment epithelium. It may present with symptoms such as floaters, flashes of light, and a curtain-like visual field defect. The cherry red spot and specific retinal vessel changes described are not typical of retinal detachment.

Option D -  Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO): CRVO is characterized by venous congestion, retinal hemorrhages, cotton wool spots, and macular edema. The presence of a cherry red spot and the specific retinal vessel changes described are not consistent with CRVO.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics inhibits the attachment of transfer RNA (tRNA) amino acids to the A-site on the 30S ribosome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Tetracycline:

  • Tetracycline inhibits protein synthesis by blocking the attachment of transfer RNA (tRNA) amino acids to the A-site on the 30S ribosome.
  • This action prevents the incorporation of amino acids into growing peptide chains.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Chloramphenicol: Chloramphenicol inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit and inhibiting peptidyl transferase activity. It does not specifically target the attachment of tRNA amino acids to the A-site on the 30S ribosome.

Option C - Linezolid: Linezolid inhibits protein synthesis by attaching to the 23S ribosomal RNA of the 50S ribosomal subunit, preventing the formation of the initiation complex. It does not directly interfere with the attachment of tRNA amino acids to the A-site on the 30S ribosome.

Option D - Aminoglycoside: Aminoglycosides bind to the 30S ribosomal subunit and interfere with the proofreading process of mRNA translation, leading to the misreading of the genetic code. While they can inhibit initiation of protein synthesis, their primary mechanism involves interfering with translation elongation and proofreading, rather than specifically targeting the attachment of tRNA amino acids to the A-site.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with complaints of pain and stiffness in the forearm. An x-ray of the forearm is given below. Which of the following is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Excessive fluoride intake:

  • The ossification of the interosseous membrane, as indicated by the x-ray of the radius and ulna, suggests fluorosis. Fluorosis is a condition caused by prolonged exposure to high levels of fluoride.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Elevated cortisol levels: Elevated cortisol levels are associated with conditions like Cushing's syndrome, but they do not typically cause ossification of the interosseous membrane as seen in fluorosis.

Option B - Insufficient sunlight exposure: Insufficient sunlight exposure can lead to vitamin D deficiency, but it is not directly related to the ossification of the interosseous membrane. Vitamin D deficiency is more commonly associated with conditions like rickets. Radiological features of rickets include widened and irregular growth plates, particularly at the wrists and knees, and cupping, fraying, and splaying of the metaphysis in long bones. Additionally, there may be a "cupped" or "trident" appearance at the wrist joint.

Option D - Impaired kidney function: While impaired kidney function can lead to abnormalities in mineral metabolism, it is not a primary cause of interosseous membrane ossification.

questions.text: How long should a primigravida wait before starting breastfeeding after delivering a healthy baby through a normal delivery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Within 1 hour:

  • According to the World Health Organization (WHO), breastfeeding should be initiated within the first hour after birth. This is important because colostrum, the first milk produced by the mother, is rich in nutrients and antibodies that help protect the newborn from infections and diseases. It also helps to establish a strong bond between the mother and baby and stimulates milk production. 

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - After 1 hour: Waiting for one hour to initiate breastfeeding may cause the baby to miss out on the benefits of colostrum and delay the establishment of breastfeeding.

Option C - After 4-6 hours: Waiting for 4-6 hours to initiate breastfeeding is not recommended as it may negatively affect the baby's health and well-being. 

Option D - After 24 hours: Waiting for 24 hours to initiate breastfeeding is not recommended as it may negatively affect the baby's health and well-being.

questions.text: Which arteries contribute to the plexus that is a common site for anterior epistaxis in children?

choices.text: Anterior ethmoidal artery, posterior ethmoidal artery, sphenopalatine artery, greater palatine artery
Anterior ethmoidal artery, septal branch of the superior labial artery, septal branch of sphenopalatine artery, greater palatine artery
Anterior ethmoidal artery, septal branch of the superior labial artery, greater palatine artery, nasal branch of anterior superior dental artery
Anterior ethmoidal artery, posterior ethmoidal artery, the nasal branch of the anterior superior dental artery, branches of the facial artery to nasal vestibule

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Anterior ethmoidal artery, septal branch of the superior labial artery, septal branch of sphenopalatine artery, greater palatine artery:

Kiesselbach's plexus, also known as Little's area, is a vascular plexus located in the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum. It is a common site for epistaxis particularly in children. The plexus is formed by the anastomosis of four arteries.:

  • Anterior ethmoidal artery
  • Septal branch of superior labial artery
  • Septal branch of sphenopalatine artery
  • Greater palatine artery

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anterior ethmoidal artery, posterior ethmoidal artery, sphenopalatine artery, greater palatine artery.:

  • The posterior ethmoidal artery is not part of Kiesselbach's plexus. The posterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic artery and supplies the nasal septum as well as the lateral wall of the nose.

Option C - Anterior ethmoidal artery, septal branch of the superior labial artery, greater palatine artery, the nasal branch of the anterior superior dental artery.:

  • The superior labial artery and the nasal branch of the anterior superior dental artery are not part of Kiesselbach's plexus.

Option D - Anterior ethmoidal artery, posterior ethmoidal artery, the nasal branch of the anterior superior dental artery, branches of the facial artery to nasal vestibule:

Anterior ethmoidal artery, nasal branch of the anterior superior dental artery, greater palatine artery, septal branch of the superior labial artery.

  • The nasal branch of the anterior superior dental artery are not part of Kiesselbach's plexus.

questions.text: What condition is related to a 3-year-old with diarrhea, runny nose, fever, erythematous rash on the face, and upper limb pain, whose mother had a history of blood transfusion during pregnancy?

choices.text: Affects erythroid progenitors but individuals who totally lack Blood Group P antigen are resistant to infection.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Affects erythroid progenitors but individuals who totally lack Blood Group P antigen are resistant to infection:

  • People who do not have P antigen, which is the cellular receptor for parvovirus B19, are naturally resistant to infection with this pathogen.
  • Parvoviruses are the smallest viruses. 
  • They belong to the family Parvoviridae.
  • Shows tropism for erythroid progenitor cells. → aplastic crises in Sickle cell anaemic patients
  • Tropism for RBCs: It infects RBC precursors by using P blood group Ag as a receptor.
  • Transmission: Most commonly by the respiratory route, followed by blood transfusion and transplacental transmission (occurs in 30% of cases with maximum risk in the second trimester).
  • Associated with:
    • NIHF (non-immune hydrops fetalis).
    • Polyarthralgia syndrome- Pain is more in upper limb joints than lower limb joints.
    • Erythema infectiosum /5th disease- slapped check appearance.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - <10% spread by transplacental route:

  • The most common mode of transmission is the respiratory route.
  • The transplacental transmission occurs in 30% or higher cases with maximum risk in the second trimester.

Option B - Parvovirus B19 exclusively infects animals:

  • Parvovirus only infects humans.

Option C - It is an RNA virus:

  • It is not a RNA virus.
  • Parvovirus is a non-enveloped single-stranded DNA virus.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old contact lens wearer presents with sudden-onset severe eye pain, photophobia, and a purulent discharge in the left eye. On examination stromal edema and other features as in image below are note:



 Which of the following statements regarding this condition is false?

choices.text: Pneumococcus causes Ulcer Serpens also called hypopyon corneal ulcer
Hypopyon in bacterial keratitis is a sterile hypopyon containing pus cells in Anterior chamber
Nocardia is a bacterial keratitis that resembles fungal keratitis
Staphylococcus aureus is the most common bacteria causing keratitis in India

questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Staphylococcus aureus is the most common bacteria causing keratitis in India:

  • Staphylococcus aureus is known to cause keratitis, but in the Indian context, organisms like Staphylococcus epidermidis are more commonly associated with corneal infections. The prevalence of causative organisms can vary by geographic region.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pneumococcus causes Ulcer Serpens, also called hypopyon corneal ulcer.

  • True. Pneumococcus is known to cause a type of corneal ulcer called Ulcer Serpens, characterized by a snake-like pattern of corneal inflammation. This type of ulcer is associated with the presence of a hypopyon.

Option B - Hypopyon in bacterial keratitis is a sterile hypopyon containing pus cells in the anterior chamber.

  • True. Hypopyon in bacterial keratitis is sterile; it typically contains pus cells

Option C - Nocardia is a bacterial keratitis that resembles fungal keratitis.

  • Nocardia is a bacterium that can cause keratitis, and its clinical presentation may resemble fungal keratitis. This can make the diagnosis challenging and may require laboratory testing for confirmation. However bacterial keratitis has more symptoms when compared to fungal keratitis.

questions.text: Which among the following nerves gives the sensory innervation to the palm?
questions.solution:
Option A: Ulnar and Median nerve

  • The cutaneous innervation of the palm involves three nerves: Mainly the Median nerve and Ulnar nerve, along with a slight contribution from the superficial branch of the radial nerve.
  • Lateral two-third of the palm is supplied by the palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve.
  • Medial one-third of the palm is supplied by the palmar cutaneous branch of the ulnar nerve.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B,C and D:

  • The majority of the cutaneous innervation of the palm is supplied by the median and ulnar nerves.
  • The radial nerve contributes to a slight portion on the lateral side of the thumb via its superficial branch.
  • The musculocutaneous nerve ends as a lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman from a rural area presents to the vision center with complaints of decreased night vision and dryness of the eyes. On ocular examination, the woman is found to have an ulcer involving <⅓ rd of the cornea. On lab investigations, the serum retinol level is 2 mcg/dL. At what stage of Vitamin A deficiency can the signs be reversed with treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - X2:

  • ​​​​​Description: This stage is characterized by dryness of the cornea (corneal xerosis) and can present with symptoms such as decreased night vision and dryness of the eyes.
  • Reversibility: The signs of Vitamin A deficiency at this stage can be reversed with appropriate treatment, such as supplementation with Vitamin A. This is because the structural integrity of the cornea is still largely intact, and the condition has not yet progressed to more severe and irreversible stages.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - X3B:

  • This stage indicates severe Vitamin A deficiency but with more pronounced clinical features including corneal xerosis, corneal ulceration, and keratomalacia.
  • The ulcer involves > ⅓ rd of the cornea.
  • At this stage, irreversible ocular damage has already occurred, and treatment aims to prevent further progression rather than reversal of existing signs.

Option C - XS:

  • XS denotes the presence of a corneal scar, a secondary sign of vitamin A deficiency.
  • A scar is an irreversible change.

Option D - XF:

  • XF refers to the occurrence of fundal changes.
  • This is a very severe change and cannot be reversed.

questions.text: What is the positive wave in an ECG that appears after the wave representing atrial depolarization?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - R wave:

  • The R wave is the first positive deflection within the ECG after the P wave(atrial depolarization). It represents the depolarization of the ventricles.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Q wave: The Q wave is the first negative deflection after the P wave. It indicates septal depolarization.

Option C - T wave: The T wave represents the repolarization of both the right and left ventricles.

Option D - S wave: The S wave represents depolarization of the base of ventricles.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with complaints of persistent dry eyes and mouth. She reports experiencing frequent episodes of gritty sensation in her eyes and difficulty swallowing dry food. In a suspected case of Sjogren's syndrome , which HLA associations would be most relevant to investigate in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - HLA DR3, Drw52:

  • Sjögren's syndrome is associated with specific HLA associations, including HLA DR3 and Drw52.
  • Therefore, investigating HLA DR3 and Drw52 would be most relevant in this patient to confirm the diagnosis of Sjögren's syndrome.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - HLA DR4, Drw53: While HLA DR4 is associated with other autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis, it is not a common HLA association in Sjögren's syndrome.

Option B - HLA DR5, Drw52: HLA DR5 is not a known HLA association in Sjögren's syndrome.

Option D - HLA DR2, Drw52: While HLA DR2 is associated with other autoimmune diseases like multiple sclerosis, it is not a common HLA association in Sjögren's syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is scheduled for intubation before surgery. During the airway assessment, the following findings were noted: Facial trauma, Inter Incisor Distance of >3 finger breadths, Thyroid To Mouth Distance of 2 finger breadths, Mallampati Class III, and the patient can touch his chest with his chin. What is the total Lemon Airway Classification score for this patient?
questions.solution:
Based on the given findings:

  • Facial trauma = 1 point
  • Inter Incisor Distance > 3 finger breadths = 1 point
  • Thyroid To Mouth Distance of 2 finger breadths = 0 points
  • Mallampati Class III = 1 point
  • The patient can touch his chest with his chin = 1 point

In the Lemon Airway Classification system, points are assigned based on several parameters to predict the ease of intubation. The parameters are:

 

Look externally

facial trauma = 1 point

Evaluate 3-3-2 rule

Inter Incisor Distance > 3 finger breadths = 1 point, Thyroid To Mouth Distance < 3 finger breadths = 0 points

Mallampati Class

Class III = 1 point

Obstruction or lack thereof

ability to extend the neck = 0 points

Neck mobility

ability to touch the chest with the chin = 1 point

 

Adding these points together, the total Lemon Airway Classification score for this patient is:

Therefore, the correct answer is C. 4 points.

questions.text: Which of the following joint allows abduction and adduction movement of the foot?
questions.solution:
Option B: Subtalar joint

  • The posterior joint between the talus and the calcaneum is known as the subtalar joint. 
  • It is a plane joint and articulates between the inner body of the talus body and the left facet in the middle of the upper surface of the calcaneum. 
  • The capsule encloses the joint and is attached to the margins of the articular areas of the two bones. 
  • The synovial membrane lines the capsule. The important movements of inversion and eversion of the foot occur at the subtalar and transverse tarsal joints. 
  • There is a slight movement of abduction and adduction at this joint, comparing the other choices.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Ankle joint

  • The movements at the ankle joint are plantar flexion, dorsiflexion, inversion, and eversion.

Option C: Tarso-metatarsal joint

  • The tarsometatarsal joint allows moderate amounts of dorsiflexion and plantar flexion, coupled with small amounts of inversion and eversion.

Option D: None

  • This option is incorrect because the subtalar joint allows slight movement of abduction and adduction.

questions.text:
After subarachnoid analgesia for delivery, a 24-year-old woman experiences progressively worsening throbbing pain in the back of her head, radiating to the neck and shoulder, nausea, vomiting, and neck stiffness. In what order were the following structures pierced during the analgesia?

a) Epidural space

b) Interspinous ligament

c) Supraspinous ligament

d) Ligamentum flavum

e) Subarachnoid space
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: c-b-d-a-e

  • Structures pierced in sequence:
    • Skin
    • Fat
    • Supraspinous & interspinous ligaments
    • Ligamentum flavum
    • Epidural space
    • Dura mater
    • Arachnoid
    • Subarachnoid space
  • When carrying out lumbar puncture, the needle passes between adjacent vertebral spinous processes, through the supraspinous and interspinous ligaments, and enters the extradural space.
  • The needle continues through the dura and arachnoid mater and enters the subarachnoid space containing CSF.
  • Lumbar puncture is usually done to obtain a sample of CSF for examination and to inject antibiotics, chemotherapeutic drugs, and some anesthetics into the subarachnoid space.
  • The lumbar region is the best site to access the subarachnoid space because the spinal cord terminates around the level of discs between L1 and L2 in adults.
  • The subarachnoid space usually extends to the region of the lower border of the S2 vertebrae.
  • Therefore, there is a large CSF-filled space containing lumbar and sacral roots but no spinal cord.

questions.text: Which of the following is the gestational age at which the amniotic fluid is maximum?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 32 weeks:

  • The gestational age at which the amniotic fluid is maximum is 32 weeks

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C and D:

  • The amniotic fluid is not maximum in these gestational ages

questions.text: Ectopia lentis is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A -Homocystinuria:

  • Ectopia lentis refers to the abnormal displacement or dislocation of the lens of the eye. It can occur as a result of various underlying conditions. Among the given options condition associated with ectopia lentis is homocystinuria.
  • Other diseases associated with ectopia lentis are:
    • Marfan syndrome.
    • Weill Marchesani syndrome.
    • Ehler’s Danlos syndrome.
    • Hyperlysinemia.
    • Sulphite oxidase deficiency.
    • Stickler syndrome.
       

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Refsum's disease: Refsum's disease, also known as heredopathia atactica polyneuritiformis, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of phytanic acid in the body. It primarily affects the nervous system and other organs but is not associated with ectopia lentis.

Option C - Wilson's disease: Wilson's disease is an inherited disorder that leads to abnormal copper metabolism in the body, resulting in copper accumulation in various organs, particularly the liver and brain. It manifest as Kayser-Fleischer ring in the cornea.

Option D - Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is a systemic inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs, including the eyes. Ocular manifestations inlude band-shaped keratopathy, and uveitis.

questions.text: What contributes to the generation of the fourth heart sound in the cardiac cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Vibration of ventricular wall:

  • The fourth heart sound occurs after the AV valves open during rapid ventricular filling.
  • It occurs due to the vibration of the ventricular wall or the vibration of the blood in the ventricular cavity.
  • It occurs during the last rapid filling phase (LRFP) due to atrial contraction.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Closure of the atrioventricular valves:

  • The S4 sound is not associated with atrioventricular valve closure.

Option B - Opening of the tricuspid valve:

  • The S4 sound is not associated with not tricuspid valve opening.

Option C - Opening of the atrioventricular valves::

  • The fourth heart sound (S4) is not associated with atrioventricular valves.

questions.text: The Norwood-Hamilton classification is commonly used to assess the stage and severity of which type of hair loss?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Male androgenic alopecia:

  • The Norwood-Hamilton classification is a widely used system for grading and describing the patterns of male pattern hair loss, which is also known as androgenic alopecia or male pattern baldness. The classification provides a visual representation of the progression and severity of hair loss in men.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Telogen effluvium:  Telogen effluvium is a temporary form of hair loss characterized by the shedding of hair due to a disruption in the premature entry of hair into the telogen phase due to the risk factors (stress). It is not graded using the Norwood-Hamilton classification.

Option B - Alopecia areata: Alopecia areata is an autoimmune condition that causes patchy hair loss. It is not classified using the Norwood-Hamilton system, as this classification is specific to male pattern hair loss.

Option D - Traction alopecia: Traction alopecia is hair loss caused by excessive tension or pulling on the hair. It is not graded using the Norwood-Hamilton classification.

questions.text: A child was brought to the clinic by his father complaining of fever along with a rash that began on the first day of fever. On examination, the rash is pleomorphic. The doctor explained to the interns that it is caused by a DNA virus from the Herpesviridae family and the incubation period is 10-12 days. Which among the following is not a complication of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Otitis media:

  • The condition that is described in the question is Chickenpox
  • It is caused by Varicella zoster virus
  • Otitis media is not a complication of this disease

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stroke

Option B - Transverse myelitis

Option C - Optic neuritis

  • These are the complications of Chickenpox

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the neurology clinic with progressive weakness and muscle atrophy in his limbs. He reports difficulty in performing daily activities such as walking and lifting objects. Upon examination, the patient exhibits muscle fasciculations and hyperreflexia. All are the factors contributing to the pathology of this condition except?
questions.solution:
Correct option D - Increased Methionine levels:

  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the degeneration of upper and lower motor neurons, leading to muscle weakness, atrophy, and eventual paralysis.
  • Several factors contribute to the pathology of ALS:
    • Defective protein degradation in neurons:
    • Defective RNA processing
    • In ALS, dysfunctional glutamate handling mechanisms, such as impaired glutamate uptake by astrocytes and downregulation of glutamate transporters like EAAT2 (excitatory amino acid transporter 2), lead to increased extracellular glutamate levels.
    • Excessive glutamate accumulation overactivates glutamate receptors, triggering calcium influx and subsequent neuronal injury.
    • Excitotoxicity contributes to motor neuron degeneration in ALS and is implicated in disease pathogenesis.
  • There is no increase in the level of Methionine in the pathology of Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, C:

  • These are the factors associated with the pathology of Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

questions.text:
Identify the fracture in the X-ray and mark the option with the right statements.



a) Piedmont fracture is another name for this condition

b) Galeazzi sign is seen in the above X-ray

c) Extensor carpi ulnaris tendon entrapment is common

d) ORIF with long plates and screws is the treatment of choice

e) Piano key sign is a classical sign

f)Monteggia fracture is more common than this fracture
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - a,d,e:

  • The X-ray shows fracture of lower-third of radius indicating a Galeazzi fracture
  • a) Piedmont fracture is another name for this condition
  • d) ORIF with long plates and screws is the treatment of choice
  • e) Piano key sign is a classical sign

Incorrect Options:

Option A - b,c,f:

  • The X-ray shows Galeazzi fracture and not Galeazzi sign. Galeazzi sign is found in DDH(ALLIS TEST).These two are completely different entities.
  • Entrapment of extensor carpi ulnaris tendon is rare.
  • Galeazzi fracture is more common than Monteggia fracture.

Option C - a,b,f: This option can be eliminated by above explanation

Option D - b,d,e: This option can be eliminated by above explanation

questions.text: At which level does the hypopharynx extend inferiorly?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - C6:

  • The hypopharynx, also known as the laryngopharynx, extends inferiorly from the level of the tip of the epiglottis to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage, which corresponds to the C6 vertebral level.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - C2: The hypopharynx extends up to C6 vertebrae.

Option B - C7: The hypopharynx extends up to C6 vertebrae.

Option C - C4: The hypopharynx extends up to C6 vertebrae.

questions.text: A child is presented with pale skin and blonde hair. His pedigree is given below. Identify the type of given pedigree.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Autosomal recessive: 

  • In autosomal recessive inheritance, the disorder typically appears in individuals who have two copies of the defective gene (homozygous) or in individuals who inherit one defective gene from each parent (heterozygous).
  • This means that both parents are typically unaffected carriers of the disorder, and the disorder may skip generations before appearing.
  • The pedigree given here shows the characteristic features of autosomal recessive inheritance:
    • Affected individuals usually have unaffected parents.
    • Consanguinity (relatedness between parents) is more common in autosomal recessive disorders because both parents carry the same recessive allele.
    • Both males and females are affected with equal frequency.
    • Affected individuals may have siblings who are also affected.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - X-linked recessive:

  • X-linked recessive disorders typically show a pattern where affected males are more common than affected females, as males only have one X chromosome, and if it carries the defective gene, they will manifest the disorder.
  • In the given pedigree, there is no clear pattern of affected males being more common.

Option B - Autosomal dominant:

  • Autosomal dominant disorders usually have affected individuals in every generation, as only one copy of the defective gene is needed for the disorder to manifest.
  • In the given pedigree, there are unaffected parents who have an affected child, which is not characteristic of autosomal dominant inheritance.

Option C - X-linked dominant:

  • X-linked dominant disorders typically affect more females than males, as females have two X chromosomes, and if one carries the defective gene, they are more likely to manifest the disorder.
  • In the given pedigree, there is no clear pattern of more affected females than males.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents to the clinic with swelling behind the ears. The child developed a rash 10 days ago on the face and spread to the trunk and extremities. On examination, you notice occipital and postauricular lymphadenopathy. The child's mother mentions that he had a mild fever since yesterday. The pediatrician suspects a viral illness. Which of the following is the secondary attack rate of this illness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 80%:

  • The child likely has rubella, caused by the rubella virus. Symptoms include a 3-day maculopapular rash, often accompanied by fever, malaise, upper respiratory symptoms, and lymphadenopathy, particularly in the second week after exposure. Subclinical cases or those without a rash are also common.
  • The secondary attack rate (SAR) refers to the proportion of susceptible individuals who develop a specific disease after being exposed to a primary case within a defined period.
  • The SAR for rubella is 80%.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, D:

  • These are not the secondary attack rates for rubella.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with features of a fistula above the lacrimal sac after abscess drainage by interns. What is the next step for the management of fistula?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Dacryocystorhinostomy:

  • The most appropriate treatment for lacrimal fistula is dacryocystorhinostomy. This is a surgical procedure that creates a new passageway between the lacrimal sac and the nasal cavity for the drainage of tears.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Fistulectomy:

  • This involves the surgical removal of a fistula, which is an abnormal connection between two hollow structure of the body.

Option C - Nasolacrimal duct probing:

  • This is a less invasive procedure used to treat nasolacrimal duct obstruction, which can cause symptoms like tearing not preferred for lacrimal fistula.

Option D - Warm compresses:

  • Warm compresses are a non-invasive, conservative measure often used to alleviate symptoms associated with inflammation and swelling. Therefore, the definitive treatment of lacrimal fistula is Dacryocystorhinostomy.

questions.text: A term 10-week-old male baby was brought to the clinic complaining of not gaining weight adequately. On examination by the Pediatrician, Tachypnea and tachycardia were present. On auscultation, a continuous machinery murmur was found. Chest X-ray was advised, and the report showed Cardiomegaly with LV apex. What is the drug of choice for this condition in preterm neonates?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Indomethacin:

  • This is the drug of choice used for the closure of Patent ductus arteriosus in preterm neonates
  • It is a prostaglandin inhibitor
  • The condition described in the question is Patent ductus arteriosus
  • It is characterized by failure to thrive, tachypnea, tachycardia, and a continuous machinery murmur on auscultation

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Aspirin

Option C - Digoxin

Option D - Furosemide

  • These are not the drugs of choice for closure of Patent ductus arteriosus

questions.text:
Match the following:


	
		
			
			1
			
			
			Type I thyroplasty
			
			
			A
			
			
			Shortening of vocal cords
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			Type II thyroplasty
			
			
			B
			
			
			Medialization of vocal cords
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			Type III thyroplasty
			
			
			C
			
			
			Lengthening of vocal cords
			
		
		
			
			4
			
			
			Type IV thyroplasty
			
			
			D
			
			
			Lateralization of vocal cords
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1-B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-C:

Type 1 Thyroplasty (Medialization of vocal cords)
  • In type 1 thyroplasty, a window is created in the thyroid cartilage and then an implant (silastic or cartilage) is placed in the paraglottic space. The placement of an implant helps to push the vocal cord in the midline.

Type 2 Thyroplasty (Lateralization of vocal cords)
  • Lateralization of vocal cord is done either by resecting the arytenoid known as arytenoidectomy or via cordectomy (removal of posterior 2/3rd of vocal cords)
  • Kashima’s operation (cordectomy + arytenoidectomy)

 

Type 3 Thyroplasty (Shortening of vocal cords)
  • This procedure is generally done to lower the vocal pitch by creating a window in the thyroid cartilage and thus shortening the vocal cords.
  • Generally done in cases of Puberphonia and in sex–change operation (female to male).

Type 4 Thyroplasty (lengthening of vocal cords)
  • This procedure is done to elevated the vocal pitch.
  • Generally done in cases of androphonia and in sex – change operation.
  • This consists of lengthening the thyroid cartilage which includes cricothyroid approximation

questions.text:
Which one of the below-mentioned structures does not pierce the marked structure?

\

choices.text: Coccygeal branch of the inferior gluteal artery

questions.solution:
Option C: Posterior femoral cutaneous nerve

  • The structure marked in the diagram above is a sacrotuberous ligament, which attaches the pelvis to the vertebral column.
  • The following diagram labels all the structures of the diagram provided in the question:

  • The sacrotuberous ligament extends from the ilium, sacrum, and coccyx to the ischial tuberosity.
  • The posterior femoral cutaneous nerve does not pierce the sacrotuberous ligament. It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen to enter the gluteal region without piercing the sacrotuberous ligament.
  • The sacrotuberous ligament is pierced by coccygeal branches of the inferior gluteal artery, the perforating cutaneous nerve, and branches of the coccygeal plexus.

Option A: Coccygeal branch of the inferior gluteal artery

  • The inferior gluteal artery arises from the internal iliac artery. It gives off a coccygeal branch that pierces the sacrotuberous ligament.

Option B: Perforating cutaneous nerve 

  • The perforating cutaneous nerve (S2, S3) pierces the sacrotuberous ligament and extends to supply the area of the skin over the gluteus maximus.

Option D: Branches of coccygeal plexus

  • It formed by the S4, S5, and coccygeal root.
  • The anococcygeal nerve arises from the coccygeal plexus and pierces the sacrotuberous ligament to innervate the anal region.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with a noticeable depression on the dorsum of their nose as shown below. The patient had a history of tuberculosis 2 years ago. What is the most appropriate management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Augmentation rhinoplasty:

  • The given clinical findings are consistent with a diagnosis of saddle nose deformity.

Saddle Nose Deformity

  • Depression on the dorsum of the nose is called saddle nose deformity.
  • Causes:
    • Traumatic causes:
      • Direct trauma
      • Septal surgeries like submucosal resection surgery (iatrogenic)
  • Non-traumatic causes:
      • Granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis, leprosy, and syphilis will affect the cartilage of the nose
      • Septal abscesses
      • Septal hematoma
  • Symptoms: Cosmetic concerns
  • Treatment:
    • Augmentation rhinoplasty is performed to fix the deformity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Reduction rhinoplasty: It is used in the management of hump nose deformity.

Option B - Septorhinoplasty: It is used in the management of crooked nose and deviated nose.

 

Option D - Moh's micrographic technique: It is used in the management of basal cell carcinoma of skin of external nose.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset severe headache, nausea, and vomiting. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the head reveals evidence of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). Which of the following is not useful in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Steroids:

  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is a medical emergency characterized by bleeding into the subarachnoid space surrounding the brain.
  • Steroids, such as dexamethasone, are not recommended in the treatment of SAH because they do not provide significant benefits and may potentially increase the risk of complications.

Incorrect Options:

Options - B, C, D:

  • Labetalol: Labetalol is a beta-blocker that is commonly used to manage hypertension, which frequently occurs in patients with SAH. It helps to control blood pressure and reduce the risk of rebleeding and complications.
  • Nimodipine: Nimodipine is a calcium channel blocker that is specifically indicated for the prevention and treatment of cerebral vasospasm, a potentially serious complication of SAH. By blocking calcium channels in cerebral blood vessels, nimodipine helps to prevent vasospasm and improve cerebral perfusion.
  • Aneurysmal clip: Surgical clipping of the ruptured aneurysm is a crucial intervention in the management of SAH. Aneurysmal clipping involves placing a metallic clip across the neck of the aneurysm to prevent further bleeding and reduce the risk of rebleeding.

questions.text: A patient presents with a unilateral throbbing headache, photophobia, and excessive lacrimation. He also complains of hemifacial pain on the clenching of teeth. On examination, pupillary reaction, light reflex, and accommodation reflex are normal. Which of the following marked nerves is involved in the above scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 3

  • 3 is the right choice since the side effects depicted involve the Trigeminal nerve ophthalmic division (V1), which supplies sensation to the forehead, scalp, and eye. 

Cluster headaches are known for one-sided pain around the eye or temple, followed by autonomic symptoms like lacrimation, nasal blockage, and ptosis. Hemifacial pain triggered by teeth clenching is also common in trigeminal neuralgia, affecting any of its divisions but usually the maxillary or mandibular.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Is an incorrect choice since the ophthalmic nerve (V1) is a branch of the trigeminal nerve (V), not the first cranial nerve (I), which is the olfactory nerve.

Option B - Is an incorrect choice since the optic nerve (II) is capable of visual work, not the symptoms described within the scenario.

Option D - Is an incorrect choice since the facial nerve (VII) supplies the muscles of facial expression and the lacrimal and salivary glands but isn't included in the sensory symptoms portrayed within the scenario.

questions.text: All of the following conditions show restricted diffusion on diffusion weighted imaging except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Arachnoid cyst:

  • Arachnoid cysts contain cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), which can move freely, and as a result, there is no restriction of diffusion. 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Medulloblastoma: Medulloblastomas are hypercellular tumors that often show restricted diffusion on DWI. The hypercellularity restricts the movement of water protons, resulting in bright signals on DWI.

Option B - Epidermoid cyst: Epidermoid cysts, which contain keratin-like material, can show restricted diffusion on DWI. The restricted diffusion is due to the hindered movement of protons within the cyst.

Option D - Brain abscess: Brain abscesses often show restricted diffusion on DWI. The presence of thick pus in the center of the abscess restricts the motion of protons, leading to bright signals on DWI.

questions.text: A 7-month-old child was brought by her mother with complaints of diarrhoea and mucocutaneous lesions, as shown in the image. The symptoms have been present since weaning was started. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option B: Acrodermatitis enteropathica:

  • The patient's presentation with diarrhoea and mucocutaneous lesions, which started since weaning, is suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica.
  • Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by impaired zinc absorption, leading to zinc deficiency.
  • It typically manifests when breast milk or formula is replaced with a zinc-deficient diet, such as solid foods.
  • The condition is characterized by diarrhea, mucocutaneous lesions, and a failure to thrive.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is a primary immunodeficiency disorder characterized by recurrent infections, eczema, thrombocytopenia, and a small platelet size.

Option C: Pediatric epidermolysis bullosa: Pediatric epidermolysis bullosa is a group of inherited disorders characterized by fragile skin and mucous membranes, leading to blistering and erosions with minimal trauma.

Option D: Atopic dermatitis:

  • Atopic dermatitis is a chronic, inflammatory skin condition characterized by dry, itchy skin and a rash.
  • It often starts in infancy or early childhood and can be associated with a personal or family history of allergies.

questions.text: Which of the following structures does not pierce the clavipectoral fascia?
questions.solution:
Option B: Median pectoral nerve

  • The clavipectoral fascia is a layer of collagen fibers that extends from the clavicle downwards towards the pectoralis minor muscle. It splits and envelops the pectoralis minor muscle before continuing inferiorly toward the floor of the axilla.
  • It extends from the clavicle superiorly, costochondral joints medially, and the coracoid process superolaterally.
  • It is divided into several segments: 
    • Costocoracoid membrane: The most superficial part attached to the coracoid process blends with the upper two external intercostal membranes. It encloses the subclavius muscle.
    • Costocoracoid ligament: Between the coracoid process and the first costochondral joint.
    • It continues downward to enclose the pectoralis minor muscle
    • Suspensory ligament of the axilla: Attached to the axillary fascia.
  • Inferior to the costocoracoid ligament is an opening through which two structures enter, and two structures leave the deep compartment of the pectoral girdle
  • The structures entering include: 
    • The cephalic vein
    • The lymphatic vessels from the infraclavicular lymph nodes
  • The structures leaving include: 
    • Lateral pectoral nerve
    • The Thoracoacromial artery

The median pectoral nerve does not pierce the clavipectoral fascia.

Option A: Cephalic vein

  • The cephalic vein enters from the arm through the opening in the clavipectoral fascia to join the axillary vein.

Option C: Lateral pectoral nerve

  • The lateral pectoral nerve is a branch of the lateral cord of the brachial plexus.
  • It passes through the opening in the clavipectoral fascia to exit the deep compartment of the pectoral girdle to their respective muscles.

Option D: Thoracoacromial vessels

  • Thoracoacromial artery or its branches (acromial, deltoid, pectoral, and clavicular) exit the pectoral girdle from the opening in the clavipectoral fascia.

questions.text: Which of the following X-ray findings is characteristic of an acute retropharyngeal abscess?

choices.text: Prevertebral soft tissue shadow equal to the size of vertebrae

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Presence of air bubbles:

  • The presence of air bubbles in the soft tissues of the neck on X-ray is characteristic of an acute retropharyngeal abscess.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bending of the cervical spine: Acute retropharyngeal abscess causes a straightened spine due to loss of normal cervical spine curvature rather than bending.

Option C - Normal prevertebral soft tissue shadow: In acute retropharyngeal abscess, the prevertebral soft tissue shadow is typically enlarged, not normal.

Option D - Prevertebral soft tissue shadow equal to the size of vertebrae: An enlarged prevertebral soft tissue shadow, particularly greater than twice the size of the adjacent vertebrae, is characteristic of acute retropharyngeal abscess, not a shadow equal in size to the vertebrae.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old male comes to the OPD with swelling and pain in his right knee for several weeks. X-ray reveals the following findings:



A biopsy is performed, and histopathological examination of the specimen shows pseudo-rosettes. The doctor explains the proposed treatment plan comprising chemotherapy, radiotherapy and surgery. Which of the following drugs was mostly recommended by the doctor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Vincristine 

  • Vincristine is a cytotoxic drug belonging to the class of vinca alkaloids and is used in the preferred treatment of Ewing's sarcoma. (Vinca alkaloids destabilize microtubules).

Ewing's sarcoma:

  • It originates from neuroectodermal cells of bone marrow in the diaphyseal region of long bones. It predominantly affects males aged 5-20 years.
  • It is the most common primary malignancy in children under 10 and the second most common primary malignant tumor overall.
  • It is a radio-sensitive tumor, often arising in the upper tibia and lower femur.
  • The X-ray study shows a periosteum arranged characteristically in layers, giving a typical onion-peel appearance.
  • Treatment modalities include chemotherapy with Ifosfamide, Methotrexate, and Vincristine followed by radiotherapy and limb salvage.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vinblastine: Vinblastine is also a vinca alkaloid but not used in treating Ewing's sarcoma.

Option B - Vindesine: Vindesine, also called eldisine, is used in the treatment of malignant melanoma and uterine cancers in combination with other cytotoxic drugs.

Option D - Vinorelbine: Vinorelbine is mostly used with other cytotoxic drugs to treat non-small cell lung cancer.

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with recurrent epigastric pain, foul-smelling, floating diarrhea, weight loss, and positive stool tests for occult blood and fat. Gastrointestinal endoscopy reveals multiple ulcers in the duodenum and jejunum. Which of the following statements is correct regarding Zollinger-Ellison syndrome?

choices.text: The most common site of ulceration is the stomach
Diagnosis is confirmed by pentagastrin test
Fasting gastrin levels >200pg/mL is strongly suggestive of gastrinoma

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Associated with MEN1:

The inherited or familial form of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) is associated with MEN I syndrome.

  • The inactivating mutations of the MEN1 suppressor gene can cause an endocrine tumor syndrome called Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 1. Although it is usually inherited as an autosomal dominant disorder, MEN1 can also occur sporadically (without a family history) due to new mutations.
  • MEN1 is characterized by parathyroid tumors, pancreatic islet cell tumors, and anterior pituitary tumors.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - The most common site of ulceration is the stomach:

  • Proximal duodenum is the most common form of ulcer.

Option C - Diagnosis is confirmed by pentagastrin test:

  • The secretin stimulation test confirms the diagnosis of Zollinger - Ellison syndrome (ZES).

Option D - Fasting gastrin levels >200pg/mL is strongly suggestive of gastrinoma:

  • The fasting serum gastrin test is the best single screening test for ZES.
  • Fasting gastrin levels of more than 1000 pg/ml are strongly suggestive of gastrinoma

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with morbid obesity presents to the hospital for weight loss surgery. Her Body Mass Index (BMI) is 42 kg/m2. She has a history of hypertension and type-2 diabetes mellitus. All her previous attempts to lose weight via dietary modifications, lifestyle changes and exercise have failed. The surgeon discusses the surgical procedure he wants to perform with the patient. A pictorial diagram of the process is shown below. Which of the following is a feature of this procedure?

choices.text: The side effect is 2- 4 malodorous bowel movements per day
No effect on Type 2 diabetes mellitus

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - The side effect is 2- 4 malodorous bowel movements per day:

  • The procedure shown in the picture is biliopancreatic diversion.
  • It is the most effective type of bariatric surgery
  • It is associated with maximum weight loss
  • The main side effect is 2- 4 bowel malodorous movements per day (due to fat malabsorption)
  • Components of this procedure include:
    • Distal gastrectomy
    • Gastro-ileostomy
    • Jejunoileostomy
    • Cholecystectomy
    • Appendectomy
  • Length of the common channel created by this procedure is 50 cm. The food is allowed to mix with the bile and pancreatic enzymes only in the distal 50 cm of the ileum, causing decreased digestion and fat absorption.
  • It is largely malabsorptive and mildly restrictive
  • Maximum remission of type 2 diabetes mellitus occurs with this surgery

Disadvantage

  • There is a high risk of ulcer at the site of anastomosis of gastroileostomy

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Moderate weight loss:

  • Biliopancreatic diversion is considered to have the maximum weight loss in all bariatric surgeries.

Option B - Mildly malabsorptive and largely restrictive:

  • This procedure results in a largely malabsorptive and mildly restrictive state.

Option D - No effect on type-2 diabetes mellitus:

  • In a biliopancreatic diversion, maximum remission is seen for type-2 diabetes mellitus; therefore, patients with type-2 diabetes benefit greatly from this surgery.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Familial Mediterranean Fever is incorrect?

choices.text: It is associated with decreased production of the cytokine IL-1

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - It is associated with decreased production of the cytokine IL-1: 

  • Familial Mediterranean Fever (FMF) is associated with excessive production of the cytokine IL-1 in response to inflammatory stimuli, not decreased production.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Form of hereditary amyloidosis:

  • It is the most common and well-studied form of hereditary amyloidosis
  • Familial Mediterranean fever (FMF) also known as 'periodic peritonitis,' 'familial paroxysmal polyserositis,' 'periodic disease,' 'Siegal-Cattan-Mamou disease,' 'Wolff periodic disease' or 'Reimann syndrome' is an autoinflammatory genetic disorder that causes recurrent fevers and serosal inflammation of the abdomen, lungs, and joints leading to severe pain

Option C - Autosomal recessive:

  • FMF is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by increased cytokine IL-1 production in response to inflammatory stimuli. The pyrin protein is encoded by the FMF gene. This protein plays a crucial role in reducing the innate immune cells' reactivity to inflammatory stimuli, especially neutrophils

Option D - Mutation affecting pyrin protein:

  • FMF is an Autosomal recessive condition and the most common and best-studied form of hereditary amyloidosis. It is an auto-inflammatory diseaseassociated with excessive production of the cytokine IL-1 in response to inflammatory stimuli. The gene for familial Mediterranean fever encodes a protein called pyrin. This protein is important in dampening the response of innate immune cells, particularly neutrophils, to inflammatory mediators.

  • The patient presents with fever accompanied by inflammation of serosal surfaces, including the peritoneum, pleura, and synovial membrane and is sometimes associated with widespread amyloidosis in the body.

  • The amyloid fibril proteins are made up of AA proteins, reflecting the increased production of serum amyloid A (SAA) in response to excessive IL-1 secretion.

questions.text: During a mass casualty incident in a densely populated area, a triage system is implemented to manage the influx of patients effectively. Which among the following is not a feature of blue color coding in the triage system of disaster management?

choices.text: Victims must be helped within 0 to 6 hours
Victims must be helped within 6 to 24 hours
They can wait up to 24 hours

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Victims must be helped within 0 to 6 hours:

  • Blue indicates patients with minor injuries who can wait longer for medical care.
  • Patients in the blue color code:
    • They are of medium priority (option A)
    • Victims must be attended to within 6-24 hours but can wait up to 24 hours. (option C and D)

Option B is, therefore, not a characteristic of the blue color code in triaging.


Incorrect Options: 
Option A - Medium priority: 

Option C - Victims must be helped within 6 TO 24 hours:

Option D - They can wait up to 24 hours

  • These all are correct statements.

questions.text: What is the preferred medication to treat Grave's disease in a woman during her first trimester of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Propylthiouracil:

Antithyroid Drugs

  • Propylthiouracil is the drug of choice during 1st trimester of pregnancy/ breastfeeding as it has high protein binding. On prolonged usage of propylthiouracil, hepatotoxicity can occur.
  • Carbimazole/ Methimazole is the drug of choice in 2nd Trimester. In 1st trimester it can cross the placenta and can cause Aplasia cutis and Choanal atresia.

Incorrect Options:

Options A and B (Carbimazole & Methimazole): These are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

Option D - Radioactive ablation: It is contraindicated in pregnancy or breastfeeding.

questions.text: What medication was most likely prescribed to a 20-year-old male experiencing erectile dysfunction, leading to subsequent symptoms of hypotension and blue-green color blindness?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors:

  • The drug Sildenafil was responsible for patient’s condition.
  • Sildenafil is phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors.
  • Side effects of sildenafil
    • Headache
    • Blue green color blindness
    • Hypotension

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and C:

  • Alprostadil, Pentolamine, Apomorphine are other drugs used in the treatment of erectile dysfunction but they do not cause the given side fefects.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department following a head injury during a car accident. He lost consciousness briefly but has since regained full consciousness. On physical examination, he has a large hematoma on the right side of his head. A CT scan of the head is performed, and the image is shown below.



Based on the CT scan image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Extradural hematoma:

  • The CT scan image shows a characteristic biconvex or lentiform-shaped hematoma that is located between the inner table of the skull and the dura mater. This finding is consistent with an epidural hematoma.

Incorrect choices:

Option A - Subdural hematoma: It presents as sickle/crescent-shaped.

Option C - Subarachnoid hemorrhage: It presents as a star-shaped hemorrhage in sulcal space/cisterns.In SAH, CSF is replaced by blood

Option D - Intraventricular hemorrhage: It presents with blood in the ventricles.

questions.text: Which medication is used to prevent the action of growth hormone at its receptors in the treatment of acromegaly?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pegvisomant:

  • Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to prevent the action of growth hormone at its receptors in the treatment of acromegaly.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Octreotide: Octreotide inhibits growth hormone secretion from the pituitary gland but does not directly block its action at its receptors.

Option C - Somatostatin: Somatostatin and analogs like octreotide reduce growth hormone secretion but do not directly block its action at its receptors.

Option D - Bromocriptine: Bromocriptine inhibits growth hormone secretion but does not directly block its action at its receptors like pegvisomant.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with blurry vision and a flare in the left eye. Upon examination, you noted mild conjunctival injection, anterior chamber cells, and  keratic precipitates. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anterior uveitis:

  • In the given scenario, the patient's symptoms of blurry vision and flare, along with the examination findings of mild conjunctival injection, anterior chamber cells, and keratic precipitates, are indicative of anterior uveitis.
  • Anterior uveitis is characterized by inflammation in the anterior chamber of the eye, involving the iris and ciliary body and on examination keratic precipitates (fine and grey in non-granulomatous uveitis), mutton fat KPs (granulomatous uveitis), aqueous cells, aqueous flare, iris nodules, posterior synechiae and sectoral iris atrophy are observed.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Episcleritis: Episcleritis is an inflammation of the episcleral tissue, which is a thin layer located between the conjunctiva (outermost layer) and the sclera (white of the eye).
