It typically presents with localized redness, discomfort, and occasionally mild irritation. Episcleritis does not usually cause anterior chamber cells and flare, nor does it lead to posterior synechiae.

Option C - Keratitis : Keratitis is inflammation of the cornea, the clear front surface of the eye. While it can cause blurry vision, it is more likely to cause symptoms such as eye pain, photophobia (sensitivity to light), and foreign body sensation. Anterior chamber cells and posterior synechiae are not characteristic features of keratitis.

Option D - Conjunctivitis: Conjunctivitis, also known as pink eye, is inflammation of the conjunctiva, the thin membrane covering the white part of the eye. It typically presents with symptoms of redness, itching, discharge, and mild discomfort. While mild conjunctival injection is mentioned in the scenario, the presence of other findings such as anterior chamber cells, flare, and posterior synechiae suggests involvement beyond the conjunctiva, making conjunctivitis less likely.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female reports experiencing neck pain and stiffness, along with numbness and tingling sensations in her hands. Upon further evaluation, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) reveals the presence of a syrinx, or fluid-filled cavity, within the spinal cord .Which of the following is the treatment of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option A - Surgical decompression:

  • Surgical intervention is often the mainstay of treatment for syringomyelia, especially when associated with Chiari malformation or spinal cord compression. Decompressive surgery aims to relieve pressure on the spinal cord, restore cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow dynamics, and prevent further expansion of the syrinx.
  • Procedures may include posterior fossa decompression for Chiari malformation, laminectomy, syrinx shunting, or syringo-subarachnoid shunt placement.
  • Surgical decompression can help alleviate symptoms, improve neurological function, and halt disease progression in syringomyelia.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, D:

  • These are not the treatment options for Syringomyelia

questions.text: Which of the following tests is considered the most specific for the diagnosis of syphilis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Dark Ground Immunofluorescence (DGI) test:

  • The Dark Ground Immunofluorescence (DGI) test is a specific and sensitive diagnostic test for syphilis. It is a specialized microscopy technique that allows for the direct visualization of live Treponema pallidum, the bacterium responsible for syphilis, under dark-field illumination. This test is highly specific for syphilis and does not produce false-positive results due to cross-reactivity with other conditions. The DGI test is particularly useful in early primary syphilis when other serological tests may not yet be positive. It enables clinicians to observe the motility and morphology of Treponema pallidum, aiding in the definitive diagnosis of syphilis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) test:

  • The VDRL test is a non-specific test used to detect antibodies produced in response to a variety of infections, including syphilis. While it is a commonly used screening test for syphilis, it is not considered the most specific test. The VDRL test can yield false-positive results due to cross-reactivity with other conditions and may require confirmatory testing, such as the FTA-ABS test or Dark Ground Immunofluorescence (DGI) test, to confirm the diagnosis of syphilis.

Option B - RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin) test:

  • Similar to the VDRL test, the RPR test is a non-specific serological test used for screening and diagnosing syphilis. It detects antibodies that may arise due to various infections, not only syphilis. As with the VDRL test, the RPR test can produce false-positive results, necessitating further testing for confirmation.

Option C - FTA-ABS (Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption) test:

  • The FTA-ABS test is indeed a highly specific test for syphilis, but it is not the most specific among the listed options. It detects specific antibodies against Treponema pallidum, and a positive result is indicative of either a current or past infection with syphilis. However, the Dark Ground Immunofluorescence (DGI) test is considered more specific because it allows for direct visualization of live Treponema pallidum, providing a definitive diagnosis in early primary syphilis, when serological tests like FTA-ABS may not yet be positive.

questions.text: What is a characteristic histological feature of Paget's disease seen in biopsy findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Empty cells in the epithelium:

  • In Paget's disease, characteristic histological findings include the presence of "Paget cells," which are large, pale, vacuolated cells found within the epithelium. These cells appear empty or contain clear cytoplasm. They are indicative of Paget’s disease.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not seen in Paget’s disease.

questions.text: A 35-year-old P3 has a Pap smear showing a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion of the cervix (CIN III), followed by an inadequate colposcopy. Cone biopsy shows squamous cell cancer that has invaded only 1 mm beyond the basement membrane. There are no confluent tongues of tumor, and there is no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion. The margins of the cone biopsy specimen are free of disease. What is your Diagnosis?

choices.text: Atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B- Microinvasive cancer:

  • Microinvasive cancer refers to early-stage cervical cancer where the malignant cells have invaded only a minimal depth (1 mm) beyond the basement membrane.
  • Stage IA – Invasive carcinoma that can be diagnosed only by microscopy, with a maximum depth of invasion <5 mm. Stage IA is subdivided into the following categories:
    • IA1 – Measured stromal invasion ≤3 mm in depth
    • IA2 – Measured stromal invasion >3 mm and ≤5 mm in depth
  • In this case, there is invasion, but it is limited.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- CIN III:

  • CIN III represents severe dysplasia or carcinoma in situ of the cervix. The full thickness of the cervical surface layer is affected by abnormal cells without basement membrane penetration.
  • It is a precancerous condition but not an invasive cancer.

Option C- Atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance:

  • ASC-US is a cytological finding in Pap smears indicating uncertain significance and may warrant further evaluation.

Option D- Carcinoma in situ:

  • Carcinoma in situ refers to cancer cells that are confined to the epithelium and have not invaded the underlying tissues.

questions.text: A 35 year old man's body has been brought for examination. His company was showing undue interest in the autopsy report as the man was a victim of an occupational injury. Among the findings, the forensic doctor has described in detail the Joule burn the victim had suffered. From this finding, what can be deciphered as the cause of death of the victim?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Electrocution:

  • Joule Burns are specific and diagnostic of contact with electricity.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Blast injuries:

  • The most common urgent clinical problem in survivors is usually the penetrating injury caused by blast-energized debris, and fragments from the casing of the exploding device.
  • Many of those exposed will have a blunt, blast and thermal injuries, in addition to more obvious penetrating wounds (referred to as combined injury).
  • The soft-tissue wounds are heavily contaminated with dirt, clothing and secondary missiles, such as wood, masonry and other materials from the environment (flying missiles).
  • Blast injuries are divided into four categories: primary, secondary, tertiary and quaternary.

Option C - Firearm wounds:

  • Gunshot wounds are either penetrating or perforating.
  • Penetrating wounds: The bullet enters an object and does not exit.
  • Perforating wounds: The bullet passes completely through an object.

Option D - Lightning stroke:

  • A flash or bolt of lightning is due to an electrical discharge from a cloud to the earth.
  • It may injure or kill an individual by a direct strike, a side flash or conduction through another object.
  • Death is caused by the high-voltage direct current due to cardiopulmonary arrest or electrothermal injuries.
  • Lichtenberg flowers are pathognomonic of a lightning strike but are rare.
  • It is known by different names like ‘arborization’, ‘feathering’, ‘ferning’, ‘filigree burns’ or ‘keraunographic markings’.

questions.text: Which tumor marker is most likely to turn positive in a 32-year-old male with a radiosensitive tumor spreading via lymphatics to the para-aortic lymph nodes, and the given gross specimen and histology findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - PLAP (Placental Alkaline Phosphatase):

  • The characteristics mentioned in the question, including the patient's age falls within the 2nd and 3rd decades, a radiosensitive tumor, and lymphatic spread to the para-aortic group of lymph nodes, are indicative of a seminomatous testicular tumor
  • The given histology shows “Fried egg appearance” which is a characteristic of Seminomas.
  • Seminoma, a type of testicular germ cell tumor, is known to produce certain tumor markers. One of these markers is PLAP (Placental Alkaline Phosphatase). Therefore, in the case of a painless, slowly progressive testicular mass, particularly if it is identified as a seminoma on HPE, PLAP is most likely to be elevated as a tumor marker.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - AFP (Alpha-Fetoprotein):

  • AFP is a tumor marker associated with non-seminomatous germ cell tumors, particularly yolk sac tumors. In seminomas, AFP is typically not elevated.

Option B - hCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin):

  • hCG is another tumor marker associated with non-seminomatous germ cell tumors, especially choriocarcinoma. In pure seminomas, hCG is generally not elevated.

Option C - CA125:

  • CA125 is not a specific marker for testicular tumors. It is more commonly associated with ovarian cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition given in the image:

choices.text: It is associated with traction bronchiectasis
It is predominant in the central part of the lung.
It is seen due to irreversible fibrosis

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - It is predominant in the central part of the lung:

  • The honeycomb pattern observed in imaging, particularly in conditions like Usual Interstitial Pneumonia (UIP) or Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF), refers to a distinctive appearance characterized by clustered, small cystic airspaces resembling honeycomb cells. These cystic spaces are surrounded by thickened walls of fibrotic tissue. The honeycomb pattern indicates advanced lung fibrotic changes, suggesting irreversible scarring and loss of normal lung architecture. The honeycombing pattern is predominantly seen in the peripheral part of the lung.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It consists of air-filled cysts:

  • The honeycomb pattern appears due to the air-filled cysts laid one above the other with a septum in between.

Option B - It is associated with traction bronchiectasis:

  • Fibrosis causes traction bronchiectasis.

Option D - It is seen due to irreversible fibrosis:

  • The honeycombpattern occurs due to irreversible fibrosis leading to traction bronchiectasis.

questions.text: Which anatomical space is commonly associated with cholesteatoma?

choices.text: Space involving the pars flaccida and the neck of the malleus
Space next to the tensor tympani muscle

questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Space involving the pars flaccida and the neck of the malleus:

  • Cholesteatoma commonly involves the space involving the pars flaccida and the neck of the malleus. This space is known as Prussak’s space and is susceptible to cholesteatoma formation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B- Space between ponticulus and subiculum: This space is known as sinus tympani. It is the most common site for recurrence of cholesteatoma.

Option C- Space around the facial recess: Cholesteatoma is not commonly associated with the space around facial recess.

Option D- Space next to the tensor tympani muscle: Cholesteatoma does not typically involve the space within the tensor tympani muscle.

questions.text: An elderly patient is screened for tuberculosis with a tuberculin test. Which of the following is true regarding this test?

choices.text: Indicates the cell-mediated immunity against the bacteria
Detects the presence of tuberculosis bacteria in the bloodstream.
Can distinguish between infection and vaccination
May be falsely positive in immunosuppression

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Indicates the cell-mediated immunity against the bacteria:

  • The purified protein derivative (PPD) test reveals whether or not someone has established an immune response to the tuberculosis-causing bacteria.
  • The Mantoux test is done by injecting 0.1 mL of liquid containing 5 tuberculin units of PPD (purified protein derivative) intradermally.
  • It is read 48-72 hours apart
  • The basis of the reading of the skin test is the presence or absence and the amount of the induration ( i.e. localized hardening).
  • A negative (no swelling) test does not always mean that a person is free of tuberculosis. A person who has received a bacillus Calmette Guerin (BCG) vaccine against tuberculosis may also have a positive skin reaction to the TB test (false positive).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Detects the presence of tuberculosis bacteria in the bloodstream: Involves injecting a purified protein derivative (PPD) of the tuberculosis bacterium into the skin and then observing the immune response at the injection site. It does not directly detect the presence of tuberculosis bacteria in the bloodstream but rather assesses the individual's immune response to the bacteria..

Option C - Can distinguish between infection and vaccination: A positive tuberculin skin test result signifies cell-mediated hypersensitivity to tubercular antigens but does not differentiate between infection and vaccination

Option D - Maybe a false positive in immunosuppression:  False-negative reactions (or skin test anergy) may be produced by certain viral infections, sarcoidosis, malnutrition, Hodgkin lymphoma, immunosuppression, and overwhelming active tuberculous disease.

questions.text:
Match the following


	
		
			
			Grading
			
			
			AFI
			
		
		
			
			a. Mild polyhydraminos
			
			
			1)32 cm
			
		
		
			
			b. Severe polyhydraminos
			
			
			2)27 cm
			
		
		
			
			c. Moderate polyhydraminos
			
			
			3)37 cm
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - A-2,b-3,c-1:

  • Mild polyhydramnios have an AFI in the range of 20-25 cm
  • Moderate polyhydramnios have an AFI in the range of 30-35 cm
  • Severe polyhydramnios have an AFI in the range of > 35 cm

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D:

  • These do not indicate the correct match between the grading of Polyhydraminos and AFI

questions.text: A 30-years-old primigravida with diabetes mellitus at 30 weeks gestation is admitted to the ICU with multiorgan dysfunction. She is oriented in time and place. She has had mild lower abdominal pain for the last few days and reports no trauma history. Her lab parameters suggest thrombocytopenia, decreased fibrinogen, and an INR of 2.1. Her blood sugar level is 180mg/dL. Which of the following is a common underlying cause of such presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Abruptio placenta

  • Abruptio placenta is the most common cause of consumptive coagulopathy in obstetrics due to the associated bleeding and activation of the clotting system.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Gestational diabetes

  • Gestational diabetes is diagnosed in pregnant patients after 20 weeks of gestation.
  • Such patients have underlying risk factors, such as obesity and prior gestational diabetes.
  • Patients who have been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus before pregnancy cannot be diagnosed with gestational diabetes.
  • DIC is not caused by GDM, however, chances of DIC are higher in overt diabetics

Option C: Placenta previa

  • Placenta previa is the attachment of the placenta at or near the internal cervical opening instead of its normal attachment site.
  • It causes visible external bleeding.
  • Placenta previa does not cause DIC unless associated with massive hemorrhage​​​

Option D: Rupture of the uterus

  • The uterus rupture is an obstetrics emergency that leads to the rapid demise of the fetus and/or mother.
  • Emergency C-section with the repair of the uterus is indicated.
  • Uterine rupture would cause DIC only if associated with massive hemorrhage

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the pharmacokinetic property exhibited by thiopentone, contributing to its rapid onset and short duration of action during anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Redistribution:
 

  • Thiopentone exhibits redistribution, which contributes to its rapid onset and short duration of action during anesthesia. Redistribution refers to the process where a drug initially distributes into highly perfused tissues, such as the brain, leading to a quick onset of action. However, it then redistributes from these tissues into less perfused tissues, particularly fat stores, causing a decrease in plasma concentration and termination of its action on the brain. This phenomenon results in the short duration of action of thiopentone.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Zero-order kinetics:

  • Describes constant drug elimination rate regardless of concentration.
  • Thiopentone doesn't follow zero-order kinetics; it's eliminated via first-order kinetics.

Option B - First-pass metabolism:

  • Metabolism by the liver before systemic circulation, typically via portal vein.
  • Thiopentone is eliminated primarily via redistribution, not first-pass metabolism.

Option D - Renal clearance:

  • Involves drug elimination through kidneys.
  • Thiopentone is primarily eliminated via redistribution into fat tissues, not renal clearance.

questions.text: NIKSHAY is an online software for reporting and compliance with treatment. In an area endemic to tuberculosis, this software is being utilized along with other control measures. Several ASHA workers are newly recruited and provided with appropriate training. Among the following options, which one is not part of active case detection of TB?

choices.text: ASHA workers receive an incentive of Rs.100 for notification if the suspect referred is diagnosed to be TB patient by MO
Any community member helping identify presumptive TB cases gets an incentive of Rs. 500
Dwellers, prisoners, difficult-to-reach populations, occupational exposure-silicosis, migrants, tribals, shelter homes, and PLHIV are the vulnerable groups
ASHA workers get Rs. 10 per form filled

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - ASHA workers get Rs.10 per form filled:

  • While ASHA workers are crucial in active case detection, the incentive structure mentioned in this option does not directly contribute to identifying presumptive TB cases.
  • Instead, it focuses on providing an incentive for filling out forms.
  • While documentation is essential for monitoring and reporting purposes, the primary objective of active case detection is to identify potential TB cases in the community.
  • Therefore, this option is not a part of active case detection of TB.
  • It is a part of community-based screening of tuberculosis.

Nikshay

  • It is an online software, for reporting & compliance with treatment.
  • HMIS (Health Management Information System) for TB patients.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - ASHA workers receive an incentive of Rs.100 for notification if the suspect referred is diagnosed to be TB patient by MO

  • ASHA workers play a crucial role in active case detection of TB.
  • They are incentivized to find presumptive cases to encourage their active participation in the program.
  • Offering an incentive of Rs. 100 motivates them to search for potential TB cases in the community actively.
  • Therefore, this option is a part of active case detection of TB.

Option B - Any community member helping identify presumptive TB cases gets an incentive of Rs. 500:

  • Engaging the entire community in identifying presumptive TB cases is an effective strategy to increase case detection.
  • Offering an incentive of Rs. 500 to any community member who helps in identifying presumptive TB cases promotes community involvement and aids in early detection.
  • Hence, this option is also a part of active case detection of TB.

Option C - Dwellers, prisoners, difficult-to-reach populations, occupational exposure-silicosis, migrants, tribals, shelter homes, and PLHIV are the vulnerable groups:

  • This option lists various vulnerable groups and populations who are at higher risk of TB infection or have difficulty accessing healthcare services.
  • Active case detection programs often prioritize these groups for targeted screening and case-finding efforts.
  • Including these groups in the active case detection strategy aligns with the goal of reaching all potentially affected populations, thus making this option a part of active case detection of TB.

questions.text: Which of the following anatomical facts is true about the stomach?

choices.text: Lymph from the superior two third of the stomach drains into the supra-pancreatic nodes.
All lymphatic drainage from the stomach drains through the celiac nodes.
The gastric branches of the vagus are given at the greater curve.
The lower esophageal sphincter is supplied by the nerves of Latarjet.

questions.solution:
Option B: All lymphatic drainage from the stomach drains through the celiac nodes.

  • All the lymph from the stomach eventually drains into the celiac nodes and then into the cisterna chyli.
  • The lymph from the stomach drains into the right and left gastric nodes on the right side, pancreaticosplenic nodes and supra-pancreatic nodes on the left side, and the inferior portion drains into the pyloric nodes.
  •  

Option A: Lymph from the superior two-thirds of the stomach drains into the supra pancreatic nodes

  • Lymph from the superior portion of the left side drains into the inferior pancreaticoduodenal and supra pancreatic lymph nodes.

Option C: The gastric branches of the vagus are given at the greater curve.

  • Gastric branches of the vagus are given at lesser curvature.

Option D: The lower esophageal sphincter is supplied by the nerves of Latarjet

  • Nerves of Latarjet supply the pylorus and pyloric sphincter.

questions.text: Following are the true statements about Itraconazole except:

choices.text: Itraconazole is the drug of choice for maintenance therapy in penicilliosis

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Causes Hypertension Leading to CHF

Explanation:

Itraconazole can reduce cardiac contractility and precipitate or worsen heart failure in predisposed patients. However, hypertension leading to CHF is not a recognized mechanism. Thus, the statement that itraconazole causes hypertension leading to CHF is inaccurate.

 

Itraconazole:

  • Triazole antifungal is used to treat various fungal infections, including penicilliosis, blastomycosis, histoplasmosis, sporotrichosis, and eumycetoma.
  • It inhibits fungal cytochrome P450-dependent 14α-demethylase, disrupting ergosterol synthesis in fungal cell membranes.
  • Role in Specific Fungal Infections:
    • Penicilliosis, Blastomycosis, Histoplasmosis, Sporotrichosis:
      • Amphotericin B is the drug of choice for induction therapy in severe cases due to its potent antifungal activity for these systemic fungal infections.
      • Itraconazole is used for maintenance therapy or treatment of mild-to-moderate cases, as per CDC and WHO guidelines for opportunistic infections (e.g., in HIV/AIDS for penicilliosis) and IDSA guidelines for endemic mycoses. (Option D)
    • Eumycetoma: Itraconazole is the first-line treatment for eumycetoma (fungal mycetoma, e.g., caused by Madurella mycetomatis), often requiring prolonged therapy (6–12 months or longer), sometimes with surgical debridement, as per WHO guidelines. (Option B)
  • Side Effects of Itraconazole:
    • Hepatotoxicity (Option A)
    • GI Disturbances: Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal discomfort are common side effects.
    • Heart Failure
    • Hypertension and Hypokalemia

questions.text: All of the following are findings of Bergers IgA nephropathy except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 3 weeks history of sore throat:

It is seen in PSGN

  • Bergers IgA nephropathy has short History of 48 hrs after URTI

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and C are features of Bergers nephropathy(IgA nephropathy)

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents to the emergency at 29 weeks of gestation with headache, double vision, and jaundice. Her BP is 190/110 mmHg. Urinalysis reveals urine albumin 3+. Blood investigations reveal Hb=7gm%, platelet count=70,000, TLC=13,000, SGOT=230, bilirubin=2 mg/dL and INR=2. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: HELLP syndrome

  • This patient with high BP, headache, proteinuria, jaundice, low Hb, and low platelets likely suffers from HELLP syndrome secondary to preeclampsia.
  • It is a complication of severe preeclampsia.
  • It presents with hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelets.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Acute Cholecystitis

  • It presents with right upper quadrant pain radiating to the shoulder and fever, secondary to cholelithiasis.
  • High BP, proteinuria, and visual disturbances are not present in this condition.

Option C: Hepatic rupture

  • It is a life-threatening event, usually due to abdominal trauma.
  • There is severe abdominal bleeding and deranged LFTs.

Option D: IHCP

  • Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy presents in the 3rd trimester with itching and raised ALP.
  • Hemolysis and thrombocytopenia are not present in this condition.

questions.text: A patient came to the hospital with a complaint of abdominal pain. Routine investigations were unremarkable. On observation, the urine turned black on standing. Which of the following enzymes is likely to be defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Homogentisate oxidase

  • The patient's black urine suggests the presence of a condition called alkaptonuria.
  • Alkaptonuria is a rare inherited disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate oxidase. This enzyme is responsible for the breakdown of homogentisic acid, a product of the metabolism of the amino acids phenylalanine and tyrosine.
  • When homogentisate oxidase is deficient, homogentisic acid accumulates in the body and is excreted in the urine, leading to the characteristic dark or black urine on standing.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Xanthine oxidase: Xanthine oxidase deficiency is associated with a condition called xanthinuria, which results in the accumulation of xanthine and hypoxanthine.

Option C - Phenylalanine hydroxylase: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency is seen in a condition called phenylketonuria (PKU). PKU is characterized by the inability to metabolize phenylalanine properly, leading to its accumulation in the body.

Option D - Dihydric orotate dehydrogenase: There is no known enzyme called dihydric orotate dehydrogenase. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Identify the given instrument and specify it’s use:

choices.text: Asch forceps, For correction of nasal bone
Walsham forceps, For correction of nasal bone
Asch forceps, For correction of nasal septum
Walsham forceps, For correction of nasal septum

questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Walsham forceps, For correction of nasal bone:

  • The image shows Walsham forceps. Their blades are not elevated. Walsham's forceps have a rubber guard on one of the ends to prevent any orbital trauma, as only one end goes inside the nose. Walsham forceps are used to correct the nasal bone during the management of fracture of the nasal septum.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Asch forceps, for correction of nasal bone: The tip of the Asch forceps is elevated, not straight. They are used to correct the nasal septum, not the nasal bone.

Option C- Asch forceps, for correction of nasal septum: The tip of the Asch forceps is elevated, not straight. They are used to correct the nasal septum.

Option D- Walsham forceps, for correction of nasal septum: Walsham forceps are primarily used to correct the nasal bone, not the nasal septum.

questions.text: Identify the fungus shown in the image given below which is stained by India ink dye.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cryptococcus:

  • Cryptococcus is a genus of fungi that includes pathogenic species, most notably Cryptococcus neoformans and Cryptococcus gattii. These fungi are encapsulated yeast-like organisms and can cause serious infections, particularly in individuals with weakened immune systems.
  • India ink staining is a diagnostic technique used to visualize Cryptococcus species in clinical samples, such as cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). The ink particles do not penetrate the capsule surrounding the Cryptococcus cells, resulting in a clear halo around the unstained organisms against the dark background. This "halo effect" is a characteristic feature observed in India ink preparations for Cryptococcus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aspergillus: These are filamentous fungi characterized by their acute dichotomous branching, septate hyphae, and conidial structures. Specific staining techniques such as lactophenol cotton blue or potassium hydroxide (KOH) mounts are commonly employed to examine their hyphal structures and conidia.

Option B - Penicillium: These are dimorphic fungi characterized by brush/broom conidial structures. Specific staining techniques such as lactophenol cotton blue or potassium hydroxide (KOH) mounts are commonly employed to examine their hyphal structures and conidia.

Option D - Candida: Candida is a yeast-like fungus that forms budding cells rather than hyphae. Instead, techniques such as Gram staining, wet mounts with KOH, or specialized fungal stains like methylene blue or calcofluor white are commonly used to visualize Candida cells.

questions.text: For which procedure is the No. 11 blade primarily used?

choices.text: Minor surgical procedure, plastic & pediatric surgery

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Arteriotomy: 

  • The No. 11 blade is primarily used for arteriotomy procedures.
  • Arteriotomy involves making an incision into an artery, typically for procedures such as vascular surgeries or accessing blood vessels for various medical interventions.
  • The No. 11 blade's fine, pointed tip and sharp edge make it suitable for precise incisions required in arteriotomy procedures.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Open skin/skin incision: This procedure is typically performed using a No. 10 blade, which is specifically designed for making open skin incisions. The No. 10 blade has a larger, more rounded blade compared to the No. 11 blade.

Option C - Minor surgical procedure, plastic & pediatric surgery: The No. 15 blade is commonly used for minor surgical procedures, plastic surgery, and pediatric surgery. It has a smaller, more delicate blade compared to the No. 11 blade, making it suitable for intricate procedures on delicate tissues.

Option D - Abdominal incision: Abdominal incisions are typically made using larger blades such as the No. 22 blade, which is specifically designed for this purpose. The No. 22 blade has a larger size and stronger construction compared to the No. 11 blade, making it more suitable for cutting through thicker tissues encountered in abdominal surgeries.

questions.text: In a 19-year-old woman presenting at 6 weeks of pregnancy and expressing a desire for Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP), which procedure is most appropriate for her case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • This combination is a commonly used and effective medical abortion method. Mifepristone is an anti-progestin that blocks the hormone necessary for maintaining pregnancy. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin, is usually administered a day or two later to induce uterine contractions and expel the pregnancy. This regimen is suitable for early pregnancies, typically up to 7 weeks gestation.

First Trimester Abortion:

  • Methods vary between the first trimester (up to 12 weeks) and the second trimester (12-24 weeks), with viability defined at 28 weeks.
  • Medical Abortion:
    • Success rates: 99% within the first seven weeks, up to 95% within nine weeks.
    • Drugs used:
      • Oral Mifepristone (200-600 mg): An antiprogestin that withdraws pregnancy support.
      • Vaginal Misoprostol (800 μg): Administered 24-48 hours after Mifepristone, it induces uterine contractions.
    • Pre-requisites: Ultrasound to locate fetus and rule out ectopic, counseling on drugs and bleeding, repeat ultrasound for completion.
  • Surgical Abortion:
    • Suction Evacuation: Electrical vacuum aspirator attached to a Karman's cannula used for suctioning products of conception, feasible up to 8-10 weeks of last menstrual period.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Dilation and curettage

  • This can be done but since curettage is involved, there is an inherent risk of Asherman's syndrome. Hence, avoiding such early gestation

Option B: Suction and evacuation

  • Suction and evacuation, also referred to as vacuum aspiration, is a frequently employed surgical abortion method that utilizes suction to extract the uterine contents, including the pregnancy. This method is most suitable for pregnancies within the gestational age range of 7 to 12 weeks.

Option D: Dinoprostone

  • Dinoprostone is a prostaglandin (PG E2) that can soften and dilate the cervix. It is sometimes used with other methods, such as suction and evacuation, to facilitate the procedure. However, it is typically used in 2nd trimester abortions.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the poisoning caused by the seeds shown below?

choices.text: Uncrushed seeds will not lead to poisoning
Inhibits neurotransmitter glycine effect at the pre-synaptic receptor

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Toxin potentiates neurotransmitter glycine effect at pre-synaptic receptor:

  • The above given image is of Strychnine Seeds aka Dog Buttons
  • It is used to kill stray dogs, hence called Dog-buttons.
    • Seeds shape is concavo-convex.
    • It is odorless and bitter in taste.
    • Fatal dose: One crushed seed
  • Toxin potentiates neurotransmitter glycine which does not effect the pre synaptic receptor.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pleurosthotonus:

  • Pleurosthotonus: Lateral flexion of the spine, which is a feature of Strychnine poisoning.

Option B - Post mortem caloricity:

  • After death ‘Postmortem caloricity’ phenomenon occurs i.e., initially after death, the patient remains warm for few hours.

Option C - Uncrushed seeds will not lead to poisoning:

  • Unbroken seeds when ingested are not poisonous, as the hard pericarp is not soluble in digestive juices.

questions.text: At which vertebral level does the hemiazygos vein cross from left to right?
questions.solution:
Option B: T8

  • The hemiazygos vein is, also known as the inferior azygos vein, formed in the upper abdomen by the union of:
    • Left ascending lumbar vein
    • Left subcostal vein
  • It runs superiorly, passing through the left crus of the diaphragm to enter the thoracic cavity. It courses upwards in the posterior mediastinum along the left side of the vertebra. It then courses to the right, crossing the aorta, oesophagus and thoracic duct posteriorly, to enter the azygos vein at the level of the T8 vertebra.

Option A: T7

  • T7 corresponds to the inferior angle of the scapula in our body.

Option C: T10

  • At the level of T10, an esophagal opening in the diaphragm is present.

Option D: T12

  • The level of T12 represents the aortic opening in the diaphragm is present.

questions.text: A 4-hour-old boy is brought to the emergency department with complaints of difficulty in feeding and cough. He was born full term at home via normal vaginal delivery to a 25-year-old primigravida, who did not seek prenatal care. When his mother tried to breastfeed him, he coughed and vomited. Subsequent attempts at feeding failed. On examination, his temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), blood pressure is 88/70 mmHg, heart rate is 116/min, and respiratory rate is 30/min. His weight and height are at the 25th and 50th percentile, respectively. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Chest examination reveals coarse breath sounds bilaterally along with intercostal retractions. Neurologic examination is insignificant. What is the best initial investigation for this patient?

choices.text: Bronchoscopy with an injection of methylene blue
NG tube insertion and CXR to check the position of the tube

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - NG tube insertion and CXR to check the position of the tube:

  • This patient's presentation, including difficulty feeding and cough, coarse breath sounds bilaterally along with intercostal retractions on chest examination, coughing fit along with vomiting on feeding attempt, is suggestive of esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula.

Esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula:

  • Defective division of the foregut into the esophagus and trachea resulting in a proximal esophageal blind pouch and a fistula between the distal esophagus and trachea.
  • Clinical features: The initial signs of esophageal atresia are usually seen soon after birth : :
    • frothy white bubbles in the baby's mouth
    • coughing or choking when feeding
    • cyanosis, especially when baby is feeding
    • difficulty breathing
  • EA and TEF are also often found in babies born with VACTERL (vertebral defects, anal atresia, cardiac defects, trachea-oesophagal fistula, renal anomalies and limb abnormalities) syndrome. Not all babies born with VACTERL syndrome have abnormalities in all of these areas.
  • Diagnosis:
    • The initial investigation includes the inability to pass the nasogastric (NG) tube into the stomach. It is later confirmed by an x-ray, which shows an NG tube coiled in the proximal esophagus. The inability to pass an NG into the stomach is a cardinal feature for the diagnosis of esophageal atresia
    • If gas is present in the GIT below the diaphragm, an associated tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) is confirmed
    • Inability to pass an NG tube with absent radiographic evidence for gastrointestinal gas is virtually diagnostic of an isolated EA without TEF
    • For H-type: Tracheobronchoscopy + Endoscopy should be performed
  • Management: Surgical correction

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bronchoscopy with an injection of methylene blue:

  • It is used to diagnose bronchopleural fistula. A bronchopleural fistula (BPF) is a communication between the pleural space and the bronchial tree. BPF should be suspected in the postoperative lung resection patient who presents with sudden onset of dyspnea, chest pain, hemodynamic instability, and subcutaneous emphysema.

Option C - CT scan of the chest:

  • CT scan of the chest has no role in the diagnosis of EA with TEF.

Option D - Endoscopy:

  • It is used as a subsequent investigation in type E TEF to confirm the diagnosis, not as the first investigation. H

questions.text: What marker indicates the site of Bochdalek hernia?
questions.solution:
Option D: D

  • This is a case of Bochdalek hernia.
  • In Bochdalek hernia, the patient typically presents with shortness of breath and decreased breath sound on auscultation at the affected site.
  • Site for Bochdalek hernia (Left postero-lateral) due to deficiency in the pleuroperitoneal membrane.
  • Bochdalek hernia is a defect in the postero-lateral area of the diaphragm.
  • It results in herniation of abdominal viscera into the thorax.
  • It causes mechanical compression on the lung parenchyma, which is under development.
  • Occasionally, it can also cause hypoplasia of the lungs.
  • These symptoms usually manifest in children and tend to be respiratory.
  • Rarely an adult diagnosed with such symptoms

Option A: A

  • Site for eventration of the diaphragm.

Option B: B

  • Site for Morgagni hernia (Right Antero-medial).

Option C: C

  • Esophageal opening at T10 → this opening can cause sliding hiatus hernia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with advanced corneal disease requires a corneal transplant. Which type of keratoplasty would involve replacing the full thickness of the cornea with a healthy cornea?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Penetrating keratoplasty:

  • Penetrating keratoplasty (PK) involves the replacement of the full thickness of the cornea with a healthy cornea. It is the standard surgical procedure for corneal transplantation. Donor cornea is placed onto the recipient's cornea, and the edges are sutured together.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lamellar keratoplasty: Lamellar keratoplasty involves the replacement of partial thickness of the cornea, while preserving the endothelium. It is of two types : Anterior and Posterior.

  • Anterior lamellar keratoplasty:
    • It is the replacement of the anterior portion of the cornea without disturbing the endothelium, as there is a high chance of endothelium graft rejection.
  • Posterior lamellar/ Deep endothelial lamellar keratoplasty:
    • This type replaces the endothelium with or without a part of the stroma.

Option C - Deep anterior lamellar keratoplasty: Deep anterior lamellar keratoplasty (DALK) is a variation of lamellar keratoplasty that involves the removal of the anterior layers of the cornea, including the diseased or scarred tissue, while preserving the healthy endothelium. It is mainly used in cases where the disease or damage is limited to the front part of the cornea.

Option D - Endothelial keratoplasty: Endothelial keratoplasty, also known as Descemet's stripping automated endothelial keratoplasty (DSAEK) or Descemet's membrane endothelial keratoplasty (DMEK), involves the transplantation of only the endothelial layer of the cornea. It is performed for conditions where the endothelial cells are dysfunctional, such as Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy or corneal endothelial cell loss.

questions.text: All are the objectives of the National Leprosy Eradication Programme, except?

choices.text: Reduce prevalence rate <1/10000 the population at national and district level
Zero stigma and discrimination against people affected by leprosy
Zero disabilities among new child cases

questions.solution:
Correct Pption B - Annual new case rate < 5/lakh:

  • The Annual New Case Detection Rate is the rate at which new cases (never treated before) are detected in a defined geographical area (block, district) in a year (April-March).
  • The National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) is a public health initiative undertaken by the Government of India to control and ultimately eliminate leprosy from the country.
  • The program was launched in 1983 by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.
  • One of the objectives of the NLEP is to achieve an Annual New Case Detection Rate of <10/ lakh population.
  • Therefore, the statement given in option B is incorrect.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Reduce prevalence rate <1/10000 the population at national and district level:

  • This is accurate.
  • This objective aims to decrease the prevalence of leprosy to less than one case per 10,000 population at both the national and district levels.
  • This is a key indicator of the success of the program in controlling the spread of leprosy.

Option C - Zero stigma and discrimination against people affected by leprosy:

  • This is included in the objectives of the NLEP.
  • This objective focuses on addressing social stigma and discrimination associated with leprosy.
  • It aims to create awareness and promote acceptance and inclusion of individuals affected by leprosy in society.

Option D - Zero disabilities among new child cases:

  • Preventing disabilities among new child cases is a desirable goal, and it is a part of the objectives of the NLEP.
  • Efforts are made to diagnose and treat leprosy early to prevent disabilities, especially in children.

questions.text: In a patient with maple syrup urine disease, all of the following amino acids should be restricted in diet, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Methionine:

  • Maple syrup urine disease is a metabolic defect caused by abnormal activity of the branched-chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase (BCKAD) complex. This complex is responsible for the breakdown of branched-chain amino acids leucine, isoleucine, and valine. 
  • Methionine is an essential amino acid required for protein synthesis and other metabolic processes.
  • It is not restricted in the diet of patients with maple syrup urine disease, and it is not one of the branched-chain amino acids affected by MSUD.

Incorrect Options - B, C, and D must be restricted in the diet of patients with maple syrup urine disease, as they are unable to metabolize it properly.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the highest risk of aspiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Bilateral SLN palsy:

  • Bilateral superior laryngeal nerve (SLN) palsy results in abduction of the vocal cords, leading to a high risk of aspiration.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Bilateral RLN palsy: Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve is not associated with an increased risk of aspiration compared to bilateral SLN palsy.

Option C - Bilateral SLN and RLN palsy: Bilateral SLN and RLN palsy have a moderate risk of aspiration.

Option D - Unilateral SLN and RLN palsy: Unilateral SLN and RLN palsy have a mild risk of aspiration.

questions.text: Which tapeworm species is leaf-like, lacks suckers, and has two grooves ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Diphyllobothrium latum:

  • Diphyllobothrium latum is characterized by its leaf-like appearance.
  • It lacks suckers on its scolex.
  • Instead of suckers, it possesses two suctorial grooves, also known as bothria, which are longitudinal channels used for attachment to the host's intestine.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Taenia solium: Taenia solium, also known as the pork tapeworm, has suckers and hooks, which are used for attachment to the host's intestinal wall. It does not have a leaf-like appearance and does not possess two grooves.

Option B- Taenia saginata: Taenia saginata, known as the beef tapeworm, is similar to Taenia solium in that it has suckers but no hooks for attachment to the host's intestinal wall. It does not have the leaf-like characteristics or the presence of two grooves.

Option C- Echinococcus: Echinococcus tapeworms, specifically Echinococcus granulosus and Echinococcus multilocularis, are known for their small size and the formation of cysts in various organs of the host, such as the liver and lungs. It possesses both suckers and hooks. They do not have a leaf-like appearance or two grooves.

questions.text: Which among the following is punishable in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Voyeurism:

  • Voyeurism: Observing people getting undressed/ bathing/ watching intercourse.
  • It is a punishable offense.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tribadism:

  • Tribadism: Female homosexuality by mutual acts of sexual indulgence to achieve sexual gratification.
  • Valid ground for divorce but not punishable in India.

Option B - Consensual sodomy between 2 adults:

  • Sodomy: Anal intercourse between 2 males or a male and a female.
  • With mutual consent, it is not punishable.

Option C - Incest:

  • Sexual intercourse by a man with a woman who is closely related to him by blood or by marriage (prohibited degrees of relationship).
  • It is not a criminal offence.

questions.text: In a patient receiving amphotericin B who develops extreme lethargy, muscle weakness, and an increase in carbon dioxide levels with hyperventilation, and a serum potassium level of 2.3 mEq/L, what is the appropriate correction of potassium to be given to the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 140 mEq of KCl/24hrs:

  • For potassium levels less than 3 mEq/L or in patients unable to take oral supplementation due to ileus or illness, intravenous correction with potassium chloride is indicated.
  • Correction should be done slowly via infusion.
  • To increase potassium levels from 2.3 to 3 mEq/L, approximately 200 mEq of KCl should be supplied slowly via IV. Once levels reach 3 mEq/L, oral supplementation can be considered.
  • Additionally, to maintain a rise of 0.7 mEq/L, approximately 140 mEq of KCl should be administered over a 24-hour period.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • A, B and C are incorrect due to the above given reasons.

questions.text: Which among the following is a method of direct local violence to conduct criminal abortion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cupping:

  • CUPPING: A form of direct local violence, A mug is turned mouth downwards over a lighted wick and placed on the hypogastrium and the mug is pulled, which results in partial separation of the placenta. This is usually practiced in advanced pregnancy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A/ B/ C - Abortion stick/ Electricity/ Syringing:

  • Higginson's syringing (AIR / Soap water in the uterus), rupturing the membrane (pointed object), abortion sticks, dilation of the cervix (slippery elm bark and drugs), Dilatation and Curettage, air insuﬄation.
  • All these are local methods used in criminal abortion.

questions.text:
A newborn infant is brought to the paediatrician for a routine check-up. The parents mention that the baby appears cyanotic, especially during feeding and crying episodes. Physical examination reveals a  murmur and diminished femoral pulses. A chest X-ray is obtained and is given below.



Which of the following congenital heart defects is most likely responsible for the clinical presentation and X-ray findings in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Transposition of great arteries:

The X-ray finding of "egg on side/string" appearance, characterized by an abnormal positioning of the heart within the chest, is indicative of Transposition of the Great Arteries (TGA). TGA is a congenital heart defect where the positions of the pulmonary artery and aorta are switched. This abnormality results in severe cyanosis and diminished peripheral pulses.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Atrial septal defect: Atrial septal defect is characterized by an abnormal opening between the atria. It typically presents with a wide, fixed splitting of the second heart sound (S2). 

Option B - Ventricular septal defect:It presents with a holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border.

Option C - Constrictive pericarditis: Constrictive pericarditis is characterized by fibrous thickening and calcification of the pericardium, leading to impaired diastolic filling of the heart. The classic X-ray finding of "egg in the cup" appearance represents the calcified and shrunken pericardium causing restriction of the cardiac chambers.

questions.text: A 34-year-old primigravida presents to the emergency at 32 weeks of gestation with seizures.She was started on MgSO4 therapy and an emergency LSCS has been planned. Which of the following is not a contraindication to MgSO4 therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D: Impending eclampsia

  • This patient presenting with seizures at 32 weeks of gestation suffers from eclampsia.
  • Both impending and presenting eclampsia are indications of giving MgSO4 therapy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Renal Failure

  • Renal failure is considered a contraindication to magnesium sulfate therapy. The drug is excreted by the kidneys, and in the presence of renal insufficiency or failure, there is a risk of magnesium accumulation, leading to toxicity.
  •  it can be used cautiously with dose adjustment.

Option B: Hypocalcemia

  • It is also a contraindication to MgSO4 therapy as it increases the risk of respiratory paralysis.

Option C: Myasthenia gravis

  • Myasthenia gravis is considered a contraindication to magnesium sulfate therapy. Magnesium sulfate can exacerbate muscle weakness in individuals with myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: In a community with a prevalence of trachoma follicles greater than 10%, which of the following interventions would be the most appropriate according to the SAFE strategy?

choices.text: Follow facial hygiene and environmental cleanliness

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Trichiasis surgery:

  • The SAFE strategy, implemented by the WHO, aims to control trachoma in communities.
  • The criteria for implementing the SAFE strategy depend on the prevalence of trachoma follicles in the community.
  • If the prevalence of trachoma follicles is greater than 10%, follow the SAFE strategy. If it is between 5-10 %, follow only the FE strategy.

questions.text: Which type of crisis in sickle cell anemia can cause auto-splenectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sequestration crisis:

  • A sequestration crisis in sickle cell anemia involves the entrapment of sickle cells within the spleen, leading to splenic damage and multiple splenic infarcts. This condition eventually results in a decrease in spleen size, leading to auto-splenectomy.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D do not lead to auto-splenectomy.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of a neonate who is brought to the hospital with complaints of forceful vomiting that is not accompanied by bile after feeding? The child appears lethargic and dehydrated, and abdominal examination shows visible movements of the stomach. A barium meal was conducted and the provided image is shown below.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis:

  • Infants with CHPS typically present with projectile nonbilious vomiting, which is forceful and occurs shortly after feeding. Lethargy and dehydration may also be present.
  • Abdominal examination often reveals visible gastric peristalsis, known as an "olive" due to the hypertrophied pylorus.
  • The barium meal image may show delayed passage of contrast material through the pylorus or an "string sign," indicating the narrowed pyloric canal.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hirschsprung's disease: Hirschsprung's disease typically presents with symptoms of bowel obstruction such as constipation, distended abdomen, and failure to pass meconium shortly after birth.

Option C - Jejunal atresia: Jejunal atresia commonly presents with symptoms of intestinal obstruction, including bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. Visible gastric peristalsis is not typically seen in jejunal atresia.

Option D - Duodenal atresia: Visible gastric peristalsis may or may not be present. The barium meal image for duodenal atresia typically shows a "double bubble" sign, indicating the dilation of the stomach and proximal duodenum.

questions.text: Alvarado's scoring in appendicitis includes which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Migratory Right Iliac Fossa Pain:

  • Starts near the umbilicus and migrates to the right iliac fossa as appendicitis progresses.
  • Alvarado (MANTRELS) Score: Used to predict acute appendicitis.
  • Components: Includes symptoms like migratory right iliac fossa pain, anorexia, nausea, vomiting; signs like tenderness and rebound tenderness in the right iliac fossa, and elevated temperature; and laboratory findings like leukocytosis and shift to the left.
  • Scoring: Scores range from 1 to 10, with higher scores indicating a higher likelihood of appendicitis.
  • Prediction: Scores of 9-10 indicate certain appendicitis, 7-8 suggest a high likelihood, 5-6 are equivocal, and 1-4 indicate appendicitis can be ruled out.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Flank pain:

  • Flank pain occurs in conditions such as renal colic or urinary tract infections.
  • The pain of acute appendicitis is migratory and starts from the umbilical region and then migrates to the right iliac fossa.

Option C - Normal temperature:

  • Mild pyrexia is common. Temperature is usually 37.5° C - 38° C.

Option D - Leukopenia:

  • Leukopenia is defined as decreased white blood cells in the blood and occurs in viral as well as enteric fever.
  • A neutrophil-predominant leukocytosis is seen in 80-90% of acute appendicitis.

questions.text: What is the likely causative agent for the distinctive sickle-shaped organism and 'falling leaves' motility in a 28-year-old with foul-smelling diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and bloating?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Giardia lamblia:

  • The clinical presentation of foul-smelling, greasy diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and bloating, along with the presence of a distinctive sickle-shaped organism within the lumen and trophozoite motility resembling falling leaves, is characteristic of Giardia lamblia infection. Giardia trophozoites have a characteristic "falling leaf" motility, where their flagella-driven movement resembles the fluttering of leaves.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Entamoeba histolytica: Entamoeba histolytica causes dysentery and amoebic colitis and exhibits very active unidirectional motility.

Option C - Balantidium coli: Balantidium coli is a ciliated protozoan causing dysentery and exhibits rotating motility.

Option D - Dientamoeba fragilis: Dientamoeba fragilis exhibits sickle-shaped cysts exhibits an internal flagellum.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of redness, swelling, and pain in the right leg with fever, chills, and nausea. He reports seeing liquid oozing from the affected area on his right leg. His temperature is 38.7°C (102°F), his pulse is 106/min, and his blood pressure is 152/94 mm Hg. Examination of the right lower leg shows a large area of erythema with poorly-demarcated borders and purulent drainage. The area is fluctuant, warm, and tender to the touch.  In addition to incision, drainage, and taking cultures from the wound, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Intravenous vancomycin:

  • This patient is most likely suffering from purulent cellulitis, a rapidly spreading local infection of the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue. Cellulitis is caused most commonly by Streptococcus pyogenes and Staphylococcus aureus.
  • It commonly appears in areas with broken skin (e.g., due to trauma or another infection). The diagnosis is usually clinical.
  • Intravenous vancomycin is effective against gram-positive bacteria, including MRSA, making it the empirical treatment of choice for patients with purulent cellulitis and systemic signs of infection (e.g., tachycardia, fever).
  • Since infection by MRSA is becoming increasingly common, an antibiotic that covers MRSA is also required for empirical therapy in patients with a history of recent hospitalization, recent antibiotic use, penetrating trauma, injection drug use, or evidence of MRSA infection or colonization elsewhere.
  • Once culture and sensitivity results are available, a more targeted approach to antibiotic therapy should be pursued.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Oral clindamycin:

  • Clindamycin is effective against gram-positive bacteria, including MRSA. While clindamycin is one of the recommended empiric antibiotics for non-purulent cellulitis in patients who do not require parenteral therapy, it is not recommended for purulent cellulitis. Oral clindamycin is inappropriate for this patient with systemic signs of infection (tachycardia, fever).

Option C - Surgical debridement:

  • For patients with cellulitis, surgical debridement is indicated in the case of recurrent infection and necrotizing fasciitis and if cellulitis continues to spread despite appropriate antibiotic therapy.
  • This patient has no evidence of necrotizing fasciitis, such as pain out of proportion to the area of erythema, skin necrosis, or crepitus.

Option D - Oral dicloxacillin:

  • Dicloxacillin is a type of anti-staphylococcal penicillin that is indicated for nonpurulent cellulitis. However, it is not indicated for empiric treatment of purulent cellulitis because it is ineffective against MRSA.

questions.text: Below are the various options showing the order of appearance of serum markers in Hepatitis B infection. Pick the correct answer.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - HBsAg → HBeAg → IgM → Anti-HBeAg → Anti-HBsAg:

  • Initially, HBsAg (hepatitis B surface antigen) is detected during the acute phase of infection.
  • Subsequently, as the infection progresses, HBeAg (hepatitis B e antigen) appears.
  • IgM antibodies against hepatitis B core antigen (IgM anti-HBc) appear early in infection and indicate recent exposure.
  • As the infection resolves, IgG antibodies against HBsAg (anti-HBs) and HBeAg (anti-HBe) develop, with anti-HBeAg before anti-HBsAg.

Incorrect Options: Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: A patient after heavy drinking of alcohol presents with multiple episodes of vomiting and hematemesis. The most likely diagnosis could be:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mallory-Weiss syndrome:

  • Mallory-Weiss syndrome is typically caused by excessive vomiting or retching, such as in cases of heavy alcohol consumption or bulimia. The main symptom is upper gastrointestinal bleeding, which can manifest as hematemesis or melena. Given the patient's history of heavy alcohol drinking, multiple episodes of vomiting, and hematemesis, Mallory-Weiss syndrome is a likely diagnosis.

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Esophageal carcinoma: Esophageal carcinoma refers to cancer of the esophagus, which can present with symptoms such as dysphagia, weight loss, chest pain, and gastrointestinal bleeding.

Option C - Achalasia cardia: Symptoms include difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of undigested food, and chest pain. Achalasia cardia does not typically present with episodes of vomiting and hematemesis.

Option D - Boerhaave's syndrome: It is a medical emergency and can present with symptoms such as severe chest pain, difficulty breathing, and subcutaneous emphysema (air trapped under the skin). While heavy alcohol consumption can increase the risk of esophageal rupture, the multiple episodes of vomiting and hematemesis in this patient are more suggestive of Mallory-Weiss syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following changes in kinetic parameters is associated with a non-competitive inhibitor?

choices.text: Increase in both Km and Vmax

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Decrease in Vmax:

Non-competitive inhibition

  • Non-competitive inhibitors bind to an enzyme's regulatory site, inducing a change in its configuration, preventing substrate binding and reaction.
  • Increasing substrate concentration does not overcome non-competitive inhibition, leading to decreased apparent Vmax.
  • However, Km remains unchanged, as non-competitive inhibitors do not interfere with substrate binding at the active site.
  • The effect is depicted graphically by a curve with unchanged Km but reduced Vmax.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D: Refer to the explanation of option A.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is true for a patient with hematuria and the given renal histopathology slide?



1. It is a Type III Hypersensitivity reaction.

2. Streptococcus pyogenes: strains 12, 4, and 1 are responsible.

3. Gross findings on the kidney show flea-bitten appearance.

4. Linear immunofluorescence is seen.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1,2 and 3 are true:

The image shows hypercellular glomerulus, increased inflammatory (neutrophilic) infiltrate, proliferative changes in endothelium and mesangial cells

The likely diagnosis in this patient is post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

1. It is a Type III Hypersensitivity reaction (Immune complex mediated)

2. Streptococcus pyogenes: strains 12, 4 and 1 are responsible.

3. Gross findings on the kidney show a flea-bitten appearance.

These statements are true regarding PSGN.

Incorrect Options:

4. Linear immunofluorescence is seen.

This statement is not true, linear immunofluorescence is seen in good pasture syndrome. In PSGN immunofluorescence shows starry sky appearance.

questions.text: Which statement regarding coronary blood flow is true?

choices.text: Coronary blood flow is directly related to perfusion pressure and inversely related to resistance.
Coronary blood flow is inversely related to perfusion pressure and directly related to resistance.
Coronary blood flow is directly related to perfusion pressure and also to resistance.
Coronary blood flow is inversely related to both pressure and resistance

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Coronary blood flow is directly related to perfusion pressure and inversely related to resistance:

  • Based on the clinical picture and investigation findings, the patient likely suffers from congestive cardiac failure.
  • Coronary blood flow is related directly to the perfusion pressure (diastolic aortic pressure) and the duration of diastole.
  • Because coronary flow falls to negligible values during systole, the duration of diastole becomes an important limiting factor for myocardial perfusion during tachycardia.
  • Coronary blood flow is inversely related to coronary vascular resistance. Resistance is dependent mainly on intrinsic factors, including metabolic products, autonomic activity, and different pharmacologic agents.
  • Damage to the endothelium of coronary blood vessels has been shown to alter their ability to dilate and increase coronary vascular resistance.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D; Refer to option A explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about bile acid sequestrants (resins) is true in the context of pregnancy?

choices.text: Resins are used for managing Type 1 diabetes mellitus during pregnancy.
Resins are a safe option for reducing blood cholesterol during pregnancy.
Resins are used for managing chronic kidney disease during pregnancy.
Colesevelam is specifically approved for hypercholesterolemia in pregnancy.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Resins are a safe option for reducing blood cholesterol during pregnancy.

Explanation:

  • In pregnancy, hypercholesterolemia is typically managed with lifestyle interventions (e.g., low-cholesterol diet, exercise) due to limited safety data on lipid-lowering drugs.
  • Statins, the standard for hypercholesterolemia, are contraindicated (FDA Category X) due to teratogenic risks (e.g., fetal skeletal abnormalities).
  • Bile acid sequestrants are considered relatively safe in pregnancy (FDA Category B for cholestyramine, Category C for colesevelam) because they are not systemically absorbed, minimizing fetal exposure.
  • They are used in severe cases, such as FH with high cardiovascular risk (e.g., LDL-C >190 mg/dL or vascular disease), when benefits outweigh risks. However, resins are the preferred pharmacologic option when therapy is unavoidable, as per AHA and ACOG guidance.
  • Close monitoring is required for maternal nutrient deficiencies (e.g., fat-soluble vitamins A, D, E, K) and potential fetal risks (e.g., vitamin K deficiency affecting coagulation).

 

Resins are used for managing Type 1 diabetes mellitus during pregnancy (Option A): Resins are lipid-lowering agents used for hypercholesterolemia, not diabetes management, and have no role in controlling blood glucose or insulin requirements.

Resins are used for managing chronic kidney disease during pregnancy (Option C): Resins are not used for CKD management, as they target hypercholesterolemia, not renal function or CKD-specific issues. While CKD patients may have dyslipidemia, lipid management in pregnancy follows the same principles as for hypercholesterolemia, with resins considered only for severe hyperlipidemia, not CKD itself.

Colesevelam is specifically approved for hypercholesterolemia in pregnancy (Option D): Colesevelam, a bile acid sequestrant, is FDA-approved for hypercholesterolemia and glycemic control in type 2 diabetes (non-pregnant adults). No bile acid sequestrant, including colesevelam, has specific FDA approval for hypercholesterolemia in pregnancy due to insufficient safety data.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child presented to a local subcenter with a 4-day history of fever, cough, and difficulty breathing. The child has a respiratory rate of 46 breaths per minute, a heart rate of 100 beats per minute, and a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F). On auscultation, there are crackles in the right lower lung zone. The oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. The child appears lethargic but is still responsive to verbal stimuli. The parents report that the child has had no prior illnesses of note and is up to date with vaccinations. A complete blood count shows a white blood cell count of 15,000/µL, with 70% neutrophils. A chest X-ray indicates an area of consolidation in the right lower lobe. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this child's condition?

choices.text: IV antibiotics at PHC and observe
Give the first dose of IV antibiotics & refer to a higher centre
Oral amoxicillin for 5 days and send home

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Give the first dose of IV antibiotics & refer to a higher centre

 

Explanation:

 

This 18-month-old child presents with:

  • Fever, cough, respiratory distress (RR = 46/min)

  • Crackles and consolidation on CXR → Suggestive of pneumonia

  • Lethargy (a danger sign in Integrated Management of Childhood Illness [IMCI])

  • Oxygen saturation of 94% on room air (borderline)

Classification (per IMCI guidelines):

  • Lethargy = general danger sign

  • RR > 40/min in a child 12–59 months = fast breathing

  • Crackles + consolidation = pneumonia

  • Constitutional signs (lethargy) = complicated/severe pneumonia

 

Appropriate Initial Management:

  • General danger signs (lethargy) require urgent referral.

  • First dose of IV antibiotics (usually IV ampicillin + gentamicin or ceftriaxone) should be given before referral.

  • This ensures that treatment is not delayed in case of deterioration during transport.

 

IV antibiotics at PHC and observe (Option A): Incorrect because the child has danger signs and requires care at a higher-level facility with inpatient monitoring.

Oral amoxicillin and send home (Option C): Suitable for non-severe pneumonia (no danger signs, alert child), but this child is lethargic.

Home remedies (Option D): Inappropriate in any child with signs of pneumonia, especially with general danger signs.

questions.text: Which of the following is the dose of Human rabies immunoglobulin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 20 IU / kg IM:

  • The dose of Human rabies immunoglobulin is 20 IU / kg IM
  • Rabies Immunoglobulin is administered in Category 3 bites and, under certain conditions, in Category 2 bites, particularly in cases of HIV or immunocompromised individuals.
  • Two types of Rabies Immunoglobulin exist:
    1. Equine immunoglobulin: Not the preferred choice, dosed at 40 IU/kg.
    2. Human rabies Immunoglobulin: The preferred option, administered at 20 IU/kg.
  • It should commence on Day 0 alongside vaccination and can be given within 7 days, as antibody formation due to vaccination occurs thereafter.
  • Administered via the intramuscular (IM) route, 70% of the dose is applied in and around the wound, while the remaining can be administered at a distance from the wound.
  • Once administered, immunoglobulin doesn't require repetition even in cases of re-exposure.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, D:

  • These do not indicate the doses of the human rabies Immunoglobulin

questions.text: Which protein is responsible for the maximum reabsorption of sodium at the basolateral membrane in the proximal tubule?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Na+-K+-ATPase Pump:

  • This pump is responsible for the maximum reabsorption of sodium at the basolateral membrane in the proximal tubule.

*NHE (sodium hydrogen exchanger)

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Sodium Bicarbonate Co-transporter (NBC): While the NBC plays a role in bicarbonate reabsorption, it does not account for the majority of sodium reabsorption at the basolateral membrane.

Option C - Passive reabsorption: While passive reabsorption contributes to overall sodium reabsorption, it does not involve specific proteins like the Na+-K+-ATPase pump.

Option D - None of the above: The correct option (Option A) has been identified, so this statement is incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following diuretics is involved in the blockade of the adenosine A1 receptor on the nephron?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Caffeine:

  • This is used in the treatment of migraine
  • It works by blocking the adenosine A1 receptor of the nephron.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nesiritide-Nesiritide: 

  • It is used in heart failure
  • It acts on enzyme-linked receptors on the nephron by attaching to guanylyl cyclase and increasing CGMP leading to sodium loss in urine

Option C and D - These inhibit sodium-glucose transporters in the nephron and are used in diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: Which cells are responsible for contrast enhancement by lateral inhibition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Horizontal cells:

  • Horizontal cells are responsible for contrast enhancement by lateral inhibition. They achieve this by modulating the signals between photoreceptor cells and bipolar cells.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rod cells: Rod cells are responsible for night vision and are not involved in contrast enhancement by lateral inhibition.

Option B - Bipolar cells: Bipolar cells are interneurons that transmit signals from photoreceptor cells to ganglion cells in the retina.

Option D - Amacrine cells: Amacrine cells are interneurons in the retina that modulate the signaling between bipolar cells and ganglion cells

questions.text:
A 50-year-old female comes to the OPD to get evaluated for irregular periods for 7 months, accompanied by fatigue, numbness, and tingling sensations in her left hand. She had a history of a hand fracture, which was managed with the application of a cast, as shown in the image. Identify the fracture she sustained and pick the option containing the factual statements regarding this fracture.



a) Lateral tilt is a component of this fracture and is neutralized by ulnar deviation

b) It is also called a Radial Styloid fracture

c) Radial and ulnar styloid processes are at different levels due to fracture

d) Pronation is a component of this fracture and is neutralized by supination

e) Dinner fork deformity is a classic deformity

f) Extensor carpi radialis is the most common tendon injured
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - a,e,f:

  • Patients nearing menopause are prone to developing osteoporosis causing weakening of bones leading to fractures.
  • The picture depicts a cast at a specific angle used to treat Colles’ fracture.
  • The patient also complains of numbness and tingling sensations in the affected hand which proves that she might be experiencing carpel tunnel syndrome, which is most commonly associated with Colles’ fracture.

a) Lateral tilt is a component of this fracture and is neutralized by ulnar deviation

e) Dinner fork deformity is a classic deformity

f) Extensor carpi radialis is the most common tendon injured

Incorrect Options:

Option A - b,c,f:

  • Its other name is not Radial Styloid fracture.
  • Radial and ulnar styloid processes are normally at different levels. But due to fracture, they will be at the same level.

Option B - a,d,e:

  • Pronation is not a component of this fracture. Supination is a component of Colles’ fracture and is neutralized by pronation.

Option D - b,c,d:

  • Option is eliminated by above explainations

questions.text: What is the drug of choice in the treatment of Narcolepsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Modafinil:

  • Modafinil is an indirectly acting adrenergic drug. They increase the release of catecholamines.
  • It decreases sleep.
  • It is DOC for Daytime sleepiness.
    • Occurs in Narcolepsy
    • Occurs in OSA (obstructive sleep apnea)
      • Apnea due to excess fat around the neck compressing the respiratory tract.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Tiprolisant:

  • Pitolisant is the other name of Tiprolisant
  • It is Histamine (H3) inverse agonist.
  • Cause wakefulness is used for the treatment of Narcolepsy.

Option C - Armodafinil:

  • Armodafinil is enantiomer of modafinil.
  • Used in Obstructive sleep apnea.

Option D - Solriamfetol:

  • It is a new drug approved for Narcolepsy treatment.
  • It increases norepinephrine and dopamine in the brain prevents sleepiness.

questions.text: In a municipal corporation, there has been a surge in biomedical waste generated due to the recent opening of a hospital in the vicinity. To efficiently manage this waste and prevent environmental pollution, the authorities decide to implement a dual chamber incinerator. Which among the following is the temperature range used in the Dual Chamber Incinerator?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 800-1100°C:

  • The optimal temperature range for the primary combustion chamber of a dual chamber incinerator is 800-1100°C, ensuring thorough destruction of biomedical waste and minimizing environmental and public health risks.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are not applicable as they do not provide the correct temperature range for the dual chamber incinerator.

questions.text: A healthy 18-year-old girl presented to a local emergency room with 48hr of abdominal pain and vomiting. On physical examination. there is tenderness over the left lower abdominal quadrant with guarding. Based on the radiological and biochemical reports, a diagnosis of severe acute pancreatitis was made. All the following can be used to predict severe acute pancreatitis except :
questions.solution:
Tools for predicting the severity of Acute pancreatitis

At 48 hours

  • Ranson scoring a system-A score of 3 or more indicates a severe attack. It predicts the severity of the disease on the basis of 11 parameters obtained at the time of admission or 48 hours later. It has a low positive predictive value of 50% and a high negative predictive value (90%)
  • Glasgow scoring system-A score of 3 or more indicates the severe attack
  • Serum C- Reactive protein levels - >150 mg/dL is an indicator of severity

At admission

  • APACHE II - Based on the patient’s age, previous health status and 12 routine physiologic measurements, APACHE II provides a general measure of the severity of disease. An APACHE II score of 8 or higher defines severe pancreatitis. The main advantage is that it can be used upon admission and repeated at any time. APACHE II has a positive predictive value of 43% and a negative predictive value of 89%.
  • BISAP (Bedside Index for Severity of Acute Pancreatitis )- Blood urea nitrogen (>25mg/dL), impaired mental status(GCS <15), presence of systemic inflammatory response syndrome, age >60 years and pleural effusion. A score of more than or equal to 3 is a predictor of severe acute pancreatitis
  • Urea at admission - >60 mmoL/L
