Balthazar’s CT severity index -A score of greater than or equal to 7 is a predictor of severe pancreatitis

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents to the emergency department with fever, severe headache, and neck stiffness. A lumbar puncture is performed to collect cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) for analysis. Which of the following cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) findings is typically observed in bacterial meningitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Turbid CSF:

  • Turbid or cloudy CSF is a characteristic finding in bacterial meningitis due to the presence of increased white blood cells (WBCs) and bacteria in the CSF.
  • This turbidity results from the inflammatory response and the presence of pus in the CSF.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Normal opening pressure: In bacterial meningitis, the opening pressure of CSF is typically elevated due to increased intracranial pressure resulting from inflammation and edema.

Option C - Normal glucose level: Bacterial meningitis is associated with low CSF glucose levels due to bacterial consumption of glucose and impaired glucose transport across the blood-brain barrier.

Option D - Lymphocytic predominance: Bacterial meningitis is characterized by a predominance of neutrophils (polymorphonuclear leukocytes) in the CSF, whereas lymphocytic predominance is more commonly observed in viral meningitis.

questions.text: During the surgery for acute appendicitis in a 2-year-old child, the surgeon discovered a structure measuring 2 inches in length located 2 feet closer to the ileocecal junction. What is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Meckel’s diverticulum:

  • The structure measuring 2 inches in length and located 2 feet closer to the ileocecal junction is suggestive of Meckel’s diverticulum.
  • Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital abnormality where a small pouch-like structure forms in the small intestine.
  • It is the result of incomplete closure of the vitelline duct, which connects the developing embryo to the yolk sac.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about the definition of steroid dependent nephrotic syndrome?

choices.text: Two consecutive relapses when on alternate day steroid therapy
Two or more relapses in the initial 6-month period
More than 3 relapses in any 12 months
Two consecutive relapses within 3 weeks of its discontinuation.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Two consecutive relapses when on alternate day steroid therapy:

  • Steroid dependent nephrotic syndrome is characterized by Two consecutive relapses when on alternate day steroid therapy or within 14 days of its discontinuation.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Two or more relapses in the initial 6-month period

Option C - More than 3 relapses in any 12 months

B and C are both features of frequent relapse

questions.text: Administration of 4 units of PRBC,4 units of FFP, one unit of SDP is done in which round of massive blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Round 2:

Round 2: of transfusion includes -Infusion of

  • 4 Units PRBC , 4 Units FFP , 1 Unit SDP (Single Donor Platelet)
  • Team B: Resend blood to lab so that we can evaluate coagulopathy and metabolic acidosis component.
  • Calcium gluconate is given to prevent tetany (caused by citrate in PRBC).
  • Cryoprecipitate is given: If the fibrinogen < 100 mg/L
  • If No Improvement: ROUND 3

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Round 1: Infusion of 4 Units of PRBC (O-VE) & 2 units FFP (AB +)

Option C - Round 3: Repeat round 2 + factor VIIa

Option D - Round 4: Does not exist

questions.text: Which of the following is a side effect associated with the use of ivabradine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Luminous phenomenon:

  • Ivabradine, reducing heart rate by inhibiting funny channels on the SA node, can cause visual abnormalities.
  • It blocks funny channels in the retina, altering perception of light.
  • Patients may experience normal light as excessively bright or perceive bright flashes.
  • Luminous phenomenon is a well-known side effect of ivabradine therapy.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Hypertension:

  • Ivabradine primarily reduces heart rate and can lower blood pressure.

Option B - Tachycardia:

  • Ivabradine specifically reduces heart rate, leading to bradycardia.

Option D - Peripheral Edema:

  • Ivabradine doesn't commonly cause peripheral edema; it primarily affects heart rate without inducing fluid retention.

questions.text: Serum acid phosphate is raised in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Prostatic carcinoma:

  • Prostatic carcinoma, or prostate cancer, is a malignant tumor that develops in the prostate gland. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is the commonly used marker for prostate cancer, but serum acid phosphate levels can also be elevated in some cases.

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - Osteosarcoma: Osteosarcoma can lead to elevated levels of alkaline phosphatase, it is not typically associated with raised levels of serum acid phosphate.

Option C - Paget's disease: Paget's disease can cause elevated levels of alkaline phosphatase, it is not typically associated with raised levels of serum acid phosphate.

Option D - Hyperparathyroidism: Hyperparathyroidism can affect phosphate levels, it does not typically cause raised levels of serum acid phosphate.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old female patient presents with complaints characterized by episodic color changes in her fingers in response to cold temperatures or emotional stress. She mentions experiencing these symptoms for several years. Upon further examination, the patient is noted to have thickening and tightening of the skin on her fingers. She also reports occasional episodes of ischemic pain in her digits, particularly during cold weather.

Which of the following antibodies is most likely to be positive in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Anti-Centromere antibody:

  • The patient's presentation, including Raynaud's phenomenon, sclerodactyly (thickening and tightening of the skin on the fingers), and ischemic pain in the digits, is suggestive of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis.
  • In this, Raynaud's phenomenon often precedes the development of sclerodactyly by several years.
  • One of the characteristic antibodies associated with systemic sclerosis, particularly in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), is the Anti-Centromere antibody.
  • Autoantibodies in systemic sclerosis
  • Image 1:Anti-Topoisomerase antibodies
  • Image 2:Anti-Centromere antibody
  • Image 3:Anti-RNA Polymerase III

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D:

  • Other antibodies such as Anti-Topoisomerase antibodies (anti-Scl-70), Ku antibody, and U1 RNP may be seen in systemic sclerosis, they are less commonly associated with the limited cutaneous form

questions.text: Which of the following is the anticoagulant used in a green vacutainer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  D) Sodium Heparin :

  • Sodium Heparin is the anticoagulant used in a green vacutainer tube.
  • Green tubes are used for : Osmotic fragility testing, immunophenotyping, Arterial Blood Gas studies.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and C are incorrect. Correct option is explained above.

questions.text: Which subtype of schizophrenia is associated with predominantly negative symptoms and a poor prognosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Simple schizophrenia

  • Simple Schizophrenia is a subtype of schizophrenia characterized by predominantly negative symptoms, such as social withdrawal, anhedonia (loss of pleasure), avolition (loss of motivation), and affective blunting (inability to express emotions). It is associated with the worst prognosis among the subtypes of schizophrenia. The negative symptoms in simple schizophrenia can lead to significant impairment in daily functioning and a poor quality of life.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Paranoid schizophrenia

  • Paranoid schizophrenia is incorrect because it is associated with positive symptoms such as delusions and hallucinations, and it has a relatively good prognosis compared to simple schizophrenia.

Option B- Catatonic schizophrenia

  • Catatonic schizophrenia is incorrect because it is characterized by symptoms of catatonia, including motor abnormalities and peculiar postures. Catatonic schizophrenia has a better prognosis compared to simple schizophrenia.

Option D- Undifferentiated schizophrenia

  • Undifferentiated schizophrenia is incorrect because it involves a mixture of symptoms and does not specifically refer to predominantly negative symptoms. The prognosis of undifferentiated schizophrenia can vary depending on the severity and combination of symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following are not considered examples of anticipatory control systems?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Adaptive relaxation of the stomach:

  • Adaptive relaxation occurs as a response to the filling of the stomach, allowing it to accommodate larger volumes of food. It is more reactive and not strictly anticipatory.

Incorrect Options:

Option A – Thermoregulation System: Thermoregulation involves maintaining body temperature within a narrow range. This can include anticipatory mechanisms, such as sweating before physical activity in anticipation of increased heat production. 

Option B – Cephalic phase of gastric secretion: The cephalic phase of gastric secretion is a preparatory phase that occurs before food enters the stomach. It involves the release of digestive enzymes and stomach acid in response to sensory stimuli (sight, smell, taste of food). This is an example of anticipatory control, preparing the digestive system for food intake.

Option C – Receptive relaxation of the stomach: Receptive relaxation occurs in response to the arrival of food in the mouth on swallowing food, and it enters the upper parts of the esophagus, the upper part of the stomach relaxes or dilates. This happens ahead of the food reaches, in order to receive the food.

questions.text: Mr. Johnson, a chronic heavy drinker, presents to the emergency room with confusion, disorientation, and visual hallucinations 48 hours after stopping alcohol consumption. Vital signs reveal increased heart rate and elevated blood pressure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Delirium Tremens

  • Delirium Tremens is characterized by disturbed consciousness, disorientation, hallucinations (visual most commonly), and autonomic hyperactivity. It is a life-threatening condition that typically occurs 48 to 72 hours after alcohol cessation, especially in individuals with a history of heavy alcohol use.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Alcohol intoxication: This choice is incorrect because Mr. Johnson's symptoms occur 48 hours after stopping alcohol, which is beyond the timeframe of acute alcohol intoxication.

Option B - Hepatic Encephalopathy: Hepatic Encephalopathy is a neuropsychiatric syndrome associated with liver dysfunction. It can occur in chronic alcoholics with liver disease and is characterized by confusion, disorientation, and personality changes.

Option D - Alcohol-related psychosis: While alcohol-related psychosis can occur with heavy alcohol use, the presence of confusion, disorientation, and vital sign abnormalities in this scenario is more indicative of Delirium Tremens.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with unilateral painful proptosis, restricted eye movements, and decreased visual acuity. The child also has lid edema, conjunctival congestion, and chemosis. The parents report that the child has been experiencing fever, weakness, and malaise. Based on the clinical features described, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Options A - Orbital cellulitis:

  • The clinical presentation of unilateral painful proptosis, restricted eye movements, decreased visual acuity, lid edema, conjunctival congestion, chemosis, and systemic symptoms of fever, weakness, and malaise are indicative of orbital cellulitis. Orbital cellulitis is characterized by inflammation behind the orbital septum and is commonly caused by sinusitis, dental infections, dacryocystitis, or trauma.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Preseptal cellulitis: Preseptal cellulitis is characterized by eyelid erythema, edema, and warmth without proptosis or restricted eye movements. It is more commonly seen in children and can be caused by insect bites or mild trauma.

Option C - Ethmoid sinusitis: Ethmoid sinusitis can be an underlying cause of orbital cellulitis, but the presented clinical scenario describes the manifestations of orbital cellulitis rather than ethmoid sinusitis alone.

Option D - Dacryocystitis: Dacryocystitis is an infection of the lacrimal sac and is not typically associated with proptosis, restricted eye movements, or decreased visual acuity. While it can lead to orbital cellulitis in severe cases, the given scenario suggests a primary diagnosis of orbital cellulitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not appropriate regarding National AIDS Control Programme?

choices.text: National AIDS Control Programme (NACP) launched in 1992
National AIDS Prevention and Control Policy (NAPCP) in 2021
Headquarters of National AIDS Control Organisation is New Delhi
National strategic plan for HIV/AIDS elimination 2024-2030

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - National strategic plan for HIV/AIDS elimination 2024-2030:

  • National strategic plan for HIV/AIDS elimination - 2017-2024.Merged with the National Health Mission in 2021.
  • First case of HIV/AIDS - 1986 (Chennai)
  • National AIDS Control Programme (NACP) launched in 1992.
  • National AIDS Prevention and Control Policy (NAPCP) in 2021
  • National strategic plan for HIV/AIDS elimination - 2017-2024
  • Merged with the National Health Mission in 2021.
  • NACO
    • National AIDS Control Organisation
    • Headquarters: New Delhi
    • Launched NACP

 

Incorrect Options: 

Options A,B and C are incorrect 

  • These options are true regarding National AIDS Control Programme.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis from the given abdominal x-ray?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Rectal foreign body:

  • Rectal foreign bodies are a difficult and unique topic of colorectal trauma. The reasons for insertion and types of foreign bodies vary greatly. The most common objects observed are household objects such as bottles and glasses.
  • In decreasing order of frequency, the motives for insertion are autoeroticism, concealment, attention-seeking behavior, accidental, assault, and constipation relief.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ureterocele: A ureterocele is a cystic structure that projects into the bladder, usually around the vesicoureteric junction (VUJ).

Option B - Pelvic bone fracture: The X-ray image does not include any such trauma. Hence, the case is not a pelvic bone fracture.

Option D - Bladder stone: Bladder stone (calculi) occurs in a "hollow" viscus and has a layered calcification made up of alternating layers of strongly calcified and matrix components.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents to the clinic with a 2-day history of watery diarrhea, vomiting, and mild dehydration. Upon examination, the child appears lethargic with dry mucous membranes. The physician diagnoses acute gastroenteritis and recommends oral rehydration therapy. What is the sodium concentration of reduced osmolarity ORS?

  • Oral rehydration solution (ORS) is a key intervention for managing dehydration due to diarrhea, especially in resource-limited settings.
  • Reduced osmolarity ORS is recommended by the World Health Organization (WHO) to treat dehydration.
  • ORS is an example of appropriate technology (principle of primary healthcare).

questions.text: Which of the following features as shown in the image is observed by an Ophthalmologist in a 36-year-old male who presented to the OPD and sustained a blunt injury to right eye?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Iridodialysis

  • An iridodialysis is characteristic of blunt injury to the eye. Iridodialysis is the disinsertion of the iris from the scleral spur.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hyphema: Hyphema is a condition where there is blood in the anterior chamber of the eye. It can occur as a result of blunt trauma to the eye. Hyphema can cause decreased vision, eye pain, due to increased intraocular pressure and can also lead to corneal staining.

Option C - Corneal abrasion: A corneal abrasion is an injury to the corneal epithelium. Corneal abrasions typically cause pain, tearing, and foreign body sensation.

Option D - Retinal detachment: It is a seperation of retinal pigment epithelium from neurosensory retina. Symptoms of retinal detachment may include flashes of light, floaters, and a curtain or shadow over the field of vision. An ophthalmologist would need to perform a dilated retinal examination to confirm retinal detachment.

questions.text: A local health department in a village is investigating an outbreak of vector-borne diseases. Several patients have presented with symptoms, including high fever, severe joint pain, and rash. The health authorities suspect the involvement of Aedes mosquitoes,  infamous vectors for transmitting various diseases. Among the listed diseases below, which is NOT caused by the Aedes mosquito?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - West Nile fever:

  • Aedes mosquitoes, particularly Aedes aegypti, are responsible for transmitting several diseases. 
  • Dengue fever, Chikungunya, and Yellow fever are all transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes. 
  • Aedes is NOT a vector for West Nile virus. This virus is transmitted by Culex mosquitoes.
  • The clinical picture shows that the patients in a rural area presented with nonspecific symptoms such as fever, joint pain, and a rash.
  • Further history and lab investigations are required to comment on the diagnosis.
  • Mosquito control measures should be initiated when an outbreak is recognized.
  • Common methods include:
    • Environmental sanitation
    • Larvicides
    • Biological control using aquatic predators
    • Chemical control using spraying methods
Diseases transmitted by mosquitoes
Anopheles Malaria
Culex Japanese encephalitis, Filariasis, West Nile fever
Aedes Dengue, Chikungunya, Rift Valley fever, Zika virus
Mansonia Brugian filariasis

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dengue Fever:

  • Dengue fever is caused by dengue virus, transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes.
  • DF manifests as fever with a headache, retro-orbital pain, arthralgia, and myalgia.
  • It can progress to more severe forms - dengue hemorrhagic fever and dengue shock syndrome.

Option B - Zika: 

  • Zika virus is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes. 
  • Most infected patients are asymptomatic.
  • Others present with a maculopapular rash and arthralgia.

Option D - Rift Valley Fever:

  • Rift Valley fever is a viral zoonotic disease that primarily affects animals but also has the capacity to infect humans. 
  • It is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and blood-feeding flies. 
  • In humans, the disease ranges from a mild flu-like illness to severe hemorrhagic fever that can be fatal.

questions.text: Which of the following acts as a cell marker for the identification of different types of cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Intermediate filament:

  • Intermediate filaments serve as cell markers for identifying different types of cells due to their cell-type-specific protein composition.
  • Example

Cell marker

Cell

Cytokeratin

Epithelium cell

Vimentin

Fibroblast cell

Desmin

Skeletal muscle cell

Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP)

Astrocytes

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Microtubules: While microtubules have essential cellular functions, they are not typically used as specific markers for identifying different cell types.

Option B - Microfilament: Microfilaments are involved in various cellular processes but are not commonly used as specific markers for identifying different cell types.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman came to the clinic for a consultation regarding contraception. She expressed interest in starting oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) and requests information about the contents of a particular brand she saw advertised. The physician provided her with a package inserted in the image below. Based on the information provided, what is the composition of the oral contraceptive?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg and ethinylestradiol 0.03 mg:

  • The composition of the oral contraceptive depicted in the image is Levonorgestrel 0.15 mg and Ethinylestradiol 0.03 mg.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D provide compositions that do not match the package insert shown in the image.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with a history of recurrent, unilateral nasal obstruction and episodes of profuse epistaxis over the past several months. On examination, the following is observed:



What sign is likely to be seen on this patient's CECT scan due to erosion of the wedge of the pterygoid?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Chopstick sign:

  • The given clinical presentation is consistent with the diagnosis of JNAF. The Chopstick sign is seen in JNAF and refers to the appearance of the medial and lateral pterygoid plates resembling separate chopsticks due to erosion of the pterygoid wedge by the tumor.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Holman-Miller sign: This sign refers to the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus seen in patients of JNAF.

Option B - Hondusa's sign: This sign refers to an increase in distance between the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus and the mandible on a CT scan seen in a patient of JNAF.

Option D - Phelp sign: This sign is seen in glomus tumors and occurs due to erosion of the carotico-jugular spine bone.

questions.text: A 7-week old female infant presented with jaundice and abnormal laboratory findings significant for direct hyperbilirubinemia, transaminitis and elevated alkaline phosphatase and gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT). The total bilirubin level was 6.4, and the direct bilirubin level was 3.2. The baby was exclusively breastfed and otherwise healthy. Ultrasound was done, which revealed the following finding. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Kasai:

  • The given ultrasound image shows a Triangular cord sign which is seen in Biliary atresia
  • Biliary atresia
    • The extrahepatic bile ducts are progressively destroyed by an inflammatory process that starts around the time of birth. 
    • Intrahepatic changes eventually occur, causing biliary cirrhosis and portal hypertension. Untreated, death from the consequences of liver failure occurs before the age of 3 years.
    • Treatment of choice for biliary atresia: Kasai portoenterostomy 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Billroth I: Billroth I is the gastroduodenal anastomosis; this procedure is performed for gastric ulcers

Option B - Billroth II: Billroth II is the gastrojejunostomy; this procedure is done for refractory peptic ulcers and gastric adenocarcinoma.

Option D - Mayo: Mayo repair is used for umbilical hernia repair

questions.text: A 60-year-old gardener presents with a slowly growing lesion on the tip of his nose and a history of occasional bleeding from the lesion. On examination, there is a raised, pearly nodule with telangiectasias on the nasal tip. What is the most appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Mohs micrographic surgery:

  • Mohs micrographic surgery is the most appropriate management for basal cell carcinoma (BCC), which is the likely diagnosis in this case based on the clinical presentation. Mohs surgery is the most appropriate surgical technique used to manage BCC.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Topical corticosteroid cream application: This is not used for the treatment of BCC.

Option B - Cryotherapy: Cryotherapy is not used for the treatment of BCC.

Option D - Observation and regular follow-up: Observation without intervention is generally not recommended in management of BCC.

questions.text: What is the mode of inheritance in Haemophilia A?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - X-linked recessive disorder:

  • Haemophilia A, which is an X-linked recessive disorder.
  • They manifest only in males. 
  • A male with an affected allele on his single X chromosome is hemizygous and can not transmit the disorder to their male offspring, but all his daughters would be carriers. 
  • Healthy heterozygous carrier females pass the disorder to affected sons.
  • So from affected males, it can be transmitted to male grandchildren through carrier daughter

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Autosomal recessive disorder:

  • Haemophilia is not an Autosomal recessive disorder.
  • In an autosomal recessive type inheritance pattern, 2 copies of the same gene must be mutated for an individual to express the disease.
  • An affected individual usually has unaffected parents, each of whom carries a single copy of the mutated gene (carriers) and normally does not exhibit disease symptoms.

Option B - Autosomal dominant disorder:

  • Haemophilia is not an Autosomal dominant disorder.
  • A single affected parent has a 50% chance of transferring the mutated gene to their child.
  • The mutated genes are located on non-sex chromosomes.

Option D - X-linked dominant disorder :

  • Haemophilia is not an X-linked dominant disorder.
  • The X-linked dominant disorder is a mode of inheritance in which an X chromosome carries the dominant gene.
  • This means that the gene causing the disorder is on the X chromosome.
  • Only one copy of the allele is sufficient to express the disease if inherited from a diseased parent. Females are more affected in number.
    Affected males can transmit the disorder only to their daughters, while affected females can transmit the disorder to sons as well as daughters.

questions.text: All these are the true features of NITI Aayog except?

choices.text: The chairperson of framing all administrative policies is the president

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - The chairperson of framing all administrative policies is the president:

 

  • This statement is not true.
  • While the President of India holds a ceremonial role in the Indian administrative setup, the chairperson of NITI Aayog is the Prime Minister of India.
  • The Prime Minister chairs the meetings of NITI Aayog and plays a pivotal role in framing administrative policies related to economic planning and developmen

  • National Institution for Transforming India.
  • It replaced the planning commission.
  • Formed on January 1, 2015.
  • It is THINK TANK of India
  • Responsible for framing all administrative policies.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - National Institution for Transforming India:

  • This statement is true. NITI Aayog stands for National Institution for Transforming India. It was established with the aim of fostering involvement and participation in the economic policy-making process.

Option B - It replaced the planning commission:

  • This statement is true. NITI Aayog was formed to replace the erstwhile Planning Commission, which had been the apex institution for economic planning and development in India since its establishment in 1950.

Option C - It was formed on January 1, 2015:

  • This statement is true. NITI Aayog was officially formed on January 1, 2015, by a resolution of the Union Cabinet, replacing the Planning Commission.

questions.text: A 20-year-old migrant worker in the dental alloy industry comes to the OPD due to an intractable cough, fatigue, weight loss, and night sweats for several weeks. He also complains of pain and swelling near the knee for four months. An X-ray image below shows elevated periosteum and microcalcifications along Sharpey's fibers. Suggest the possible diagnosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Osteogenic sarcoma:

  • This clinical vignette is about a patient who works in the dental alloy industry exposing him to significant amounts of beryllium. This exposure poses a risk of developing osteogenic sarcoma.
  • The cough, weight loss, and fatigue can be a result of either metastatic lung lesions or berylliosis.
  • The elevated periosteum in the distal femur in the X-ray is highly suggestive of osteosarcoma

Incorrect Options:

Option A - TB knee: Though intractable chronic cough, weight loss, fatigue and night sweats are features of TB, TB infection of the knee does not involve elevation of the periosteum.

Option B - Acute pyogenic osteomyelitis: Though raised periosteum is a common finding in acute pyogenic osteomyelitis, no symptoms suggest acute bacterial infection. This patient’s presentation is chronic.

Option D - Syphilitic osteomyelitis: There is no evidence of syphilitic infection in this patient.

questions.text: In a clinical scenario, a pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation is expecting monochorionic twins. Upon evaluation, it is noted that one twin is experiencing anemia, while the other demonstrates polycythemia.There is no differences in weight or amniotic fluid levels between them. What specific diagnosis is associated with this unique presentation in the patient's case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Twin Anemia Polycythemia Sequence (TAPS):

  • TAPS is a rare condition in monochorionic twins where there is a significant difference in hemoglobin levels between the twins. It is characterized by anemia in one twin (donor) and polycythemia in the other twin (recipient).
  • Diagnosis of TAPS is made on fetal Doppler when the donor twin has MCA PSV of > 1.5 MoM, while the recipient twin has MCA

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Twin-to-twin Transfusion Syndrome (TTTS):

  • TTTS is a condition in which there is an imbalance in blood flow between the fetuses sharing the same placenta (monochorionic twins). It results in one twin (donor) giving more blood to the other twin (recipient), leading to volume overload and other complications.

Option C - Monochorionic Monoamniotic (MCMA):

  • MCMA twins share the same chorionic sac and amniotic sac. This condition is associated with higher risks, including cord entanglement and compression.

Option D - Discordant Growth Syndrome (DGS):

  • Discordant Growth Syndrome refers to a situation where one twin is growing at a significantly different rate than the other twin. This can be due to various factors such as differences in placental function.

questions.text: A 28-year-old gardener presents to the clinic with a tender, red, and swollen area on her forearm, showing a central area of necrosis surrounded by an erythematous halo. A skin biopsy reveals eosinophilic material forming radially arranged spikes around the necrotic center. What term describes this histological phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon:

  • Histopathological staining of the biopsy shows a star-shaped body (asteroid body), and the patient's presentation is suggestive of sporotrichosis caused by Sporothrix schenckii.
  • Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon (asteroid bodies) is the in vivo formation of intensely eosinophilic material (radiate, star-like, asteroid or club-shaped configurations) around microorganisms (fungi, bacteria and parasites) or biologically inert substances.  

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Granuloma: A granuloma is a localized area of inflammation characterized by a persistent immune stimulus that causes the accumulation of macrophages and immune cells, typically lymphocytes. Granulomas are often seen in response to chronic infections, autoimmune diseases, or foreign bodies.

Option B - Acantholysis: Acantholysis is the loss of intercellular connections between keratinocytes in the epidermis. It is a histological feature seen in conditions like pemphigus vulgaris, where autoantibodies target the desmosomal proteins that hold keratinocytes together. Acantholysis does not involve the deposition of eosinophilic material around a necrotic center, as described in the question.

Option D - Koebnerization: The Koebner phenomenon refers to the development of new skin lesions at the site of trauma or injury in individuals with certain skin conditions, such as psoriasis or lichen planus. It does not involve the histological findings described in the question, which focus on eosinophilic material deposition around a central necrotic area.

questions.text: All of the following are the electrolyte disturbances observed in patient with tumor lysis syndrome on cancer therapy except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B- Hypernatremia:Hypernatremia is not seen in tumor lysis syndrome

Incorrect Options- A,C &D (Hyperkalemia, Hyperphosphatemia & Hypocalcemia): All are seen in tumor lysis syndrome

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic with a history of binge drinking presents with an episode of vomiting bright red blood. His vitals are stable. An endoscopy was performed, an image of which is given below; what is the probable diagnosis here?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Mallory Weiss Tear:

  • The most probable diagnosis for a 45-year-old alcoholic with a history of binge drinking who presents with an episode of vomiting bright red blood is Mallory Weiss Tear.
  • Mallory Weiss Tear is a condition characterized by a tear between the esophagus and the stomach, known as the gastroesophageal junction.
  • It is commonly associated with alcoholism and binge drinking, as well as with excessive vomiting and retching.

Incorrect Options: 

Correct Option A - Tension pneumothorax: It typically presents with sudden onset shortness of breath, chest pain, and tachycardia and is a medical emergency that requires immediate intervention.

Option B - Boerhaave syndrome: Boerhaave syndrome, also known as Spontaneous Esophageal Perforation, typically occurs due to forceful or repeated vomiting, predominantly affecting males.

Option D - Gastric ulcer perforation: Gastric ulcer perforation is when an ulcer in the stomach lining erodes through the stomach wall, leading to a hole or perforation.

questions.text: The attending doctor plans to apply outlet forceps in a patient in the second stage of labor. This is the only correct pre-requisite in the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option B: The pre-requisite to use outlet forceps is –

  • The fetal head is at or on the perineum
  • Head should be fully rotated or < 45º short of full rotation
  • The leading point of the fetal skull should be at a station greater than or equal to +2 for low forceps and at the perineum for outlet forceps
  • The cervix must be fully dilated and retracted

Incorrect Options:

Option A:

  • The leading point of the fetal skull should be at a station greater than or equal to +2 for low forceps and at the perineum for outlet forceps

Option C:

  • Head should be fully rotated or < 45º short of a full rotation

Option D:

  • Uterus need not be relaxed for forceps application. Forceps are applied in the second stage of labor when a patient is usually having peak contractions. Uterine relaxation is required for version procedures such as the external cephalic version or internal podalic version.

questions.text: A gynecological surgeon is performing a hysterectomy for a case of endometriosis with pelvic adhesions. On opening the abdomen, multiple adhesions are obscuring pelvic anatomy. Which of the following is an INCORRECT statement regarding normal pelvic anatomy?

choices.text: The ureter lies beneath the uterine artery
The mucosa of the fallopian tube is lined by ciliated cells
The pouch of Douglas lies between the bladder and the uterus
External iliac artery lies superior to the ovarian fossa

questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option C: The pouch of Douglas lies between the bladder and the uterus

  • The pouch of Douglas is a peritoneal pouch or cul-de-sac that is situated between the uterus and the rectum, not the bladder. It is the most dependent part of the peritoneal cavity in the female pelvis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: The ureter lies beneath the uterine artery

  • The ureters originate from the renal pelvis at the ureteropelvic junction, descending along the anterior surface of the psoas major in the retroperitoneal space. At the sacroiliac joints, they enter the pelvic cavity, crossing the pelvic brim and bifurcation of the common iliac arteries. They travel down the lateral pelvic walls within the pelvic cavity, turning anteromedially at the ischial spines. As they approach the bladder, the ureters obliquely pierce its lateral aspect, creating a one-way valve to prevent back-flow. Notably, at this point, the ureter lies beneath the uterine artery.

Option B: The  mucosa of the fallopian tube is lined by ciliated cells

  • The ultra-structure of the uterine tubes facilitates the movement of the female gamete:
  • The inner mucosa is lined with ciliated columnar epithelial cells and peg cells (non-ciliated secretory cells). They waft the ovum towards the uterus and supply it with nutrients.
  • Smooth muscle layer contracts to assist with the transportation of the ova and sperm. Muscle is sensitive to sex steroids, and thus peristalsis is greatest when estrogen levels are high.

Option D:  External iliac artery lies superior to the ovarian fossa

  • Ovarian fossa is bound superiorly by external iliac artery and vein, anteriorly by broad ligament, posteriorly by ureter, internal iliac artery, and vein, inferiorly by obturator nerve and vessels

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a 7-day-old infant who has bilious vomiting, significant abdominal distention, absent bowel sounds, and an abdominal X-ray indicating the presence of multiple gas-filled loops?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Malrotation of gut:

  • The clinical presentation of bilious vomiting, gross abdominal distention, absent bowel sounds, and an X-ray abdomen showing multiple gas-filled loops is consistent with malrotation of the gut.
  • Malrotation is a congenital condition where the intestines do not rotate and fixate properly during fetal development, leading to abnormal positioning and potential complications such as volvulus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hirschsprung disease: Hirschsprung disease is characterized by a lack of ganglion cells in the distal bowel, leading to obstruction and failure to pass meconium. It does not typically present with bilious vomiting and gas-filled loops on an X-ray.

Option B - Congenital Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Congenital Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is a condition characterized by hypertrophy and narrowing of the pyloric sphincter, causing projectile nonbilious vomiting. It does not typically present with gas-filled loops on an X-ray.

Option C - Duodenal atresia: Duodenal atresia is a congenital condition where there is complete or partial obstruction of the duodenum. It typically presents with bilious vomiting, but the X-ray findings may show a "double bubble" sign rather than gas-filled loops throughout the abdomen

questions.text: A farmer presents with a lesion on his arm after working with cattle on his farm. Gram staining of a sample from the lesion reveals gram-positive rods with square ends and central spores. What is the most likely organism causing this lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C- Bacillus anthracis:

  • Bacillus anthracis is the causative agent of anthrax, which commonly affects individuals exposed to infected animals such as cattle.
  • The characteristic gram-positive rods with square ends and central spores, known as "boxcar" appearance, are typical of Bacillus anthracis.
  • The clinical presentation of a lesion with central necrosis, erythema, and raised borders is consistent with cutaneous anthrax, often seen in individuals handling infected animal products.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Brucella abortus: Brucella species are gram-negative bacteria responsible for brucellosis, a zoonotic disease transmitted from animals to humans. The gram-staining appearance and clinical presentation of brucellosis, such as fever, arthralgia, and hepatosplenomegaly, differ significantly from the findings in the presented scenario.

Option B- Pseudomonas aeruginosa: This gram-negative bacterium is known for causing opportunistic infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

Option D- Bacillus cereus: Bacillus cereus is a gram-positive, spore-forming bacterium that can cause food poisoning after consumption of Chinese fried rice. It does not produce skin lesions.

questions.text: A group of students was studying vitamin deficiencies. They discussed symptoms like dermatitis, dementia, diarrhea, and death. Which deficiency presents with the above symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Niacin deficiency:

Niacin deficiency

  • It gives rise to Pellagra
  • Pellagra is a disease of 4D's
    1. Diarrhea
    2. Dermatitis: Photosensitivity, rashes on sun-exposed areas like Casel's necklace (hyperpigmented rash in the neck area)
    3. Dementia (early onset)
    4. Death
  •  Pellagra like rash can be seen in metabolic disorders like Hartnup disease (impaired transport of neutral amino acid)

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Thiamine deficiency:

  • Predominantly, it is due to intake of polished rice, GI, or liver disease
  • In thiamine deficiency: Beri-Beri
  • Wet Beri-Beri: There can be features of congestive cardiac failure like edema, respiratory distress
  • Dry Beri-Beri: Neurological features like irritability, weakness of lower limbs, DTRs (Deep tendon reflexes) may be diminished.

Option C - Riboflavin deficiency

  • Riboflavin deficiency can cause
    • Glossitis
    • Cheilosis: Inflammation of lips
    • Angular stomatitis: Painful lesions near the angle of the mouth
    • Seborrheic dermatitis along the nasolabial folds
    • Photophobia

Option D - Biotin deficiency:

  • Biotin deficiency can cause
    • Alopecia
    • Skin rashes like periorificial scaly dermatitis
    • Conjunctivitis
    • Glossitis
    • Anorexia, vomiting
    • Neurological manifestations: Developmental delay or seizures

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the surgical emergency room with a high-speed road traffic injury sustained 4 hours earlier. He has severe shortness of breath at the time of the presentation. On examination, his blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg, and his heart rate is 100 beats per minute with an oxygen saturation of 85% at room air. The breath sounds are reduced on the left side. His jugular venous pulse (JVP) is also elevated. A chest x-ray is done, which is shown in the picture below. Which of the following statement is correct about this condition?

choices.text: The trachea has deviated to the affected side of the chest
The best investigation for diagnosis is a non-contrast CT scan
The treatment of choice is the insertion of intercostal drainage in 2nd intercostal space
The best X-ray film for diagnosis is a chest X-ray lateral view

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - The best investigation for diagnosis is a non-contrast CT scan:

  • Based on the history of road traffic accident, symptoms of shortness of breath with hypotension and tachycardia associated with raised JVP, and the image shown, the most likely diagnosis is left-sided tension pneumothorax.
  • The gold standard investigation for its diagnosis is the non-contrast CT scan.
  • Pneumothorax is characterised by the presence of air in the pleural cavity, which results in defective oxygenation and ventilation.
  • Tension pneumothorax is characterised by low blood pressure and low pO2.
  • On examination, breath sounds are reduced or absent on the affected side of the chest, and the trachea deviates towards the better side.
  • The thorax may also be hyper-resonant on percussion, and jugular venous distention and tachycardia may also be present.
  • Symptoms may include chest pain, dyspnea, anxiety, fatigue
  • Treatment includes:
    • Oxygen supplementation
    • Needle decompression followed by tube thoracostomy.
    • Treatment of tension pneumothorax is urgent needle decompression by inserting a large-bore needle into the 2nd intercostal space in the midclavicular line, followed by chest drain insertion immediately into the 5th intercostal space in the triangle of safety.
    • Triangle of safety: anterior border of the latissimus dorsi, the lateral border of the pectoralis major muscle, a line superior to the horizontal level of the nipple
Type Etiology
Primary spontaneous pneumothorax (PSP) No underlying lung disease (but blebs/bullae commonly present)
Secondary spontaneous pneumothorax (SSP) Associated with underlying lung disease (e.g., chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, cystic fibrosis, AIDS with emphysema)
Traumatic iatrogenic pneumothorax Related to trauma to the thorax Secondary to transthoracic or transbronchial lung biopsy (10% risk), central venous catheterization, supraclavicular nerve block

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The trachea has deviated to the affected side of the chest:

  • As the patient is diagnosed with tension pneumothorax, the trachea deviates towards the better side and opposite to the affected side.
  • Therefore, this is not the correct option.

Option C - The treatment of choice is the insertion of intercostal drainage in 2nd intercostal space:

  • In tension pneumothorax, the treatment of choice is inserting a chest drain in the 5th intercostal space and not the 2nd intercostal space.
  • Initially, needle decompression is done, followed by chest drain insertion.

Option D - The best X-ray film for diagnosis is a chest X-ray lateral view:

  • The best X-ray film for diagnosis is chest X-ray AP view.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a known history of type 2 diabetes presents to the emergency department with complaints of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain for the past 12 hours. She appears lethargic but is oriented to time, place, and person. After further assessment, DKA is diagnosed with moderate dehydration. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Administer subcutaneous insulin and continue oral hydration
Administer 10-20 ml/kg of 0.9% normal saline over 20-30 minutes
Start continuous IV insulin infusion at 0.05-0.1 unit/kg/hr before IV fluids

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Administer 10-20 ml/kg of 0.9% normal saline over 20-30 minutes:

  • The patient's presentation with moderate DKA and minimal dehydration warrants rapid fluid resuscitation.
  • The initial fluid of choice is 0.9% normal saline.
  • Administering isotonic saline helps improve intravascular volume and corrects electrolyte imbalances.
  • After initial fluid resuscitation, continuous IV insulin infusion and electrolyte replacement (including potassium) are the next steps in DKA management.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Administer subcutaneous insulin and continue oral hydration:

  • Administering subcutaneous insulin and continuing oral hydration is the treatment approach when the patient presents with DKA with minimal dehydration.

Option C - Critical observations/monitoring:

  • Hourly blood glucose, hourly fluid input and output, and hourly neurological status are done after insulin administration and fluid correction.

Option D - Start continuous IV insulin infusion at 0.05-0.1 unit/kg/hr before IV fluids

  • Continuous IV insulin infusion should not be started before IV fluids.
  •

questions.text: Which mineral is associated with the functioning of carbonic anhydrase?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Zinc:

Zinc is an essential mineral that plays a crucial role in the activity of carbonic anhydrase, an enzyme involved in the conversion of carbon dioxide (CO2) and water (H2O) to carbonic acid (H2CO3) in various tissues and cells of the body.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Iron: Iron is not directly linked to the activity of carbonic anhydrase. It primarily functions in oxygen transport and storage as a component of hemoglobin in red blood cells.

Option C - Calcium: While calcium plays important roles in various physiological processes such as bone health, muscle contraction, and nerve function, it is not directly associated with carbonic anhydrase activity.

Option D - Potassium: Similar to calcium, potassium is not directly linked to the activity of carbonic anhydrase. Potassium is an essential mineral involved in maintaining proper cell function, nerve transmission, and fluid balance.

questions.text: In bullous impetigo, which of the following is the primary target?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Desmoglein-1 (DSG1):

  • In bullous impetigo, the primary target is desmoglein-1 (DSG1). Staphylococcus aureus produces exfoliative toxins, particularly exfoliative toxin A (ETA), which specifically targets and cleaves desmoglein-1. This leads to the separation of keratinocytes within the epidermis, resulting in the formation of bullae.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Desmoglein-3 (DSG3): It is not the primary target in bullous impetigo. Although desmoglein-3 is involved in autoimmune blistering disorders like pemphigus vulgaris, it is not the primary target in bullous impetigo.

Option C - Epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR): It is not the primary target in bullous impetigo. EGFR is a receptor involved in cell signaling pathways and is not directly implicated in the pathogenesis of bullous impetigo.

Option D – Fibronectin: It is not the primary target in bullous impetigo. Fibronectin is an extracellular matrix protein involved in cell adhesion and wound healing processes but is not specifically targeted in bullous impetigo.

questions.text: Which of the following human papillomavirus (HPV) types is associated with the development of numerous warts, as well as a condition known as Tree man syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - HPV 5:

  • HPV 5 is associated with the development of numerous warts and a condition called Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis (also known as "Tree man Syndrome"). This rare genetic disorder is characterized by a susceptibility to HPV infections, leading to the development of extensive warts on the skin. It is caused by a chromosomal defect on chromosome 17. The term "Tree man Syndrome" refers to the appearance of wart-like growths on the skin that can resemble the texture of tree bark.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - HPV 16:

  • HPV 16 is considered a high-risk type of HPV and is associated with the development of genital and oral carcinomas, especially cervical cancer. It is not linked to the specific characteristics mentioned in the scenario.

Option B - HPV 18:

  • HPV 18 is another high-risk type of HPV that is associated with an increased risk of genital and oral carcinomas, especially cervical cancer. It is not related to the features described for "Tree man Syndrome" or numerous warts.

Option D - HPV 6:

  • Low risk infection causes-
    • Warts in vocal cord
    • Results in Laryngeal Papillomatosis, showing voice change
    • Genital warts are Condyloma Acuminatum while Condyloma lata is seen in secondary syphilis

questions.text: Which local anesthetic can be administered via the intravenous route?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lidocaine:

  • Lidocaine is a commonly used local anesthetic with a relatively fast onset of action.
  • It is frequently employed for intravenous regional anesthesia (IVRA), also known as Bier's block.
  • Lidocaine is suitable for short-duration surgical procedures, and its use allows for regional anesthesia of the limb.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Bupivacaine:

  • Bupivacaine is a long-acting local anesthetic commonly used for various regional anesthesia techniques.
  • Bupivacaine is more commonly utilized for epidural anesthesia, peripheral nerve blocks, and spinal anesthesia.

Option C - Ropivacaine:

  • Ropivacaine is another long-acting local anesthetic similar to bupivacaine.
  • While it is used for various regional anesthesia techniques, it is not typically administered through the intravenous route for IVRA.

Option D - Tetracaine:

  • Tetracaine is a long-acting local anesthetic belonging to the ester class.
  • Used mostly for topical anesthesia

questions.text: Bacillus Anthrax is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Gram-positive rods with square ends:

  • Bacillus anthracis, the bacterium responsible for anthrax, is a Gram-positive bacterium that appears as rods under a microscope. These rods have square or boxy ends arranged in a chain, giving a bamboo stick or box car appearance.

Incorrect Options:
Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following endocrine effects is associated with the use of lithium?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A: Hypothyroidism

  • Lithium is known to increase the risk of hypothyroidism, especially in women and those with rapid cycling.
  • Regular monitoring of thyroid function is important in individuals taking lithium to detect and manage any potential thyroid-related issues.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Hyperglycemia: Lithium is not typically associated with hyperglycemia or elevated blood sugar levels.

Option C - Hypernatremia: Lithium does not cause hypernatremia, which is characterized by high levels of sodium in the blood.

Option D - Hypercalcemia: Lithium does not cause hypercalcemia, which is characterized by high levels of calcium in the blood.

questions.text: Which of the following activates the Alternative pathway of Complement system?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - IgA:

  • The Alternative pathway of the complement system is activated by IgA

Incorrect Options:

Option A & D- Immune complex(Ag-Ab) lgM & IgG):

  • Immune complex(Ag-Ab) lgM and IgG activate the Classical pathway of the Complement system

Option B - Microbial organisms:

  • Microbial organism activate the MBL pathway of the complement system

questions.text:
What are the contents of the falx cerebra?


	Superior sagittal sinus
	Inferior sagittal sinus
	Straight sinus
	Anterior sinus
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 1, 2, and 3:

1. Superior sagittal sinus

2. Inferior sagittal sinus

3. Straight sinus

  • The falx cerebri is a sickle-shaped vertical fold of dura that begins anteriorly at the crista galli and winds around the corpus callosum between the two cerebral hemispheres to reach the falcon-tentorial junction on the superior aspect of the tentorium cerebelli. It is located in the longitudinal fissure between the cerebral hemispheres, and the corpus callosum is immediately inferior to the free.
  • Straight sinus runs along the line of attachment of falx cerebri to tentorium cerebelli.
    • The inferior sagittal sinus lies in the free edge of the falx cerebri.
    • The sphenoparietal sinus lies along the Posterior edge of the lesser wing of the sphenoid bone.
  • The cavernous sinus lies on each side of the sella turcica and the body of the sphenoid bone.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - All are present:

  • Statements 1, 2, and 3 are in falx cerebri as described above.

Statement 4: Superior petrosal sinus.

  • The Tentorium cerebellum is an extension of the dura mater that separates the cerebrum from the cerebellum and the brainstem. The superior petrosal sinus runs from the posterior end of the cavernous sinus to the transverse sinus along the attached margin of the tentorium cerebella.

Option C - Only 1, 2, and 4:

Falx cerebri contains.

  • 1-Superior sagittal sinus.
  • 2- Inferior sagittal sinus.
  • But not 4, which is superior petrosal sinus.

Option D - Only 1 and 3:

  • Statements 1, 2, and 3 are part of the flax cerebrum and not only the 1 and 3 statements.

questions.text: Identify the logo
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Integrated Child Development Services:

  • Target: 0-6 years.
  • Provides 
    • Supplementary nutrition
    • Non formal education
    • Immunization services
    • Health checkups 
    • Referral services
  • Pregnant women and adolescent girls are also benefited.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, C and D are incorrect due to the above given reasons

questions.text: A 59-year-old male with untreated chronic lymphocytic leukemia presents with breathlessness and milky fluid on thoracocentesis, indicating thoracic duct blockage. The clinician suspects the blockage occurs at the level where the thoracic duct crosses from the right to the left side. What level represents this blockage?
questions.solution:
Option A: T5

  • The thoracic duct is the largest lymphatic vessel of the body.
  • Malignancies are a common cause of blockage of the thoracic duct and non-traumatic chylothorax.
  • The thoracic duct is a continuation of the upper end of the cisterna chyli at the lower border of T12.
  • It enters the thorax through the aortic opening of the diaphragm.
  • It ascends through the posterior mediastinum.
  • It crosses from the right to the left side at the level of T5.
  • It then runs in the superior mediastinum along the oesophagus and reaches the neck.
  • From there, it arches laterally at the level of C7.
  • It then descends in front of the first part of the left subclavian artery and opens into the junction of the left subclavian and left internal jugular veins.

Option B: T6

  • The thoracic duct crosses from right to left at T5 and not T6.

Option C: T10

  • T10 level does not represent any important anatomic level for the thoracic duct.

Option D: T12

  • T12 represents the level of origin of hte thoracic duct from the cisterna chyli.

questions.text: What is the enzyme defect if a child with anemia, thrombocytopenia, bony pain, and hepatosplenomegaly shows a "crumpled tissue paper" appearance on light microscopy of bone marrow aspirate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Beta- glucosidase:

  • Gaucher disease, caused by a defect in β-glucosidase (glucocerebrosidase), leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide (glucocerebroside) within macrophages.
  • These macrophages, engorged with glucosylceramide, are known as Gaucher cells.
  • The accumulation affects the bone marrow and spleen, leading to anemia (due to impaired RBC production and increased destruction) and thrombocytopenia (due to impaired platelet production and increased destruction).
  • Gaucher cells have a characteristic appearance, often described as having a "crumpled tissue paper" look. This is due to the accumulation of glucosylceramide in the cytoplasm of macrophages, forming fibril-like structures.

​​​​​Incorrect Options:

Option B - Sphingomyelinase:

  • Niemann-Pick disease, a condition similar to Gaucher disease, results from a deficiency in sphingomyelinase.
  • Its bone marrow findings involve foamy histiocytes with lipid-filled cytoplasm, not the "crumpled tissue paper" appearance seen in Gaucher disease.

Option C - Hexosaminidase:

  • Tay-Sachs disease:Tay-Sachs disease, characterized by hexosaminidase deficiency, doesn't typically cause anemia, thrombocytopenia, or bone pain.
  • Its bone marrow findings may show an "onion skin" appearance, not "crumpled tissue paper" as in Gaucher disease.

Option D - Glucose 6-phosphatase:

  • Von Gierke disease, due to glucose6-phosphatase deficiency, may lead to hepatosplenomegaly and bone pain but not anemia or thrombocytopenia.
  • Its bone marrow findings lack the "crumpled tissue paper" appearance seen in Gaucher disease.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with enlarged hands and feet, coarse facial features, and a protruding jaw. What could one of the radiological findings in this patient?

choices.text: Salt and pepper appearance in the skull
Concavity of bones due to subperiosteal resorption

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Spade phalanx:

  • The clinical presentation of a 28-year-old male with enlarged hands and feet, coarse facial features, and a protruding jaw is indicative of acromegaly, a condition often associated with excess growth hormone secretion. In acromegaly, the spade phalanx is a characteristic radiological finding, referring to the enlargement and widening of the distal phalanges of the fingers, resembling the shape of a spade.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Salt and pepper appearance in the skull: This radiological finding is typically associated with hyperparathyroidism, not acromegaly. It presents as a speckled appearance in the skull due to multiple lytic lesions.

Option C - Concavity of bones due to subperiosteal resorption: This feature is more characteristic of hyperparathyroidism, not acromegaly. Hyperparathyroidism leads to bone resorption, causing a concave appearance.

Option D - Brown tumor: Brown tumors are due to abnormal bone metabolism in hyperparathyroidism. These lesions are formed from the replacement of the resorbed bone with fibrovascular tissue and giant cells. There is also hemorrhage and hemosiderin deposition.

questions.text: A 31-year-old female, P1L1, underwent a routine pap smear, which was reported as CIN III (High-Grade Squamous Intraepithelial Lesion/ HSIL). The colposcopy showed an area of abnormal cells around her cervix. What will be the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option:

Option D: Colposcopy biopsy

  • A colposcopy is recommended if cervical screening finds cell HPV-induced cell changes.
  • These dysplastic cells can turn into cervical cancer cells.
  • Colposcopy is a procedure that examines the cervix for abnormal tissue and takes a biopsy if needed.
  • If CIN III is found, the next step is a colposcopy-directed biopsy for tissue diagnosis and to plan further management

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Trachelectomy

  • Surgical removal of the cervix, is called trachelectomy.
  • Trachelectomy is done in younger women with early cervix cancer (with a tumor no larger than 2-3 centimeters).
  • Trachelectomy need not be done in premalignant lesions in a young female unless a biopsy proves invasive carcinoma.

Option B: Hysterectomy

  • A hysterectomy is not done for CIN III unless a biopsy proves cancer

Option C: Conization

  • Conization of the cervix is defined as the excision of a cone-shaped or cylindrical wedge from the cervix uteri that includes the transformation zone and all or a portion of the endocervical canal.
  • Conization is not done in a young patient with an incomplete family as it causes
    • Short cervix→ cervical incompetence → abortions
    • Stenosis→ Infertility

questions.text: A study is conducted to assess the contraceptive efficacy of a new method among women aged 18-35 years in a rural community. The researchers followed up with the participants for  2.5 years. During this period, there were 23 accidental pregnancies recorded among 390 women who used the new method. Which among the following is the correct representation of the Pearl Index?

choices.text: Pearl index = No. of accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure × 1200
Pearl index = No. of accidental pregnancies / Total years of exposure × 1200
Pearl index = No. of accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure × 1400
Pearl index = No. of accidental pregnancies / Total years of exposure × 1400

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pearl index = No. of accidental pregnancies / Total months of exposure × 1200:

  • This is the correct representation of the Pearl Index.
  • The Pearl Index is a measure of contraceptive efficacy that indicates the number of pregnancies that occur per 100 woman-years of exposure while using a particular contraceptive method.
  • It is often used to compare the effectiveness of different contraceptive methods.
  • It is the most commonly used technique to evaluate the effectiveness of contraceptives.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, D: These formulae are inaccurate regarding the Pearl index.

questions.text: A father brings his 3-month-old baby boy to the OPD because of a lack of social smile. He said that he and his wife read articles online that babies of this age should be able to smile. On examination, there are no abnormalities. The pediatrician reassured the father and advised him to wait for a specific time. What is the upper age limit at which a social smile can be attained?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 6 months:

  • The upper limit of age at which a social smile can be attained is 6 months
  • Normally it is attained at 2-3 months

Incorrect Options:

Option B: 8 months: At 8 months, the baby acquires the social skill of object permanence.

Option C: 9 months: At 9 months, the baby can wave bye-bye.

Option D: 10 months: At 10 months, the baby plays peek-a-boo.

questions.text: Regarding this dose-response curve, which parameter does the drug on the left side of the log DRC indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - More potent:

  • A drug's potency is determined by its ability to produce the same effect as another drug but at a lower dose.
  • Potency is assessed by the position on the dose-response curve (DRC), where drugs on the left side are more potent.
    • Additionally, efficacy, or the maximum effect of a drug, is indicated by the height of the curve, while slope reflects the drug's safety.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - More safe:

  • Drug safety is evaluated through the therapeutic index, where a higher value signifies a safer drug.

Option C - More efficient:

  • A drug's efficiency is gauged by the height of its curve on the DRC; the higher the peak, the more efficient the drug is perceived to be.

Option D - Lower therapeutic index:

  • The therapeutic index (TI) is calculated as TD50/ED50, with TD50 representing the median toxic dose and ED50 the median effective dose.
  • A lower TI indicates a higher risk, necessitating careful dose monitoring.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female named Sarah recently survived a severe car accident. She was trapped in the wreckage for several hours before being rescued. Since the accident, she has been experiencing recurrent distressing dreams about the event, avoiding driving or even being near cars, and constantly feeling on edge. Which of the following best describes Sarah's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C : Hypervigilance and avoidance behavior.

  • Based on the scenario, Sarah is experiencing several symptoms consistent with Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). These symptoms include recurrent distressing dreams about the traumatic event (intrusion symptoms), avoiding driving or cars (avoidance), and constantly feeling on edge (hypervigilance). Therefore, option C is the most appropriate choice that reflects Sarah's symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Anterograde amnesia: Anterograde amnesia pertains to a specific type of memory impairment, rather than the set of symptoms she is experiencing.

Option B - Social withdrawal and isolation: While avoidance behavior is present in PTSD, it specifically refers to avoiding reminders of the traumatic event, not necessarily social withdrawal or isolation.

Option D - Excessive sleepiness and fatigue: While sleep disturbances can occur in PTSD, the scenario does not mention excessive sleepiness and fatigue as primary symptoms experienced by Sarah.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with liver damage. The picture depicts the patient having their eyes examined. Which of the following subsequent factors is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Options A - Copper

  • In Wilson's disease, there is a defect in the transport of copper, leading to its buildup in the liver and subsequent release into the bloodstream.
  • Excess copper is then deposited in various organs, including the eyes.
  • The copper deposition in the eyes can cause a characteristic finding called Kayser-Fleischer rings, which are golden-brown to greenish-brown rings seen around the cornea.
  • The accumulation of copper in the liver can damage the liver, resulting in hepatocellular dysfunction, inflammation, and fibrosis.
  • This can manifest as hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), jaundice, fatigue, and other symptoms of liver dysfunction.

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B - Glucose is not responsible for the condition described. Glucose is a simple sugar and the body’s primary energy source. While liver damage can occur due to various causes, glucose itself is not a direct factor responsible for liver damage in this scenario.
  • Option C - Galactose is not responsible for the condition described. Galactose is a sugar found in milk and dairy products. Galactosemia is a rare genetic disorder characterized by the inability to metabolize galactose, leading to its accumulation in the body.
  • Option D -. Mannose is not responsible for the condition described. Mannose is a sugar that plays a role in glycoprotein synthesis and cellular communication.

questions.text:
Below are images of different types of surgical knots. Match them with their corresponding names. 


	
		
			
			1.
			
			
			a. Granny knot
			
		
		
			
			2. 
			
			
			b. Square knot
			
		
		
			
			3.
			
			
			c. Surgeon's knot
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- 1-c, 2-a, 3-b:

  • Surgeon’s knot: It consists of two throws. There are two wraps in the first throw and one in the second, and crossing occurs in each throw.
  • Granny knot: This knot, also called a pseudo square knot, involves two throws taken without crossing. One end is above, and the other is below. The granny knot is more prone to slip and is relatively unstable.
  • Square knot: This knot, also known as the reef knot, consists of two throws, and crossing is done in each throw. It is relatively secure.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man with a family history of MEN2 presents with an intermittent and severe headache, palpitations, and excessive sweating. A palpable mass is detected in his upper left abdomen during the physical examination and his blood pressure is 180/100 mmHg. What is the investigation of choice for this patient?

choices.text: Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Plasma fractionated metanephrine
level:

  • This clinical scenario is suggestive of a pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-secreting tumor typically arising from the adrenal medulla. Pheochromocytomas can cause paroxysmal hypertension, severe headaches, palpitations, and sweating. The presence of a palpable mass in the left upper abdomen further supports this diagnosis.
  • Measurement of plasma-free metanephrines is the most sensitive and specific initial test for detecting pheochromocytomas. Plasma-free metanephrines (metanephrine and normetanephrine) are the breakdown products of catecholamines and are elevated in the setting of a pheochromocytoma.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen: It is a valuable imaging modality to localize the tumor once the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma is confirmed. However, it is not the initial investigation of choice.

Option B - A 24-hour urine collection for vanillylmandelic acid (VMA): It is an older test that measures the breakdown product of epinephrine and norepinephrine. Although it can be used in the workup of pheochromocytoma, it is less sensitive and specific compared to plasma-free metanephrines.

Option D - MRI of the abdomen: It can provide detailed anatomical information about the tumor and surrounding structures. However, it is not the initial investigation of choice in this scenario.

questions.text: A 23-year-old pregnant woman at 9 weeks of gestation came to the clinic for an antenatal checkup. On examination, vitals were normal. The doctor recommended Covishield vaccination since there was a pandemic of COVID-19. Which of the following is the interval between the two doses of Covishield vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 12-16 weeks:

  • The interval between the two doses of Covishield is 12-16 weeks
  • COVID vaccination can be safely given to all pregnant women and breastfeeding mothers

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D:

  • These do not indicate the correct interval between the two doses of Covishield vaccine

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with increased risk for the complication, shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C:

  • The image of the placenta shows vessels from the umbilical cord traveling within the membrane unsupported (velamentous cord), while the USG image also suggests vessels from the cord near the fetal presenting part in the lower segment.

  • Such findings are suggestive of velamentous cord with vasa previa.

Vasa previa

  • Presence of velamentous cord at the level of Internal Os.
  • Rupture of the membranes involving the overlying vessels lead to vaginal bleeding.
  • As it is entirely fetal blood, this may result in fetal exsanguination and even death in more than 50% of cases.
  • Diagnosis is best made by doppler

Incorrect Options:

Option A:

  • There is no increased risk of PROM.

Option B:

  • Vasa previa may be associated with increased risk of PPH given its association with placenta previa, but this is less likely a complication than fetal exsanguination.

Option D:

  • There is no increased risk of fetal malformations with vasa previa.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male presents with a two-month history of progressive cough, dyspnea on exertion, and night sweats. He also complains of weight loss. A chest X-ray is given in the image. Skin examination shows painful nodules on the shin. Further evaluation reveals elevated calcium levels in his blood work.

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Sarcoidosis:

  • The patient's clinical presentation aligns with sarcoidosis, a multisystem inflammatory disease characterized by non-caseating granuloma formation in various organs.
  • The images given depict erythema nodosum (painful nodules on the shins) and pulmonary fibrosis (chest X-ray).
  • Clinical features of sarcoidosis: 
    • Progressive cough, dyspnea, and stridor due to bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
    • Night sweats, weight loss 
    • Skin: Lupus Pernio and Erythema nodosum
    • CNS: lymphocytic meningitis, optic neuritis, central diabetes insipidus
    • Ocular: uveitis, Sicca Syndrome 
    • Parotid gland involvement can lead to facial diplegia
    • Cardiac: tachyarrhythmias, ischemic heart disease, pulmonary artery hypertension
    • Liver: granulomatous hepatitis
    • Bone marrow: lymphopenia 
    • Endocrine: hypercalcemia due to 1-alpha hydroxylase enzyme in granulomas
  • Lofgren syndrome is a variant with erythema nodosum, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, and arthritis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Tuberculosis (TB): TB may present with symptoms like cough, night sweats, weight loss, and lung involvement. However, in sarcoidosis, non-caseating granulomas are formed, and specific skin manifestations like Erythema Nodosum differentiate it from TB.

Option B - Lung Cancer: Lung cancer can present with cough, dyspnea, weight loss, and night sweats. However, the presence of bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and painful shin nodules (Erythema Nodosum) suggests a different diagnosis, like sarcoidosis.

Option D - Pulmonary Embolism: Pulmonary embolism is a condition where a blood clot blocks the pulmonary artery. While it can cause dyspnea, it does not present with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy or skin nodules.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs is synthetic heparin which is unsafe in renal disease has longest t1/2?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Idraparinux:

  • Idraparinux is synthetic ULMWH (1500KDa)
  • Pentasaccharide
  • Other drug is Fondaparinux
  • MOA: inhibition of clotting factor X.
  • It has the longest t1/2
  • Unsafe in renal failure patients.
  • ROA: Subcutaneous.
  • aPTT monitoring is required in case of Renal failure
    • Monitor factor Xa assay
  • Uses:
    • Prophylaxis of DVT/PE
      • ICU patients
    • Af with MS
    • After knee and hip surgery

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D - Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin:

  • These drugs are Fractionated LMWH.
  • MOA: Inhibition of clotting factors X>>>>II
  • Unsafe in renal failure patient.
  • ROA: Subcutaneous.
  • Uses are same as ULMWH.

questions.text:
Match the following conditions with their respective types of respiratory failure


	
		
			
			1. ARDS
			
			
			a. Respiratory failure type 2
			
		
		
			
			2. Status asthmaticus
			
			
			b. Respiratory failure type 4
			
		
		
			
			3. Peri-operative atelectasis
			
			
			c. Respiratory failure type 1
			
		
		
			
			4. Cardiogenic shock
			
			
			d. Respiratory failure type 3
questions.solution:
Correct option: C - 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

1. ARDS

c. Respiratory failure type 1

2. Status asthmaticus

a. Respiratory failure type 2

3. Peri-operative atelectasis

d. Respiratory failure type 3

4. Cardiogenic shock

b. Respiratory failure type 4

Respiratory Failure

Respiratory Failure

Examples

Management

Type I

ARDS, CHF
  • Low volume ventilation
  • Prone position and neuromuscular blockage

Type II

Status asthmaticus, acute exacerbation of COPD
  • Tight fitting face mask (NIV)
  • ET tube with IPPV - If due to diaphragmatic paralysis

Type III

Peri-operative atelectasis
  • O2 supplementation
  • Chest physiotherapy

Type IV

Decreased perfusion of respiratory muscles
  • ET tube with IPPV

Incorrect options: A, B and D - Refer to the above explanation

questions.text: Which among the following is an ultrashort-acting opioid?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Remifentanil:

  • Remifentanil is an ultra-short-acting synthetic opioid with an extremely short duration of action.
  • It is rapidly metabolized by nonspecific Plasma and Tissue esterase, making it suitable for precise control of analgesia during surgery.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Fentanyl:

  • Fentanyl is a potent synthetic opioid with a relatively rapid onset of action. However, it is not classified as an ultra-short-acting opioid. Its duration of action is relatively short to intermediate.

Option B - Sufentanil:

  • Sufentanil is a highly potent synthetic opioid, more potent than fentanyl. While it has a rapid onset, it is not considered an ultra-short-acting opioid. It does have a shorter duration of action compared to some opioids, making it suitable for certain surgical procedures.

Option D - None of the above

questions.text: Which statement accurately identifies an exception within the Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) program?

choices.text: Free diet to mothers during their hospital stay
Free transport for patients from home to the hospital and vice versa
Free treatment for sick infants up to 6 months of age?

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Free treatment of sick infants up to 6 months of age: 

  • However, the program does not offer free treatment for sick infants up to 6 months of age.
  • Services provided under Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) program

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C accurately describe components of the Janani Shishu Suraksha Karyakram (JSSK) program, which aims to provide free maternal and neonatal health services.

questions.text: What is the likely reason for the food poisoning experienced by the worker in the groundnut factory who consumed spoiled groundnuts that were stored in the facility?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D- Aflatoxins :

  • Given that the worker consumed stale groundnuts stored in the factory, which are susceptible to aflatoxin contamination, aflatoxins are the most probable cause of food poisoning in this case.
