The other options are incorrect as they are unrelated to groundnuts or do not explain the specific symptoms of food poisoning experienced by the worker.

Incorrect Options:

Option A. Beta oxalyl amino alanine(BOAA), a neurotoxic compound in certain plants like Lathyrus sativus seeds, leads to Lathyrism when consumed excessively over time. It is not associated with groundnuts.

Option B.Smoke inhalation While exposure to smoke may cause health problems, it does not explain the specific symptoms of food poisoning experienced by the worker.

Option C. Sanguinarine is an alkaloid found in certain plants, including bloodroot and other members of the Papaveraceae family.

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory findings are most likely, if a child has a disorder of fatty acid oxidation?

choices.text: Hypoglycemia, acidosis, and elevated urine dicarboxylic acids
Acidosis and elevated urine reducing substances
Hypoglycemia, acidosis, and elevated serum leucine, isoleucine, and valine
Hepatomegaly, elevated serum liver enzymes, and elevated tyrosine

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hypoglycemia, acidosis, and elevated urine dicarboxylic acids:

  • Symptoms of metabolic diseases often emerge after initial feedings, exposing the baby to non-metabolizable nutrients.
  • Inborn errors of metabolism manifest with symptoms such as vomiting, lethargy progressing to coma, hypoglycemia, acidosis, and hyperammonemia.
  • Disorders of fatty acid oxidation lead to carnitine depletion, failure of fatty acid oxidation, and excretion of dicarboxylic acid intermediates.
  • Medium-chain fatty acid oxidation deficiencies may present after illness with calorie deprivation in children aged 2 to 6 years.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Acidosis and elevated urine reducing substances:

  • Galactosemia worsens on exposure to lactose-containing formula, causing hypoglycemia, liver failure, and excretion of urinary sugars (reducing substances).

Options C - Hypoglycemia, acidosis, elevated serum leucine, isoleucine, and valine:

  • Tyrosinemia and maple syrup urine disease worsen after protein feeding, causing elevated levels of specific amino acids and associated complications.

Option D - Alkalosis and elevated serum ammonia:

  • Urea cycle disorders worsen with fasting or protein feeding, leading to excess ammonia production and respiratory alkalosis.

questions.text: Which of the following stages of NEC has portal vein gas as a feature on abdominal X-rays?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Stage IIB:

  • Stage IIB shows portal vein gas on abdominal X Ray

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Stage IIA:

  • Stage IIA shows Pneumatosis intestinalis (Air in the wall of the intestine).

Option C- Stage IA:

  • Stage IA shows occult blood positive in the stool.

Option D - Stage IB:

  • Stage IB: Fresh blood present in the stool of the baby.

questions.text: A 45 year old male who is a chronic smoker came to the clinic with complaints of painful ankle and knee joints for 2 weeks. On examination, the joints were swollen, red. Serum uric acid levels were examined and the report showed 10 mg/dl. Which of the following is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - NSAIDs:

  • The condition mentioned in the scenario is Acute gout
  • The drug of choice for the treatment of Acute Gout is NSAIDs
  • Gout is characterized by painful,red,swollen ankle and knee joints
  • Serum uric acid level is elevated in Gout
  • The other drugs used for the management of Acute Gout are Oral and IV colchicines, Intra-articular and systemic steroids

Incorrect Options

Option B, C & D:

  • These are the drugs used for the management of Gout
  • But the drug of choice is NSAIDs

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with a history of lower back pain and cyclical dysmenorrhea for the last 12 months. She has been married for the last 4 years and has never conceived. She is referred to the infertility clinic for further evaluation. The patient has regular cycles with dysmenorrhea. Further investigations revealed dark red to bluish vesicles surrounded by flame-like lesions on the peritoneum. Which of the following is the most common site for a lesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Ovary

  • Ovaries are a common site of endometriosis involvement.
  • Ovarian endometriomas, also known as chocolate cysts, can form, leading to cystic masses filled with endometrial tissue.

Sites of Predilection

  • The most common site is the ovary
  • The second most common site is Pouch of Douglas
  • Bowel
  • Lung [periodic hemoptysis] (Vicarious Menstruation)
  • Nose [Periodic epistaxis] (Vicarious Menstruation)
  • Eyes (periodic subconjunctival hemorrhage] (Vicarious Menstruation)

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Fallopian tube

  • It is also a site for endometriosis. However, the more common site is the ovary.
  • Endometriosis in the fallopian tubes may lead to inflammation, scarring, and potential obstruction, impacting fertility.

Option B: Cervix

  • While endometriosis can affect the uterus, it is not the most common site.
  • Endometriosis in the uterus may involve the outer layer (adenomyosis) or other structures, but ovarian involvement is more prevalent.

Option D: Pouch of Douglas

  • The Pouch of Douglas, also known as the rectouterine pouch or cul-de-sac, is the space between the rectum and the back wall of the uterus.
  • It is the 2nd most common site for endometriosis.
  • Endometriosis can involve the Pouch of Douglas, causing pain and adhesions in this area.

questions.text: A 29-year-old female at 37 weeks of gestation presents to the antenatal clinic with complaints of headache and visual disturbances for 3 days. Her BP is 170/100 mmHg. Her urinalysis confirms proteinuria (+3). On Pelvic examination, cervix is found to be soft with 50% effacement, the station is '-2', the pelvis adequate, and the cervical os is 1 cm dilated. Which of the following will be the most appropriate management at this stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Induction of labor

  • This patient with increased BP, headache, and urinary proteinuria suffers from severe preeclampsia.
  • Management involves BP control and planning for delivery.
  • The given patient has a favorable cervix and adequate pelvis.
  • So, labor induction will be the appropriate step at this stage.
  • After giving mgso4 and controlling BP- take for labor induction.

Incorrect Options:

Option A: Observation with monitoring of BP

  • Preeclampsia is a life-threatening disorder that requires active management.
  • Observation and monitoring alone are not sufficient.

Option B: Antihypertensive & wait for spontaneous labor

  • The patient has a favorable cervix and adequate pelvis. Waiting for spontaneous labor is not the ideal management at this stage as termination of pregnancy is indicated for severe pre-eclampsia.

Option D: Cesarean section

  • It will be the preferred option when a normal delivery is impossible, in unfavorable bishops or other obstetric indications for cesarean section.
  • Pre-eclampsia is not an indication for LSCS

questions.text: A pregnant woman in her third trimester came to the antenatal check-up with a positive test report for HBsAg and HBeAg. What is the chance of vertical transmission in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 90%:

  • HBeAg: Marker for replication or infectivity of the virus
  • The patient in the question stem tested positive for HBeAg, which infers that there is an active replication of the HBV and there is a higher chance of transmission.
  • Hence, the mother has a 90% chance of transmitting to the baby during delivery
  • Management:
    • HBIg immunoglobulin to be given within < 12 hrs to the child
    • Hepatitis B vaccine 3 doses (0,6, 10 0r 14 weeks)

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and D:

  • These are incorrect answers, as there is a higher risk of transmission.

questions.text: Identify the lesion shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Wet gangrene: 

  • Wet gangrene is a type of gangrene characterized by tissue necrosis (death) that occurs in a moist or wet environment. It is usually caused by a severe bacterial infection and impaired blood supply to the affected area. The affected tissue appears swollen, discolored (often dark or black), and may have a foul odor. It is commonly seen in the extremities, such as the feet.

  • In the given image, the appearance of the foot with discoloration, swelling, and signs of tissue decay suggests the presence of wet gangrene. The presence of a severe infection and impaired blood supply are consistent with this diagnosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Dry gangrene: Dry gangrene is characterized by tissue death in a dry environment without the presence of infection. It usually occurs due to reduced blood supply to the affected area, leading to tissue necrosis. Dry gangrene often appears black, dry, and shriveled.

Option C - Frostbite: Frostbite refers to tissue injury caused by extreme cold exposure. It occurs when prolonged exposure to freezing temperatures leads to damage to the skin and underlying tissues. Frostbite can cause discoloration, numbness, and blistering of the affected area.

Option D - Ainhum: Ainhum is a rare condition characterized by the progressive constriction and autoamputation of the digits, usually the fifth toe. It typically affects individuals in certain geographical regions and is associated with the formation of a fibrous band around the affected digit.

questions.text: Which of the following radio-isotope has the highest half-life?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Radium-226:

  • Radium-226 has the highest half-life (1600 years). The first radioisotope used in humans was Radium-226. It produces Radon (decay compound), which causes carcinoma of the lungs. It emits alpha, beta, and gamma rays.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cesium-137: Cesium-137 has a half-life of about 30 years.

Option C - Cobalt-60: Cobalt-60 has a half-life of about 5.26 years.

Option D - Fluorine-18: Fluorine-18 has a very short half-life of about 2 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of an immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Arthus reaction:

  • Deposition of circulating immune complexes occurs in type III hypersensitivity.
  • The antigen-antibody (mostly IgG) complexes activates complement, which attracts neutrophils; neutrophils release lysosomal enzymes.
  • It can be associated with vasculitis and systemic manifestations.
  • Arthus reaction is a local subacute immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity reaction. Intradermal injection of antigen into a pre-sensitized (has circulating IgG) individual leads to the immune complex formation in the skin (e.g., enhanced local reaction to a booster vaccination).
  • Serum sickness is the prototypic immune complex disease. Antibodies to foreign proteins are produced and 1–2 weeks later, antibody-antigen complexes form and deposit in tissues, complement activation inflammation and tissue damage (serum C3, C4).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Asthma:

  • Asthma is a classic example of a type I hypersensitivity reaction.
  • IgE are already produced and fixed to mast cells- mast cell degranulation causes the release of mediators.
  • This leads to the later recruitment of inflammatory cells.
  • Resulting in vascular dilation, oedema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, and inflammation.
  • Examples are anaphylaxis; allergies; bronchial asthma (atopic forms)

Option C - Contact dermatitis:

  • Contact dermatitis is an example of a cell-mediated (type IV) hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Two mechanisms, each involving T cells:
    1. Direct cell cytotoxicity: CD8+ cytotoxic T cells kill targeted cells.
    2. Inflammatory reaction: effector CD4+
  • T cells recognize antigens and release inflammation-inducing cytokines.
  • The response does not involve antibodies (vs types I, II, and III).
  • Examples are contact dermatitis (e.g., poison ivy, nickel allergy) & graft-versus-host disease.
  • This principle is used in clinical tests such as purified protein derivatives for tuberculosis infection, patch tests for contact dermatitis & candida skin test for T cell immune function.

Option D - Rheumatic fever:

  • Rheumatic fever is an example of type II hypersensitivity.
  • IgG hypersensitivity reaction is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Antibodies to the M protein of group A streptococcus cross-react with self-antigens, and cross-react with myocardial antigen, due to molecular mimicry.
  • Antibodies bind to cell-surface antigens or extracellular matrix and causecellular destruction, inflammation, and cellular dysfunction.
  • Cellular destruction occurs when a cell is opsonized (coated) by antibodies, leading to either phagocytosis and/or activation of the complement system & natural cell killing (antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity).
  • Examples are autoimmune hemolytic anaemia (including drug-induced form), immune thrombocytopenia, transfusion reactions & hemolytic disease of the newborn.
  • Inflammation is mediated by the binding of antibodies to cell surfaces, activation of the complement system, and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation.
  • Examples are Goodpasture syndrome, rheumatic fever & hyperacute transplant rejection.
  • Cellular dysfunction by antibodies binds to cell-surface receptors, abnormal blockade or activation of the downstream process.
  • Examples are myasthenia gravis, graves disease & pemphigus Vulgaris.

questions.text: As a first-year resident in the Orthopaedics department, you observe a 15-year-old male presenting with frequent fractures every 3 months. Suspecting osteogenesis imperfecta type I, which type of collagen is involved in this disorder?
questions.solution:
Option A: Type I

  • Type I collagen is the most common type and is found in;
    • Bones
    • Fibro-cartilage [atypical cartilage]
    • Dermis [skin]
    • Old scar
  • Type I: Decreased production in osteogenesis imperfecta type I.
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta type I is a genetic disorder that results in skeletal deformities and deformity of bones.
  • The genetic mutation of the COL1A1 gene.
  • ↓ Formation of the hydrogen and disulfide bonds between type I pre-procollagen molecules → ↓ triple helix formation → ↓ synthesis of normal type I collagen → impaired bone matrix formation (osteogenesis).
  • Clinical features are:
    • Delay of growth.
    • Brittle bones, skeletal deformities.
    • Saber shins and bowing of bones.
    • Childbirth fracture.
    • Recurrent fracture from minimal trauma.
    • Deformation atrophy of the ossicles leads to progressive loss of hearing.
    • Lack of dentin leads to dentinogenesis imperfecta, brittle, opalescent teeth.
    • Blue sclerae.

Option B: Type II

  • Type II collagen is found in hyaline & elastic cartilage.

Option C: Type III

  • Type III collagen is found in
    • Lymphoid organs with reticular tissue [liver, spleen, lymph nodes]
    • Healing/Granulation tissue
  • Type III: Deficient in the uncommon, vascular type of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

Option D: Type IV

  • Type IV collagen is found in
    • Basal lamina/membrane
    • Type IV: Under the floor (basement membrane). Defective in Alport syndrome; targeted by autoantibodies in Goodpasture syndrome.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with a history of Parkinson's disease presents to the neurology clinic for a follow-up visit. He has been on levodopa therapy for several months, and the clinician is discussing potential side effects of the medication except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Obesity:

  • Obesity is not typically listed as a side effect of levodopa therapy. While weight changes may occur in patients with Parkinson's disease due to various factors such as changes in appetite, dietary habits, or physical activity levels, obesity itself is not directly caused by levodopa medication.

Incorrect Options

Options A, B, C:

  • Dyskinesia, nausea, and orthostatic hypotension are the side effects of Levodopa

questions.text: Which of the following is a reversible proton pump inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Tenatoprazole:

  •  It does not metabolized by CYP2C19 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not reversible proton pump inhibitors.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with a two-day history of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. He reports feeling extremely thirsty and has been urinating frequently. On examination, his breath has a fruity odor. His blood glucose level is 380 mg/dL (21.1 mmol/L). An arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis is performed. Which of the following ABG findings would be most consistent with the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - pH 7.30, PaCO2 30 mmHg, HCO3- 18 mEq/L:

  • The clinical presentation of nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, fruity breath odor, and elevated blood glucose levels suggests diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a potentially life-threatening complication of uncontrolled diabetes. DKA is characterized by metabolic acidosis resulting from the accumulation of ketone bodies (such as beta-hydroxybutyrate and acetoacetate) due to insulin deficiency and increased gluconeogenesis.
  • In DKA, ABG analysis typically reveals a low pH (acidosis), low bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels due to metabolic acidosis, and low partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) as a compensatory response to increased ventilation and decreased carbon dioxide levels. Option A presents the most consistent ABG findings for DKA, with a pH of 7.30 (normal range 7.35 - 7.45), PaCO2 of 30 mmHg (lower than the normal range of 35-45 mmHg), and HCO3- of 18 mEq/L (lower than the normal range of 22-28 mEq/L).

Incorrect Options:

Option B - pH 7.45, PaCO2 40 mmHg, HCO3- 24 mEq/L: represents a normal pH and ABG values within the reference range, not indicative of DKA.

Option C - pH 7.50, PaCO2 50 mmHg, HCO3- 28 mEq/L: suggests respiratory alkalosis rather than metabolic acidosis seen in DKA.

Option D - pH 7.40, PaCO2 45 mmHg, HCO3- 28 mEq/L: represents a normal pH and ABG values within the reference range, not indicative of DKA.

questions.text: Which of the following criteria is required for the diagnosis of definite Meniere's disease?

choices.text: Presence of episodic vertigo with histopathological confirmation
More than 2 episodes of spontaneous vertigo lasting for more than 20 minutes
One episode of vertigo without documented hearing loss
One definitive episode of vertigo lasting for more than 30 minutes with tinnitus and aural fullness.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B- More than 2 episodes of spontaneous vertigo lasting for more than 20 minutes:

The diagnostic criteria for Definite Meniere's disease include:

  • Two or more definitive episodes of spontaneous vertigo, each lasting 20 minutes or longer.
  • Audiometrically documented hearing loss on at least one occasion.
  • Tinnitus or aural fullness in the affected ear.
  • Other potential causes of these symptoms should be excluded.

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Presence of episodic vertigo with histopathological confirmation:

  • Histopathological confirmation suggests certain Meniere's disease, not definitive.

Option C- One episode of vertigo without documented hearing loss:

  • One isolated episode without documented hearing loss does not fulfill the criteria of definitive Meniere’s disease.

Option D- One definitive episode of vertigo lasting for more than 30 minutes with tinnitus and aural fullness:

  • The correct duration for episodes in the diagnostic criteria is 20 minutes or longer, not 30 minutes. Additionally, having only one episode does not meet the criteria for Meniere's disease.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the hospital after sustaining a severe motorbike collision. On examination, the patient is hemodynamically stable and alert. X-rays show multiple fractures. A whole-body CT shows a bilateral pulmonary contusion with small hemothorax, a renal contusion, and multiple pelvic fractures. Progressively, the patient becomes hemodynamically unstable. Three units of packed erythrocytes are given together with 1 g of tranexamic acid and 1000 ml hydroxyethyl starch. Laboratory parameter analysis from the blood sample drawn at admission confirms coagulopathy associated with moderate metabolic acidosis. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: The patient should be prepared for damage control surgery
The patient should be hemodynamically stable for any operative procedure; hence aggressive resuscitation is recommended
Coagulopathy has to be corrected as a part of resuscitation, and then operative control of hemorrhage & contamination is performed
If hemodynamic stability is achieved, conservative management is enough for this patient

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - The patient should be prepared for damage control surgery:

  • The patient had a severe motorbike collision. He has pulmonary and renal contusions, hemothorax and multiple fractures.
  • Labs confirm coagulopathy and metabolic acidosis.
  • As the patient progressively deteriorates, he should be immediately prepared for damage control surgery.
  • This life-saving surgery is needed to control hemorrhage. Definitive surgery can be performed later.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - The patient should be hemodynamically stable for any operative procedure; hence aggressive resuscitation is recommended:

  • The patient is progressively deteriorating.
  • Immediate surgical intervention is needed to control bleeding and contamination.
  • Aggressive resuscitation will fail as the patient has already developed coagulopathy and metabolic acidosis.
  • This patient is a candidate for damage control surgery.

Option C - Coagulopathy has to be corrected as a part of resuscitation, and then operative control of hemorrhage & contamination is performed:

  • Consumptive coagulopathy leads to death in severely injured patients.
  • Coagulopathy occurs as a part of the lethal triad of death which will not resolve without surgical intervention and control of the bleed.
  • Waiting for surgical intervention increases the risk of mortality.

Option D - If hemodynamic stability is achieved, conservative management is enough for this patient:

  • The patient is progressively becoming hemodynamically unstable.
  • Conservative management is not indicated at this stage.
  • The patient will not survive unless damage control surgery is performed.

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism of action of Allopurinol, and in which condition is its derivative Oxypurinol commonly used?

choices.text: Allopurinol inhibits xanthine oxidase, and Oxypurinol is primarily used in acute gout.
Allopurinol promotes uric acid excretion, and Oxypurinol is commonly used in Chagas disease.
Allopurinol decreases purine synthesis, and Oxypurinol is prescribed primarily for Lesch Nyhan Syndrome.
Allopurinol inhibits xanthine oxidase, and Oxypurinol is given when the patient is allergic to Allopurinol.

questions.solution:
Correct Option (Option 4):

  • Allopurinol inhibits xanthine oxidase, reducing the production of uric acid.
  • Its derivative, oxypurinol, is primarily used when a patient is allergic to allopurinol.
  • Oxypurinol has a similar mechanism of action to allopurinol, as it is the active metabolite of allopurinol, but it can be used as an alternative in patients who cannot tolerate allopurinol due to allergic reactions.

Incorrect Options:

Option 1:

  • Allopurinol inhibits xanthine oxidase, not promoting uric acid excretion.
  • Oxypurinol is not primarily used in acute gout; it is primarily used as an alternative for patients allergic to allopurinol.

Option 2:

  • Allopurinol does not promote uric acid excretion; it inhibits its production by inhibiting xanthine oxidase.
  • Oxypurinol is not commonly used in Chagas disease.

Option 3:

  • Allopurinol does not decrease purine synthesis; it inhibits xanthine oxidase.
  • Oxypurinol is not primarily prescribed for Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome; it is primarily used as an alternative for patients allergic to allopurinol.

questions.text: Which instrument is depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Plain Dissecting Forceps:

  • The instrument depicted in the image is the Plain Dissecting Forceps.
  • These forceps are commonly used in surgery for grasping and holding tissues or delicate structures during dissection procedures.
  • Plain Dissecting Forceps have smooth, non-toothed tips that provide a gentle grip on the tissue without causing damage.
  • They are versatile instruments used in various surgical specialties for tissue manipulation and dissection.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Allis Forceps:

  • Allis Forceps are a type of surgical forceps commonly used for grasping and holding tough tissues or skin during surgical procedures.
  • They have sharp, interlocking teeth that provide a firm grip on the tissue.
  • Allis Forceps are not the instrument depicted in the image, which shows Plain Dissecting Forceps with smooth, non-toothed tips.

Option C - Mosquito Hemostatic Forceps:

  • Mosquito Hemostatic Forceps are commonly used in surgery for clamping small blood vessels or tissue to control bleeding. They have fine, serrated tips that provide a firm grip on the tissue.
  • Mosquito Hemostatic Forceps are not the instrument depicted in the image, which shows Plain Dissecting Forceps with smooth, non-toothed tips.

Option D - Adson Forceps:

  • Adson Forceps, also known as Adson tissue forceps, are a type of surgical forceps with fine, serrated tips commonly used for grasping delicate tissues during surgical procedures.
  • They have small, toothed jaws that provide a firm grip on tissues without causing excessive trauma.
  • Adson Forceps are not the instrument depicted in the image, which shows Plain Dissecting Forceps with smooth, non-toothed tips.

questions.text: Which of the following is the first change to occur in psoriasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A- Supra-papillary thinning:

  • Psoriasis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition with specific histopathological changes. Among the listed options, supra-papillary thinning is the first histopathological change to occur in psoriasis. In the early stages of psoriasis, the epidermis above the papillary dermis starts to thin out, creating a characteristic "pencil point" appearance when viewed under a microscope. This thinning is often the first noticeable histopathological change in psoriasis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B- Kogoj's pustules: 

  • Kogoj's pustules, also known as sub-corneal pustules (collection of neutrophils at the level of stratum spinosum) , are a distinctive feature of pustular psoriasis and are not the first change observed in psoriasis.

Option C- Munro's microabscess: 

  • Munro's microabscess, collections of neutrophils within the epidermis, is a common finding in the chronic phase of psoriasis but is not the earliest change to occur.

Option D- Hyperkeratosis: 

  • Hyperkeratosis, the thickening of the stratum corneum (outermost layer of the epidermis), is observed in psoriasis but tends to develop after supra-papillary thinning.
